Futures for the S&P 500 index rose modestly Thursday morning after the major averages were mixed Wednesday following the Federal Reserve's interest-rate hike and 2018 outlook. Dow tech titans Microsoft (MSFT), Apple (AAPL) and Intel (INTC) continued to act bullishly, trading near key levels.X Apple suppliers Finisar (FNSR) and Lumentum (LITE) continued to move overnight on the Apple-Finisar investment, while industrial coatings and adhesives maker Nordson (NDSN) soared above a buy point on strong earnings.Meanwhile, investors will be focus on the Dow's Walt Disney (DIS). The Mouse releases "Star Wars: The Last Jedi" and just announced a $66 billion deal to buy much of 21st Century Fox (FOXA). Adobe Systems (ADBE), Oracle (ORCL) and Costco Wholesale (COST) will report earnings late Thursday.S&P 500 index futures rose nearly 0.2% vs. fair value. Nasdaq 100 futures gained 0.1%. Dow futures climbed 0.25%.Microsoft fell 0.3% to 85.35 in Wednesday's stock market trading, holding just below an 86.30 flat-base buy point. Microsoft rebounded from just above its 50-day moving average starting on Dec. 5.The stock rose 0.3% in Thursday's premarket.Microsoft is seeing huge growth in cloud-computing services, moving the needle as its legacy PC-based Windows business stagnates. Microsoft on Wednesday rolled out new features for its Bing search service powered by artificial intelligence, including one that highlights reputable sources.The other half of the Wintel duopoly also is moving past PCs finally, finding strong demand for its chips in data centers — partly a reflection of cloud-computing demand. And Intel acquired Mobileye last year to provide fuel for its autonomous-driving efforts.Intel rose 1 cent to 43.34 on Wednesday, continuing to close above its rising 50-day moving average. It's a critical test, especially with most leading chipmakers trading below that key support area. If Intel rises strongly in high volume, it could offer a new buying opportunity. The chip giant also boasts a 47.40 entry from its ongoing flat-base consolidation.Intel was not yet active Thursday.Apple rose 0.3% to 172.27 on Wednesday. The iPhone titan needs a few more days to complete its flat base, or base-on-base formation. But if it does, it would have a 176.34 buy point.Apple edged up 0.2% Thursday.Apple will invest $390 million in Finisar to help the latter revamp a Texas plant, the companies said Wednesday. Finisar will make vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers used in the iPhone X to power its Face ID identification software and other apps.Finisar shot up 23% to 23.70 during the regular session, then rose 2.7% in premarket trading Thursday.Finisar's gain was seen as coming at the expense of Lumentum. Lumentum shares plunged as low as 44.05 intraday, but closed down just 2.85% at 50.28, near session highs.Lumentum rose 2.6% early Thursday, nearly recouping Wednesday's loss.The maker of adhesives and industrial coatings and systems earned $1.38 a share in its fiscal fourth quarter vs. $1.39 a year earlier. But that beat views for $1.32, according to Zacks Investment Research. Revenue swelled 13% to $573.9 million, well above views for $543 million. Nordson also gave first-quarter guidance that was well above analyst forecasts.Nordson shares shot up 11% in premarket trading to 141. That strongly suggests that Nordson will retake a 127.71 cup-with-handle buy point and hit a record high at Thursday's open.Nordson rose 2.2% to 126.91 on Wednesday, retaking its 50-day line.The stock's Relative Strength Line has been lagging since late May, reflecting Nordson's underperformance vs. the rising S&P 500 index over that span.RELATED:The Big Picture: Are These Leading Growth Stocks Acting Well?Disney's Disturbance In The Force, Adobe Earnings: Investing Action Plan2 Drug Stocks Among These 3 Leaders Taking Out Buy PointsDow Jones Industrial Average And Dow Stocks: News And Analysis

Media stocks sold off for the second day in a row on Friday, with Discovery Communications (DISCA) and Viacom (VIA) again faring the worst.XCable TV companies and media stocks have been pressured by renewed worries that pay-TV cord-cutting is accelerating as consumers switch to on-demand internet video. Pay-TV providers pay content firms per-subscriber fees."Investors have seemingly adopted a zero-tolerance approach to anything remotely negative, be it an acceleration in subscriber declines (Discovery), a miss on ad growth (Scripps Networks Interactive (SNI)), a miss on quarterly operations (CBS (CBS)) or simply a miss on being liked (Viacom)," Steven Cahall, an analyst at RBC Capital, said in a note to clients."Put it altogether and there may be practically nowhere in media investors feel safe owning, so it's officially a rental market," added Cahall.Discovery fell 4.6% to close at 16.52 on the stock market today. Viacom lost 0.9% to 28.40. On Thursday, Discovery plunged nearly 10%, while Viacom shed 6%.Scripps fell 1.7% to 79.61 on Friday after slipping 3% Thursday. 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA) fell 3.3% to 24.97 Friday after a slight skid on Thursday."We see a few paths to media getting back in favor, but admittedly none are easy fixes," Cahall said. "One avenue to a bull move would be stabilization of key indicators: subscriber declines and ratings. Unfortunately that doesn't currently appear to be happening."IBD'S TAKE: If you want to understand the state of the market, read IBD's Stock Market Today columns throughout the market day, and The Big Picture (take a free trial) at the day's end for timely market analysis.CBS gained 1.7% to close at 55.40 on Friday after slipping 3% Thursday. Walt Disney (DIS) was up a fraction to 98.64 on Friday. Disney fell nearly 1% Thursday.CBS on Thursday reported revenue of $3.17 billion, up 3% from a year earlier, missing views of $3.26 billion. "The revenue miss was driven primarily by lower content licensing revenue of $860 million, down 22% year-over-year against tough comparisons in the prior year, which had sales of 'Penny Dreadful' as well as a renewal of library content with Netflix (NFLX)," said UBS analyst John Hodulik in a report.RELATED:AT&T, Time Warner Deal In Distress? The major averages closed mixed as the Nasdaq edged lower even as as technology stocks tried to reassert market leadership later in the week. Bitcoin screamed higher in wild, roller-coaster action ahead of CBOE (CBOE) launching futures on Sunday. CVS Health (CVS) is buying Aetna (AET) with Amazon (AMZN) a threat while Broadcom (AVGO) is going hostile with its Qualcomm (QCOM) bid.X Home Depot (HD) and Bank of America (BAC) led several big companies announcing new stock buybacks. But many chipmakers and Chinese internets remain damaged.CVS Health (CVS), a major drugstore and pharmacy benefits manager, will pay $69 billion for the No. 3 U.S. health insurer, forging a new giant with the aim of providing insurance, low-cost clinics and low-cost prescription drugs. Meanwhile, the IBD/TIPP Economic Optimism Index edged lower in December, but remained above the break-even 50 level for a 15th straight month. The data reinforce expectations for a Federal Reserve interest rate hike on Wednesday.Shares of First Solar (FSLR) jumped 16% as the largest U.S. solar products maker provided 2018 guidance that topped the consensus estimates on earnings and met on revenue. Meanwhile, Broadcom posted fiscal fourth-quarter results that beat Wall Street targets, guided higher for the current quarter and raised its quarterly cash dividend by 72% to $1.75 per share. (TOL) shares fell 3.6% but are up sharply in 2017 along with other builders.Home Depot (HD) approved a $15 billion buyback and issued a long-term sales forecast. Honeywell (HON) announced an $8 billion buyback. Bank of America (BAC) said it would buy back an extra $5 billion in stock, on top of a $12 billion buyback announcement less than six months ago. Health insurer Anthem (ANTM) OK'd a $5 billion buyback. Mastercard (MA) also OK'd repurchasing up to $4 billion in common shares. It also hiked its dividend by 14% to 25 cents. United Airlines (UAL) announced a $3 billion buyback. T-Mobile (TMUS) announced a $1.5 billion buyback.After a brutal summer for theater chains, Cinemark Holdings (CNK) launched a movie subscription membership program that gives customers discounts on tickets, concessions and other benefits. Helios & Matheson (HMNY), which offers a similar subscription service, tumbled 30%. Ford also inked a online sales deal with Alibaba (BABA) and said it continues to work with Chinese search giant Baidu (BIDU) on self-driving technology. Ford and General Motors (GM) are among automakers with plans to electrify most models or their entire lineup in coming years, driven in large part by China's clean-car push. BMW (BMWYY) said it is aiming for a 50% increase in electric vehicle sales next year.Fiber-optic companies Ciena (CIEN) and Finisar (FNSR) reported better-than-expected quarterly revenue but missed on profit. Hulu has a new CEO — and for the second time in a row it's an executive from part-owner 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA).Hulu on Tuesday named Randy Freer, president and chief operating officer of Fox Networks Group, as its new CEO. Mike Hopkins, Hulu's chief executive since 2013, is leaving to join Sony (SNE). Hopkins worked in network distribution for Fox Broadcasting before joining Hulu.Analysts have speculated over the years that Fox would like to gain majority control over Hulu, though it's not clear who the sellers might be. Comcast obtained a stake in Hulu by acquiring NBCUniversal from General Electric (GE). But Comcast hasn't had a say in management under conditions set on the NBCU deal. Those terms expire in September.Online TV service Hulu is a joint venture of Fox, Walt Disney (DIS)), Comcast (CMCSA) and Time Warner (TWX). AT&T (T) stands to be a part-owner if federal regulators approve its acquisition of Time Warner.IBD'S TAKE: If you want to understand the state of the stock market, read  The Big Picture at day's end (take a free trial) for timely market analysis and highlighted growth stocks breaking out of proper bases.Hulu launched a live TV service featuring content from three of the four major broadcast networks in early 2017. Hulu's video-on-demand service competes with Netflix (NFLX).UBS recently estimated that Hulu Live has 175,000 subscribers. Comcast reports third-quarter earnings on Thursday. Hulu's owners may disclose more data during third-quarter earnings. Fox reports earnings on Nov. 8, and Disney on Nov. 9. Netflix (NFLX) stock rose Wednesday after investment bank Wells Fargo initiated coverage of the internet television network with a bullish report and a sky-high price target.XWells Fargo started coverage of Netflix with an outperform rating and a price target of 230. Netflix was up 1.4% to close at 181.97 on the stock market today.Netflix shares have been forming a cup base over the past 10 weeks with a buy point of 191.60. Netflix hit a record high of 191.50 on July 21, four days after reporting better-than-expected results for the second quarter.Los Gatos, Calif.-based Netflix has been facing increased competition lately from rival subscription video-on-demand services including Amazon.com (AMZN) and Hulu. Plus, it has been rocked by news that content providers Walt Disney (DIS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) plan to focus on their own streaming video services.Disney announced Aug. 8 that it plans to pull its theatrical movies — including Pixar, Marvel and "Star Wars" films — from Netflix in about two years and start its own subscription video-on-demand service in 2019.IBD'S TAKE: The FANG group of closely watched internet stocks is made up of Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google-parent Alphabet. For the latest news on the group, visit IBD's page on FANG stocks.FX Networks, a unit of 21st Century Fox, intends to pull its shows off rival streaming services, such as Netflix and Amazon, to put them on its recently launched FX+ streaming service. Earlier this week, it announced that it will be adding all seasons of its critically acclaimed series "The Americans," as well as new shows "Atlanta" and "Legion," to the programming lineup of FX+.Wells Fargo analyst Ken Sena believes that Netflix has a big lead in the subscription video-on-demand sector and should be able to widen it."Netflix continues to improve the quality of its streaming service with more content, a better interface, and a more informed view of who is watching what content, a trend we see as only continuing," Sena said in a report. "Netflix will likely be harder than others to catch competitively."RELATED:Roku Prepares To Clash With Titans In Fierce Streaming-TV FieldHulu Beats Netflix, Amazon To Milestone In Emmy Award VictoryNetflix's Success In Brazil Shows It Doesn't Need Disney

Reports that federal regulators may file a lawsuit to block AT&T's (T) $85 billion purchase of media giant Time Warner (TWX) are likely tied to deadlocked talks over conditions — possibly involving the internet video market — that could be required for deal approval, analysts say.The Wall Street Journal reported Thursday that the Department of Justice could sue to block the deal. The DOJ could be trying to increase its negotiating leverage in setting conditions on the deal, says a Cowen & Co. report."We would also observe that the last two times that DOJ actually challenged deals (AT&T/T-Mobile (TMUS), Comcast (CMCSA)-Time Warner Cable), it did not let its litigation intentions be known," said the Cowen report."AT&T could be pushing back hard with DOJ on the conditions," the Cowen report added. "It could be that AT&T is frustrated because it hoped Makan Delrahim would arrive at DOJ and cut back or eliminate the conditions staff wants to impose."The U.S. Senate recently confirmed President Trump's appointment of Makan Delrahim to head the DOJ's antitrust division.Experts have said, however, that DOJ officials may be looking at the video market's structure to set conditions on the deal. Regulators may be seeking deal parameters based on an economic analysis of emerging internet video services and the pay TV market.One condition for DOJ approval, for example, might be requiring AT&T to sell Time Warner content to internet video rivals, rather than keeping the content for itself. AT&T, which acquired satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV in 2015, is the biggest provider of pay TV services by number of subscribers.AT&T, in a statement, said "vertical" deals do not raise fundamental antitrust concerns."For over 40 years, vertical mergers like this one have always been approved because they benefit consumers without removing any competitors from the market," AT&T said in a news release. The company went on to say: "While we won't comment on our discussions with DOJ, we see no reason in the law or the facts why this transaction should be an exception."IBD'S TAKE: If you want to understand the state of the market, read IBD's Stock Market Today columns throughout the market day, and The Big Picture (take a free trial) at the day's end for timely market analysis and highlighted growth stocks breaking out of proper bases.President Donald Trump promised on the campaign trail in October 2016 that he'd kill the deal because it concentrates too much "power in the hands of too few." Time Warner rebuffed a takeover by Rupert Murdoch's 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA) in 2014.AT&T fell 1.1% to 33.17 on the stock market today. Time Warner slipped 3.8% to close at 94.70. AT&T agreed to pay $107 per share, half in cash, to acquire Time Warner.Based on terms of the deal, though, Time Warner shareholders could get less than $107 per share depending on where AT&T stock is trading when the deal closes.RELATED:Could Softbank Take Sprint Private If T-Mobile Deal Is Dead?Three Reasons Why Telecom Merger Party On Hold: Goldman SachsTelecom Mergers: A 'Game Of Thrones' Without The Dragons

When Amazon.com (AMZN) began offering live Thursday Night Football streaming this fall, some wondered if it was the beginning of the end for traditional sports broadcasting.XSuddenly, the door cracked open for technology companies to buy the rights for more major sporting events. Now it seems possible that when the rights for NFL's Monday Night Football and Major League Baseball games go up for renewal in 2021-22, Amazon, Facebook (FB), Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and perhaps Apple (AAPL) could be in the mix.Don't expect a complete changing of the guard, though. Whether digital companies show up at auctions is a wild card for sports leagues as team valuations soar and player salaries continue to rise. The biggest swing factor pushing the future value of sports rights higher will be how serious new digital players are in winning deals, says BTIG Research.Further, incumbent broadcasters have good reason to bid aggressively, since live sports is one of the few tools they have left to maintain audience ratings and set high advertising prices. Some observers doubt digital platforms will gain exclusive rights to a major sports contract or championship event and push over-the-air broadcasters to the sidelines. Broadcasters offer national reach, something streaming services can't match."People keep trying to bury broadcast," Les Moonves, chief executive at network icon CBS (CBS), said at a recent industry conference. "It's still the best game in town if you want a mass audience."To be sure, you can expect tech titans will battle the old guard of traditional media for contracts over the next decade. Moonves' CBS, Walt Disney's (DIS) ESPN, AT&T (T), Comcast's (CMCSA) NBC, and 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA) will have to fend them off to keep streaming rights — just as live entertainment becomes vital for keeping young viewers.Already, digital companies have stepped up spending for sports streaming rights, including tennis, soccer, baseball and fringe events like surfing. Facebook recently raised eyebrows by bidding $610 million to stream cricket games in India, but lost out to a rival.In Amazon's case, it paid $50 million for the Thursday Night Football rights, five times more than Twitter (TWTR) paid a year earlier. Experts say there could be much more on the horizon for the e-commerce giant. There's speculation that Amazon may bid for U.K. Premier League soccer matches when an auction launches next year."It could be like the Roaring Twenties from a sports rights standpoint, with a slew of competitors competing for a limited number of sports rights," said Lee Berke, head of consultancy LHB Sports, Entertainment & Media.Some observers, though, doubt digital platforms will gain exclusive rights to a major sports contract or championship event and push aside the likes of cable's ESPN and over-the-air broadcasters.Right now, digital companies' bidding still looks puny next to the roughly $11 billion a year that U.S. sports leagues rake in from broadcasters and ESPN.If anything, digital players are likely to "coexist" with the incumbents, CBS's Moonves said.The Thursday Night Football deal is an example of a peaceful coexistence for traditional and digital media, as Amazon has streaming rights and NBC and CBS share broadcast rights. Leagues could set up more deals like that, awarding broadcast and streaming rights separately.Complicating the issue is that sports salaries as well as team valuations continue to go up, partly on the expectation that revenue from broadcast and streaming rights will rise. Forbes says the Dallas Cowboys are worth $4.8 billion, up 14% from a year ago. The Houston Rockets basketball team recently sold for $2.2 billion.The average NBA salary in 2016 was $6.4 million, with the MLB average at $4.4 million and the NFL at $2.44 million, says Sporting Intelligence."Some teams are going full blast, assuming that revenue levels will either sustain themselves or have some moderate growth going forward," said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College who specializes in the sports business."(Leagues) could take a revenue hit," Zimbalist added. "It's not going to be immediate because most deals aren't up for renewal over the next five years. So it's not going to be cataclysmic overnight."One wrinkle is that tech companies may play a different ballgame with different goals. In Amazon's case, only members of its Prime loyalty program, which offers free deliveries and other perks, can watch the Thursday Night Football games.Amazon's streaming viewership has been higher than Twitter's for the first few games, though still a small fraction of the broadcast audience. Thursday NFL game ratings overall have dipped amid President Trump's recommendation that Americans not watch football games if players do not stand for the national anthem.But "ratings aren't the story for Amazon," LHB's Berke said. "The real story is their ability to develop additional subscribers to Amazon Prime, and the longer-term story of getting ready to bid for exclusive sports rights down the road."Amazon has an estimated 69 million Prime members in the U.S. who pay $99 annually. If football brings in more Prime members, proves popular with existing ones and boosts Amazon advertising revenue, then the company would have more reason to spend megabucks on sports contracts.Berke adds that demographics need to change as well.Major League Baseball and tennis have the oldest average TV viewers at 57 and 61 years old, respectively. The National Basketball Association has the youngest at 42 years old, and the NFL is in the middle at 50 years old, according to a Sports Business Journal study. With digital platforms, sports leagues aim to engage millennials with social-media features that change the viewing experience."There's a very large but shrinking pay-TV universe (and)  a small but growing OTT (internet) universe along with social media," Berke said."No one wants to abandon large audiences and large (broadcast) revenue streams," he said. "But more opportunities are going to digital platforms. It's a small but growing audience and it's young. Any sports property is looking for its next generation of fans."Sports leagues fret that frozen screens could spark social-media storms. But despite video-streaming quality qualms, Smith College's Zimbalist says sports leagues will welcome internet players to the negotiating table."Historically, they've always taken the richer offer; at one time, cable was the new (revenue) source," he said.If Amazon streams football games to a few million viewers without a hitch, it'll be a plus for Facebook, Google's YouTube and other digital players possibly in the hunt for big sports deals.Brian Rolapp, chief media and business officer for the NFL, says that's just the start.Rolapp recently told a conference that the technical challenges of streaming live sports with just 10 million or more concurrent viewers are formidable.For now, that rules out exclusive streaming deals for the Super Bowl, World Series or NBA championship, which can have viewership up to 10 times the viewers that streamers are capable of handling. But Monday Night Football, now shown by ESPN, has topped out at 10 or 11 million viewers, seemingly in the ballpark of what streaming services can deliver.And it may only be a matter of time before the numbers aren't so daunting for digital players. The sports industry's top spender, ESPN, has watched its pay-TV subscriber count fall. As profits dwindle, many analysts expect the cable sports behemoth to pare spending or refocus its priorities.If ESPN walks away from its Monday Night Football deal at renewal time, Amazon or another internet company could bid for rights, Michael Nathanson, analyst at MoffettNathanson, said in a recent report."Will a digital company finally be willing to write a big enough check four to five years from now?" he asked.And another question lurks: Will streaming rights necessarily go to Silicon Valley companies?CBS and ESPN, owing to its purchase of digital media firm BAM Tech, also figure in future streaming negotiations.BAM Tech's new chief executive, Michael Paull, is the former vice president of streaming video at Amazon. Founded by Major League Baseball, BAM Tech also handles back-end streaming for golf, hockey and wrestling.ESPN is readying a new stand-alone sports streaming service, due out in 2018. It will not stream the same live content it shows on pay TV. Major League Baseball says it will license some out-of-market games for ESPN's new service.Dan Rayburn, executive VP of StreamingMedia.com., adds that unlike broadcasters, internet companies do not control end-to-end delivery."Google is not a last-mile provider. Neither is Facebook or Amazon," Rayburn said. "Broadcast and streaming are very different in how they distribute content."

Google's YouTube TV has 200,000 subscribers and could hit 2 million by the end of 2018, says one Wall Street analyst.Andy Hargreaves of KeyBanc Capital Markets says YouTube TV isn't yet profitable but that doesn't matter to Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL). Hargreaves says Google aims to build a brand that can take away advertising revenue from traditional TV."The service is now rolled out to almost 50 cities, which should drive accelerating subscriber growth in the second half of 2017 and into 2018," he said in a note to clients.YouTube TV features live content from major broadcasters. It's priced at $35 monthly, or $40 as an app on Apple (AAPL) TV. YouTube TV's progress is being closely watched, because Google is a new entrant in video streaming. Other video streaming services are offered by incumbent pay-TV or media companies, with the exception of Sony.AT&T (T) sells DirecTV Now and Dish Network (DISH) offers Sling TV. Hulu launched a live TV service in May. Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA), Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal and Time Warner (TWX) all have a stake in Hulu.Amazon.com (AMZN), similar to Google, is a newcomer to video streaming. Amazon Prime Video does not yet offer live TV from the big four broadcasters. Amazon Prime Video has stepped up investments in original content and is similar to Netflix (NFLX). Apple said in September that it expects to offer an Amazon Video Prime app on its TV platform later this year.Hargreaves has an overweight rating on Google stock, with a price target of 1,100. Alphabet shares ended trading Tuesday up 0.5% to 972.08.IBD'S TAKE: If you want to understand the state of the market, read IBD's Stock Market Today columns throughout the market day, and the end-of-day The Big Picture (take a free trial) for timely market analysis and highlighted growth stocks breaking out of proper bases."We estimate content costs are $39.55 per sub, and expect operating expenses to be 17% of revenue," he said. "This suggests YouTube TV will generate operating margins of minus 4%, with largely variable costs that are likely to prevent meaningful leverage in the medium term.""Despite a likely lack of direct profits, YouTube TV provides Google with a portion of TV ad inventory on the service," Hargreaves went on to say. "We believe YouTube TV represents a significant opportunity to capture share of the $70 billion U.S. TV ad market."RELATED:EU To Hit Apple, FANG Stocks With Digital Tax If Ireland Goes AlongShort Sellers Step Up Bets Against Netflix, Amazon, FacebookFacebook, Amazon, Google: Should They Now Fear Regulators?Stocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth StocksLeaderboard: Daily Updates On Stocks With Potential For Big Gains

Over the past six weeks, short sellers have been raising their bets that so-called "FAANG" stocks are due for a fall, according to a financial analytics firm.S3 Partners says growing short interest in what traditionally has been known as the FANG group — which includes four closely watched internet stocks: Facebook (FB), Amazon.com (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned Google — along with Apple (AAPL) indicates a bearish stance in those big-cap tech firms, which some collectively refer to as FAANG."We're seeing a broad-based increase in short interest across the board," Brett Weiss, director of business development at S3 Partners, said Friday.Short selling involves the sale of a stock that has been borrowed by the seller. The seller believes that the stock's price will decline, enabling it to be bought back later at a lower price to make a profit.Bearish bets against the FAANGs have increased by 7.6% since mid-August, Weiss said. The total at risk in the short selling bets against those stocks is about $27.3 billion, S3 said.The largest increases in short investments have been in Facebook, Amazon and Netflix, S3 said.Short sellers have increased their positions in Netflix by $910.5 million since Aug. 15. They've upped their short positions in Facebook and Amazon by $494 million and $502 million, respectively.By contrast, they've lowered their short positions in Apple by $161.8 million over the past six weeks.Short sellers appear to be rotating out of Apple since its Sept. 12 fall product launch event, where it introduced the iPhone X and iPhone 8 series smartphones and the Apple Watch Series 3 smartwatch.Apple stock has fallen about 5% since the company's new product unveiling. Investors reacted negatively to the later-than-expected launch of the iPhone X, pronounced "ten" as in the Roman numeral, and concerns about short supply due to manufacturing issues.Why the increased short interest in Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google lately? It could be related to negative news hammering those big names, Weiss said."There's a lot of news on every one of these stocks," he said. "The FANGs are a popular sector."Facebook, Amazon and Google have been the subject of potential antitrust enforcement to limit their dominance in online advertising and e-commerce.Facebook also has been dragged into the investigation of Russian meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election. Facebook Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg has acknowledged the social network ran some 3,000 politically themed advertisements that were bought by suspected Russian operatives. The disclosure could potentially lead to some government regulation on political ads and subject Facebook to more regulatory scrutiny.IBD'S TAKE: For the latest news on Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Google-parent Alphabet, visit IBD's page on FANG stocks.Zuckerberg, meanwhile, revealed plans around Sept. 22 that he considered creating a new class of company stock with no voting power — but abandoned the idea. He also plans to sell a big chunk of his own shares.Netflix is facing the prospect of more Hollywood studios pulling their content off the Internet TV network, following recent moves by Walt Disney (DIS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA). Disney and Fox plan to focus on their own subscription video-on-demand services that would compete with Netflix.While Apple is down 4.6% since Aug. 15, Netflix is up 7.6% in that period. Netflix is approaching its all-time high of 191.50, reached on July 21.Netflix rose 0.4% to 181.35 on the stock market today. It has been forming a cup-with-handle base over the past 10 weeks with a buy point of 191.60.Netflix has mostly shaken off worries about losing traditional studio content because it has been aggressively ramping up production of original content, including hit shows like "Stranger Things."Netflix also is facing heightened competition from streaming rivals like Amazon Prime Video and Hulu.Facebook climbed 1.3% to 170.87 on Friday. That's just below its record high of 175.49, hit on July 27. Facebook stock has been forming a flat base for the past nine weeks with a buy point of 175.59.Amazon rose 0.5% to 961.35 on Friday. It has been forming a flat base over the past 10 weeks with a buy point of 1,083.41.Alphabet was up 0.9% to 973.72 on Friday. It is in a 17-week flat base with a buy point of 1,008.71.Critics of Facebook, Amazon and Google say those internet companies have become too dominant and are snuffing out competition, innovation and even freedom of expression. Pressure is mounting on U.S. regulators to scrutinize the impact those companies are having on competition, Wall Street analysts say.Amazon has been blamed for playing a big part in the "retail apocalypse" that has major chains shuttering stores nationwide, with some going bankrupt. On Sept. 19, toy seller Toys R Us filed for bankruptcy, with Amazon listed among the reasons for its woes.More recently Amazon has been taken aim at Grubhub (GRUB) in the online food ordering and delivery business and is rumored to be exploring an entry into the prescription drug dispensing industry.RELATED:Netflix Stock Gets Thumbs Up From Fresh Analyst ReportFacebook, Amazon, Google: Should They Now Fear Regulators?The Amazon Monopoly Problem: Prime Time For Antitrust Action Vs. Internet Giants?This $300 Billion Amazon Rumor Just Won't Die

Goldman Sachs says it knows why the telecom industry's merger party has been put on hold.X"Evolving business models, more immediate priorities and regulatory uncertainty have likely limited deal making," Brett Feldman, a Goldman Sachs analyst said in a note to clients.Despite speculation involving T-Mobile US (TMUS), Sprint (S), Charter Communications (CHTR), Comcast (CMCSA), Dish Network (DISH) and Verizon Communications (VZ), no big deals have been announced in 2017.Feldman looked at what might be holding companies back, ahead of Goldman Sachs' annual Communacopia conference. It starts Tuesday in New York.Some deals would create bigger wireless or cable TV companies while others might combine a wireless company with a cable TV firm."As the industry landscape shifts, we believe that major operators are continually re-evaluating their strategic direction and options," added Feldman. 'It is not hard to understand why companies are not rushing into deals that may set their course for the next decade."AT&T (T) Chief Executive Randall Stephenson kicks off the conference Tuesday morning. Europe-based Altice Group, possibly readying an offer for Charter, and Comcast CEO Brian Roberts also are slated for Tuesday.On Wednesday, media firms Viacom (VIA) CEO Robert Bakish and 21st Century Fox's (FOXA) executive chairman Lachlan Murdoch are expected to be on hand. Verizon CEO Lowell McAdam is scheduled to appear Thursday morning.AT&T is awaiting Trump administration approval for its acquisition of media giant Time Warner (TWX), announced in October. A Sprint merger with T-Mobile is still viewed by analysts as the industry's most likely deal.IBD'S TAKE: With thousands of publicly-traded companies to choose from, how can you quickly find the best stocks to buy right now? A good starting point is to regularly review screens that highlight the top-rated equities."Under the Trump administration, we have seen a rapid pace of deregulation by the Federal Communications Commission," said Feldman. "While this implies a potentially more favorable regulatory back drop for pursuing M&A, we have not yet seen the FCC or the Department of Justice weigh in on any major mergers under this administration. As such, the major operators lack context for whether regulators take a different view on market structure than we saw under President Obama."RELATED:Top Questions Apple Will Face At Sept. 12 iPhone EventTelecom Mergers: A 'Game Of Thrones' Without The Dragons

Disney (DIS) CEO Bob Iger warned Thursday that profit will be weaker than expected this year and seemed to dash hopes that Netflix (NFLX) will retain Star Wars and Marvel content after the media conglomerate launches its own streaming service.XWhile speaking at the Bank of America Merrill Lynch 2017 Media, Communications & Entertainment Conference, Iger put earnings per share this year "roughly in line" with Disney's fiscal 2016 EPS, according to CNBC.That fiscal year, which ended in September 2016, saw EPS of $5.72, and the consensus for this year has it rising to $5.87, according to Zacks Investment Research.The weaker fiscal 2017 outlook implies Q4 EPS of $1.09, well below consensus views for $1.25. Iger blamed the expected effects of Hurricane Irma in Disney's Florida resorts, higher costs for NBA broadcast rights, the investment in BAMTech, and the lack of a major Star Wars movie release ("Star Wars: The Last Jedi" will be released at the start of fiscal 2018).Disney shares closed down 4.4% at 97.06 on the stock market today. Viacom (VIAB) lost 3.6%, 21st Century Fox (FOXA) dropped 2.4% and CBS (CBS) fell 2.1%. Netflix edged down 0.1%. NBC Universal owner Comcast (CMCSA) sank 6% after it lowered its outlook.IBD'S TAKE: Silicon Valley and Hollywood's convergence continues, amid a growing battle to own and stream television shows and movies — and get people to pay for them in the process. Here's how the big media and tech players match up. Meanwhile, Disney's upcoming streaming app will have four to five original Disney series and three to four exclusive Disney movies, Iger said, adding that Star Wars and Marvel titles will be seen exclusively on the app.Last month, Disney announced its streaming app and said it would no longer provide content to Netflix. U.S. Netflix members will have access to Disney films on the service through the end of 2019.But just days after Disney said it would pull movie content from the streaming site, Netflix Chief Content Officer Ted Sarandos told Reuters that the company was "still in active discussions" to keep "Star Wars" and Marvel movies on the platform.Iger said on Disney's earnings call last month that it was "possible" that both Marvel and Lucasfilm theatrical titles will continue to be licensed to pay services such as Netflix. He also floated the possibility of creating stand-alone proprietary services for each studio brand.RELATED:Comcast Stock Plunges On Video Subscriber Losses, Hurricane ImpactLayoffs, Restructuring Said To Hit Disney-ABC Television SoonStreaming Content May Become King, But Who Will Wear The Crown?Looking For The Best Stocks To Buy And Watch? Start HereApple, Studios May Upend The Way We Watch Movies: Report

Entertainment heavyweight 21st Century Fox (FOXA) has acquired mobile video game maker Aftershock through its gaming arm, FoxNext.The deal is worth tens of millions, according to the Wall Street Journal, citing a source familiar with the acquisition. The Wall Street Journal is owned by News Corp. (NWSA), which like 21st Century Fox is controlled by the Murdoch family.FoxNext, which includes FoxNext Games, FoxNext Destinations and FoxNext VR Studio, develops virtual reality, augmented reality, mobile, console and PC games for 20th Century Fox and Fox Networks Group. Its titles include "The Simpsons Tapped Out," "Family Guy: The Quest for Stuff" and "Futurama: Game of Drones."The Aftershock buy is FoxNext's first acquisition since its January inception, said Fox.IBD'S TAKE: Investor's Business Daily will be at video gaming mecca E3 on June 13-14, covering the latest news from Activision (ATVI), Electronic Arts (EA), Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox, Sony (SNE) PlayStation and more.Aftershock, which is currently working on an "Avatar" game, is a spinoff of Kabam after South Korean gaming company NetMarble bought out Kabam for a reported $800 million. The Kabam acquisition was completed earlier this year.Shares of Fox fell 0.8% to 27.53 in the stock market today. The stock is trying to get back above its 200-day moving average after tumbling in April and most of May.Last year, Walt Disney (DIS) shuttered its Infinity gaming unit and pulled out of the video game business, taking a $147 million charge.Disney recently opened the gates to its new "Avatar" land, Pandora — The World of Avatar, in Orlando.Disney shares fell 1% to 105.50, falling intraday to a 2017 low.RELATED:Can Disney's New 'Avatar' Land Help Ease ESPN Anxiety? Yes And NoDisney's Exit From Toys-To-Life Video Games Could Boost Activision

Charter Communications (CHTR) is testing a live-TV streaming service that starts at just under $20 with no sports content.Time Warner's (TWX) HBO, meanwhile, may be heading to Hulu.Charter, which brands its online service Spectrum Stream, says the base package includes local broadcast channels and 25 cable networks, including AMC, CNN, A&E, History, TNT and Discovery (DISCA).A $12 monthly add-on package includes ESPN channels, NBC Sports, and Bloomberg news. A $15 monthly option includes movie channels.Dish Network (DISH) launched its Sling streaming service at $20 in January 2015 with Walt Disney's (DIS) ESPN, but lacked local TV stations from the four broadcast networks.Charter's Spectrum Stream service, if commercially launched, would also compete with AT&T's (T) DirecTV Now, which starts at $35, as well as Hulu and Sony's web offering.Verizon Communications (VZ) has signaled that it could launch a video streaming service in the second half of 2017.IBD'S TAKE: Charter stock is up about 15% in 2017 but is trading near its 50-day moving average. Charter stock has a technical buy point of 341.60. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Hulu is a joint venture of Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA), Disney, and Comcast (CMCSA). Time Warner acquired a 10% stake in Hulu last year.AT&T, which is seeking regulatory approval to acquire Time Warner for $85 billion, has offered a free year of HBO in some DirecTV Now promotions. Time Warner also sells HBO as a stand-alone online product for $15 monthly.RELATED:Sprint Jumps On Comcast-Charter Wireless TalksComcast, Charter Fall; Longtime Industry Bull Downgrades Sector

Here's your Investing Action Plan for Friday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming day. Movie awards don't necessarily translate to box office returns, and film studios are only one component of conglomerates that derive revenue from a variety of sources. But this weekend's Oscars highlight the solid performance of media stocks recently like Disney (DIS)…

A Republican-led FCC may give AT&T (T), Comcast (CMCSA), Verizon Communications (VZ) and other pay TV providers more tools to counter the threat from Google TV, Hulu and other nascent internet video services, says a Cowen & Co. analyst.Ajit Pai, named chairman of the Federal Communications Commission by President Trump in January, has signaled that he'll scale back net neutrality rules that bar internet service providers from throttling, blocking or prioritizing web traffic. Under the Obama administration, the FCC sought more authority under utility-type regulations.Paul Gallant, an analyst at Cowen & Co., says "MVPDs" a regulatory term for pay TV incumbents, could seek interconnection fees from YouTube TV or Hulu. Gallant warned that MVPDs like AT&T, Comcast and Verizon might tap other tools to counter the threat from internet video services, also called over-the-top, or OTT, services. Broadband caps on data usage are another possibility, Gallant says.Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) on Tuesday announced YouTube TV, a $35 monthly paid subscription service. YouTube TV will offer access to all four major broadcast networks (CBS, ABC, NBC and Fox), and the cable channel offerings owned by their parent companies, such as sports channel ESPN.IBD'S TAKE: Quanta Services, Primerica and Nucor are on IBD's Leaderboard, which follows top stocks from their work on forming bases, through their breakouts, to their post-breakout action, up to the point where they start topping.Google aims to set itself apart with unlimited cloud storage for users to record content. Google will seek advertising revenue from YouTube TV, say analysts, who contend that $35 monthly fees might not be enough to make the service profitable.Hulu — a joint venture of Walt Disney (DIS), Fox-parent 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA) and Comcast's NBCUniversal — is set to launch yet another live TV streaming service in the spring."With the rising OTT threat and a newly Republican Washington, MVPDs may now have greater incentive and ability to employ tactics to manage the threat from OTT," Gallant said in a research report. "Whether they take these steps — and whether it draws influential companies like Google, Facebook (FB), Walt Disney, Fox and others into the net neutrality debate — could be important for the longer-term balance of power within the internet ecosystem.""We suspect the new FCC will be much more open to ISPs charging interconnection fees to high bandwidth services, mainly video providers," Gallant added.He says Google could respond by imposing a "Cable Company X Tax" on its subscribers.YouTube TV will compete with other internet video services, such as AT&T's DirecTV Now and Dish Network's (DISH) Sling. YouTube TV does not provide channels from Viacom (VIA), Time Warner's (TWX) Turner Broadcasting, Discovery (DISCA) , AMC Networks (AMCX) and Scripps Networks Interactive (SNI).Alphabet stock slipped a small fraction in the stock market today to 849.08 and is about flat since the YouTube streaming announcement.RELATED:$35 DirecTV Now Live Streaming Deals Lives On After Promotion EndsAT&T Streaming Foray Hits Snag; Did Apple Avoid Black Eye?Google Advertising Plans Key In YouTube TV Launch Vs. AT&T, Hulu

Google's pricing and content lineup for YouTube TV — its planned live-TV subscription-streaming service — has Wall Street analysts abuzz over implications for the likes of AT&T, Time Warner, Comcast, and Hulu parents Walt Disney and Fox, as well as second-tier media companies excluded from new online packages.YouTube is already a big moneymaker for Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL). One big question is how much Google-owned YouTube's advertising revenue will grow as it adds live TV and original content for paid subscription services.Google on Tuesday took the wraps off YouTube TV, which will be "available soon in the largest U.S. markets and will quickly expand to cover more cities across the country," the company said in a blog.YouTube TV will compete with other internet video services, such as AT&T's (T) DirecTV Now and Dish Network's (DISH) Sling. Hulu — a joint venture of Disney (DIS), Fox parent 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA) and Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal — is set to launch yet another live TV streaming service in the spring.YouTube TV will offer access to all four major broadcast networks (CBS, ABC, NBC and Fox), and the cable channel offerings owned by their parent companies, such as sports channel ESPN. Missing from the content lineup, though, are channels from Viacom (VIA), Time Warner's (TWX) Turner Broadcasting, Discovery (DISCA), AMC Networks (AMCX) and Scripps Networks Interactive (SNI).YouTube TV starts at $35 monthly, similar to AT&T's DirecTV Now service, but it's unclear whether YouTube's will eke out profits even with fewer channels. Alphabet stock rose 1.4% to 856.75 in the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: Alphabet stock is up 8% in 2017 and has cleared an 824.40 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The stock is still in a buy range. Learn more about Alphabet's growth trends and chart at IBD Stock Checkup.Here are some analyst take-aways from Google's announcement:RELATED:$35 DirecTV Now Live Streaming Deals Lives On After Promotion EndsAT&T Streaming Foray Hits Snag; Did Apple Avoid Black Eye?

BAMTech is adding some serious muscle to the top of its masthead, as Amazon (AMZN) vet Michael Paull has been named CEO of the streaming platform jointly owned by MLB Advanced Media, Walt Disney (DIS) and the National Hockey League.Paull, who had been at Amazon since 2012, was most recently the vice president of Amazon's digital video operations and oversaw Amazon Channels' content, product, technology, operations and marketing."In his new role, Paull will set the vision and guide this new venture, originally grown out of MLBAM, as he leads its transformation into an independent company driving sustainable high growth," according to the official statement from MLB Advanced Media.Disney shares fell 0.1% to 109.98 in the stock market today but still within buy range. Amazon, which is reportedly looking to add live sports to its own video lineup, climbed 1.35% to 856.44, rising further into its buy range.The BAMTech move comes amid a rapidly changing media landscape that has traditional players such as Disney, CBS (CBS) and others deploying a wide range of strategies in order to adapt.The House of Mouse acquired a 33% stake in BAMTech last year for $1 billion. It has articulated plans for the streamer to launch and distribute an ESPN-branded over-the-top subscription service. It is expected to launch this year.Disney is also a joint owner of streaming service Hulu, a Netflix (NFLX) rival, while Disney-owned Marvel has a four-show deal with Netflix.And the Wall Street Journal recently reported that Disney's yet-to-be-announced streaming bundle deal is with Google's YouTube, owned by Alphabet (GOOGL).IBD'S TAKE: Despite subscription declines at ESPN, Walt Disney head Bob Iger continues to sound bullish on the premium sports cable network. Here's why.Paull is no stranger to the traditional media world. His background includes stints at Sony (SNE) Pictures Entertainment, 21st Century Fox's (FOXA) Fox Entertainment Group, Sony Music Entertainment and Time Warner (TWX).RELATED:FANG Stocks News & Quotes: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, GoogleForce Friday II Will Unveil 'Star Wars: The Last Jedi' ToysDisney Chief's Confidence In ESPN Comes In Part From ... Google?

Meanwhile, Boeing (BA), Lockheed Martin (LMT) and other giants in defense and aerospace will appear at a conference at a time fraught…

Walt Disney (DIS) was subject to mixed reviews Thursday, with one set of Wall Street analysts downgrading the stock and another raising its price target.Pivotal Research handed out a slew of downgrades in the media and tech sectors, as the firm updates its models to "account for minor changes in earnings expectations and more significant changes to costs of capital associated with new political risks following the recent US elections."While Disney's studio arm is performing "spectacularly well," the company received a downgrade from Pivotal to sell from hold."Once again, costs of capital are core to the price target change, which fall to a level that is more than -15% below current trading levels, obliging us to downgrade the stock," wrote Pivotal's Brian Wieser, noting that yields on 10-year Treasury notes have risen significantly.He said the firm wasn't making any "meaningful" changes to its view at an operating level, but noted "soft TV audience trends, ongoing erosion of ESPN's subscriber base and mixed reports on Shanghai Disneyland from Asian press."He also called out uncertainty surrounding Disney's succession plan. Current CEO Bob Iger said he will step down next year, and his heir apparent abruptly left the company last year.Pivotal, which cut its price target on Disney to 86 from 102, also downgraded Discovery Communications (DISCA) and CBS (CBS) from buy to hold. The firm maintained a hold on Viacom (VIAB) and buy ratings on 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Time Warner (TWX).Meanwhile, JPMorgan analyst Alexia Quadrani reiterated an overweight rating on Disney and raised her price target to 124 from 118, calling the media conglomerate's underlying business trends "healthy, which we expect to translate into healthy longer-term earnings growth."IBD'S TAKE: Traditional networks have been trying to find balance in a modern TV-viewing environment plagued by the threat of cord-cutting. That has led some players, like CBS, to maintain its own streaming service while agreeing to join pure-play platforms like Hulu.The bank's confidence in the company is bolstered by "stable" affiliate revenue growth and solid advertising in its cable segment, a "significant" market share lead by its studio unit, and well-performing parks and consumer products segments."We believe Disney is one of the best-positioned companies in our media universe with a diverse portfolio of assets and unparalleled intellectual property that the company is able to monetize across its divisions," she wrote.Disney shares were down 1.75% at 107.53 in the stock market today, still in buy range after breaking out last week. Fox dropped 0.9%, Time Warner edged up 0.2%, CBS and Viacom slipped about 1%, while Discovery rose 2.6%.RELATED:Disney's 'Tide Is Turning' But GoPro, McDonald's Served Downgrades

AT&T's (T) promotional pricing for its DirecTV Now mobile video service will end on Monday, but it'll still have a $35-per-month offer on the table for consumers as Hulu revs up its live-TV service, which the company has said will be priced "under $40."Hulu is a joint venture of 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Walt Disney (DIS) and Comcast (CMCSA). Time Warner (TWX) has a 10% stake in Hulu. AT&T has agreed to buy Time Warner for $85 billion, though President-elect Trump has stated opposition to that merger, fearing too much media strength is being concentrated in too few hands.AT&T launched its video streaming service in late November. While AT&T's "Go Big" package of 100-plus channels will cost $60, up from the promotional $35, starting Jan. 9, DirecTV Now will also offer a 60-channel package called "Live a Little" for $35.AT&T's "Live a Little" package still lacks CBS — which announced a deal with Hulu on Wednesday — and regional sports, but it still could prove a popular offer, says Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson.IBD'S TAKE: CBS is the top-ranked stock in IBD's Media-Diversified group. CBS stock has shot up since forming a cup-with-handle formation in September. Analysts say CBS content is coveted in video streaming packages. CBS could be a takeover target. Learn more about CBS at IBD Stock Checkup. "Virtually all of the channels that anyone would really want, save for regional sports networks, are included in the $35 "Live a Little" package," said Moffett in a research report."The step-up to $50 for the "Just Right" package is arguably a sensible one for a genuine sports fan, but the step-ups from there to the "Go Big" and "Gotta Have It!" packages, at $60 and $70 per month, respectively, are mostly for a bunch of filler," Moffett wrote.AT&T stock fell 2.1% in the stock market today to 41.26. CBS stock, which spiked to a nearly three-year high of 66.88 on Wednesday, fell 1.8% Friday to 64.30.AT&T sells Time Warner's HBO for $5 extra per month, down from its usual $10 to $15 fee. AT&T on Thursday said Time Warner will not need to transfer any of its FCC licenses to AT&T in order to continue to conduct its business operations after the deal closes. If that's the case, analysts say, regulatory approval of the merger could be smoother.It's not clear that Hulu will get all of CBS' programming. CBS, meanwhile, has its own streaming service, CBS All Access, which has over 1.2 million subscribers.Analysts estimate that Dish Networks' (DISH)Sling-branded streaming service, which starts at $20 monthly but with no broadcast channels, has nearly 1 million subscribers.The DirecTV Now streaming service could boost AT&T's wireless business, where growth has stalled amid continuing postpaid subscriber losses. AT&T will not count DirecTV Now streaming toward the monthly data caps of its own wireless subscribers.AT&T's DirecTV Now does not provide a cloud-based DVR service and limits users to two simultaneous video streams.RELATED:CBS, Hulu Officially Ink Deal For New Live-TV ServiceAT&T Taps Apple TV In Launching DirecTV Now Streaming-Video Service
