Given the forecasts for long-term repercussions, however, should investors be taking more notice?The Writers Guild of America and Hollywood studios left talks on Sunday with "cautious optimism," according to Variety, as both sides edge closer to agreement on key points. The current contract expires at midnight, meaning that a work stoppage would begin on Tuesday.The last strike, which lasted for 100 days from November 2007 through February 2008, slammed the entertainment industry by $2.1 billion, according to a Milken Institute report.Moody's analysts said that in the event of another three-month-or-longer stoppage, "weaker media companies with limited financial flexibility could see their credit standing suffer."A shorter strike would not "seriously" impact revenue and cash flow, wrote Moody's Senior Vice President Neil Begley in a Monday note. But a five-month strike or longer, could be "bothersome — and even dire, in some cases" for media companies that need studio content to survive."Most at risk if there is a protracted strike would be movie theater companies, followed by broadcast television networks and premium pay-TV channels, especially companies that are highly leveraged or weakly positioned relative to their existing credit ratings," said Begley."Least at risk would be major studios and broadcasters that are well-diversified and have relatively strong balance sheets."Walt Disney (DIS) shares dipped 0.7% in the stock market today. CBS (CBS) rose 0.1%. NBCUniversal parent Comcast (CMCSA) was unchanged 21st Century Fox (FOXA) retreated 0.5%. Disney and Comcast are in buy range, while CBS is just below a proper entry area.At the heart of negotiations are the funding of the WGA health plan, as well as writers' residuals and compensation structure. Writers say that shorter seasons, a la those favored by the likes of Netflix (NFLX), have meant less pay for the same work time frames, since they are compensated per episode."Residuals formulas are also different across windows and writers are getting a lower share with the decline of traditional syndication and the rise of (video on demand) and (subscription video on demand) services like Netflix," wrote Barclays analyst Kannan Venkateshwar, who spoke on Friday with the WGA's Chris Keyser and Charles Slocum.Netflix shares rose 2.1% to 155.35, hitting a new all-time high. Amazon (AMZN), another streaming video contender that has shaken up the entertainment landscape since the last WGA strike in 2007-2008, rallied 2.5% to 948.43, rising intraday above Friday's record best.IBD's TAKE: Here's a more in-depth look at why Netflix, Amazon and even Facebook could flourish, should Hollywood's writers go on strike Tuesday.The availability of on-demand content online could mean that a strike — which would hobble the fall TV season — would push even more viewers to platforms like Netflix, Amazon, Hulu and others, said Barclays in April. The timing of a possible strike would also muck up the May upfronts season, a key period for media networks and advertisers."While it is likely premature to determine the impact, we believe given the proliferation of content and (over-the-top) platform and online advertising alternatives, the impact of a drawn-out strike this time around could last longer than the 2007 strike," said Venkateshwar in Monday's note.RELATED:If You Think Netflix, Amazon Disrupted Hollywood, You'll Love Snap, Facebook

The major market averages held firm despite political furor over President Trump's abrupt firing of FBI Director James Comey, a Macy's (M)-led retail meltdown, bad news from Walt Disney and a Snap crash. On the upside, Nvidia (NVDA), OLED play Coherent (COHR) and new IPO Trade Desk (TTD) were big winners.The Nasdaq composite rose 0.3% for the week, hitting a new record high Wednesday as Apple (AAPL) and Netflix (NFLX) were among the big-cap techs setting all-time bests. The Dow industrials sank 0.6% and the S&P 500 0.4%. Higher oil prices lifted energy stocks, while bad news from Macy's, J.C. Penney (JCP) and several other retailers sent the broader sector tumbling. Snap fell close to its IPO price as Facebook (FB) competition takes its toll. But Nvidia skyrocketed to record highs on huge demand for its chips for graphics, artificial intelligence and more.Delivering its first earnings report since coming public, Snapchat-operator Snap missed on the top and bottom line. Snap said average revenue per user rose 181%, to 90 cents, but fell from $1.05 in the prior quarter. User growth was weaker than expected, with Facebook successfully cloning Snapchat's most popular features. Shares plunged more than 21% on Thursday to a post-IPO trading low, though they did rise 6% on Friday.3 top-rated IPOs also reported earnings. Digital ad platform Trade Desk (TTD) spiked Friday morning on better-than-expected earnings and revenue. Chip-equipment play Ichor (ICHR) reported results in line with bullish preliminary figures, but gave weak guidance. IT services firm Presidio (PSDO) fell after its results.RELATED:Snap Laughs Off Facebook Competition As Stock Plunges On Earnings MissGraphics chip maker Nvidia (NVDA) earnings rose 85% and sales surged 48% to $1.94 billion, beating views and helped by strong demand for processors for cloud computing data centers. Nvidia shares shot up 23% in the two days after the late Tuesday report. Microchip Technology (MCHP) and MaxLinear (MXL) also rallied on better-than-expected quarterly results.RELATED:Nvidia Surges 23% In Two Days On Earnings, GPU ConferenceWalt Disney (DIS) was forced to defend ESPN again as the premium sports cable network's subscriber losses accelerated slightly from the prior quarter; the timing of the call, not long after ESPN laid off about 100 mostly high-profile employees, put the channel back in the spotlight and CEO Bob Iger back in the hot seat. Results were mixed as revenue growth of 3% to $13.34 billion missed estimates and profit gains of 10% to $1.50 a share topped. 21st Century Fox (FOXA) turned in mixed results, topping on profit views, but cable ad revenue was weak. Ad revenue softness and subscriber declines have put media stocks under scrutiny lately.RELATED:21st Century Fox's Weak Cable Ad Revenue Follows Disney's ESPN WoesMacy's (M) led retailers after reporting weak quarterly results, as the department store operator is trying a variety of initiatives, hoping to find a solution to the long-time decline in brick-and-mortar retailer. Macy's sold off 17% on Thursday, then continued falling Friday, hitting its worst levels since 2011. Nordstrom (JWN) tumbled on disappointing same-store sales, while Kohl's (KSS) sold off mixed results. J.C. Penney (JCP) crashed to a record low Friday on its weak comps while Dillard's (DDS) also plunged. Many retailers are trying an array of things — from better e-commerce services to new beauty offerings to stores-within-stores — to prop up sales as more people buy things online or at discounters.RELATED:J.C. Penney Threatens All-Time Low On Weak Sales As Retail Woes ContinueMacy's Doesn't Know How To Fix Its Stores, Hopes Something Will WorkOPEC production fell in April thanks to decline in output from Libya, Iraq and Iran. But Saudi Arabia's production increased by nearly 50,000 barrels per day, according to OPEC's report. The increases come as OPEC and its allies debate extending the current production deal. On Tuesday, the International Energy Agency said an extension would reduce supply even further in the second half of the year. But U.S. shale is curbing the effectiveness of the cuts. On Wednesday, the Energy Information Administration said U.S. stockpiles fell by 5.2 million barrels last week, a larger-than-expected drop. On Tuesday, the EIA raised its full-year U.S. oil production forecast for 2018 to 9.96 million barrels per day. U.S. crude futures rallied after tumbling 6.3% in the prior week.EOG Resources (EOG) said it could hit its targeted 18% production increase and operate with in cash flow if oil averages $47 per barrel. It plans to operate three more rigs than previously expected, but keep capital spending at $3.7 billion to $4.1 billion. EOG, sometimes called the "Apple (AAPL) of oil," touted its Big Data and proprietary mobile apps in helping cut costs while new wells in the Permian basin "shattered" industry records for early production. Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) raised its 2017 production outlook and Sanchez Energy (SN) said current Q2 production levels are already 46% higher than Q1 levels. Oasis Petroleum (OAS) said Q1 production soared 25.6%.Coherent (COHR) earned $2.91 a share, up 180%, in its fiscal Q2. Revenue rose 112% to $422.8 million. Shares skyrocketed to a new high. Coherent makes laser parts used in making OLED displays for TVs and increasingly smartphones. CEO John Ambroseo sees "unprecedented demand" across many of the company's verticals.E-commerce giant JD.com (JD), one of China's top performing internet companies, reported first-quarter results that topped estimates and guided second-quarter revenue above views, a week before rival Alibaba (BABA) reports. China online auto site Bitauto (BITA) reported first-quarter earnings that fell short of views, but a competing online auto website, Autohome (ATHM), topped expectations. China social networking company YY (YY) also beat the consensus estimate.Marriott (MAR) reported first-quarter earnings that topped estimates and gave a rosier outlook for revPAR — or revenue per available room — a reflection of postelection optimism. Several hotel operators have delivered strong earnings and big stock gains. Travel-information websites Priceline (PCLN) and TripAdvisor (TRIP), however, reported results that missed views.The video game publisher earned 85 cents a share excluding items, up 69% year over year, far above views, as sales grew 18% to $1.09 billion. Electronic Arts (EA) was helped by continued strong sales of its World War I shooter game "Battlefield 1" and growth in pro soccer game "FIFA 17." An industrywide shift to higher-margin digital game downloads boosted profit. EA shares soared to record highs.Online home furnishings retailer Wayfair (W) reported first-quarter results that topped analyst estimates and sent shares to all-time highs, putting the squeeze on short sellers in the process. A large amount of Wayfair shares are sold short, equivalent to almost 17 days' worth of trading.Target (TGT) is pilot-testing a next-day home-delivery service for "essentials" such as detergent and coffee in the Minneapolis area. The Target Restock service will be available to REDcard users for an unspecified flat fee as the big-box retailer seeks to catch up with Amazon (AMZN) and Wal-Mart (WMT) moves in the delivery space. Amazon, for its part, cut its free-shipping minimum to $25 from $35, after trimming that from $49 earlier this year in reaction to Wal-Mart.M.D.C. Holdings (MDC) earned 43 cents a share, up 126% vs. a year earlier. Revenue swelled nearly 43% to $581.71 million vs. estimates of $509.9 million. LGI Homes (LGIH) earned 52 cents a share vs. 57 cents a year earlier. Revenue edged up 0.9% to $162.9 million. Shares of MDC rocketed 11% Tuesday to the highest in nearly four years. LGI Homes shot up 13.2%. Larger peers such as Lennar (LEN), D.R. Horton (DHI) and KB Home (KBH) also rallied after the sector had turned spotty in recent weeks.Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) agreed to buy Tribune Media (TRCO) for $3.9 billion, or $43.50 a share, creating a TV station powerhouse after the FCC lifted ownership caps. Sinclair Broadcast, which will also assume $2.7 billion in debt, fell 5.55% for the week. Tribune Media, which had been rallying on buyout buzz, rose 2.7%.Coach (COH) will buy struggling handbag rival Kate Spade (KATE), to boost its appeal with younger women. Coach will pay $2.4 billion, or $18.50 a share, less than some had speculated.Yelp (YELP) crashed 18.4% Wednesday after the local search-and-reviews site reported weak revenue and gave guidance that was far below analyst estimates.

X Maybe honesty isn't always the best policy? Walt Disney (DIS) Chief Executive Bob Iger slogged through an array of ESPN-related questions on late Tuesday's earnings call after the sports cable giant logged another quarter of subscriber declines. His bullish reaffirmations hearkened back to calls of earnings past, after he first disclosed in August 2015 that ESPN had sustained subscriber losses."Give us a little bit of credit for being very candid with you on an earnings call two summers ago," he told analysts, asserting that "we had our eyes wide open" about ESPN's issues, which allowed the company to deal with them head-on.Disney shares fell in late trade after ending Tuesday's regular session up 0.6% to 112.07 on the stock market today.Overall, Disney turned in a mixed quarter, falling short of second-quarter revenue forecasts late Tuesday with 3% growth to $13.34 billion. Profit of $1.50 per share marked a 10% year-over-year gain, ahead of estimates for 4% EPS growth.The entertainment heavyweight's media networks revenue, which includes both broadcast and cable TV, rose 3%, while operating income fell 3%. Programming costs also weighed on ESPN; cable networks' operating income fell 3%. The Disney Channels and Freeform, which appeal to children, teens and young adults, also lost subscribers during that period.Iger has his eyes on the future, as more people get their sports scores and highlights from mobile devices.While "there's nothing we can really do to slow that down," he said it's important for the network to participate in the new wave of technology. That's translated to development of ESPN's apps, its upcoming streaming platform powered by BAMTech and the network's presence on over-the-top "skinny" bundles, which Iger says benefit from the inclusion of ESPN."They've concluded that launching without ESPN is very challenged," he said on the call, adding, however, that despite "really nice growth," subscriber growth on streaming platforms has not made up for traditional cable-package subscriber losses.ESPN found itself in the headlines late last month when it laid off around 100 on-air personalities, another reminder of the troubles facing the traditional pay TV landscape."We're not sitting on our hands," said Iger.Disney's TV woes aside, Iger predictably lauded the studio's many box office successes, calling attention to "Rogue One" and "Beauty and the Beast," each of which have brought in at least $1 billion globally.Still, theatrical results were only "comparable" to the prior-year quarter due to the strength of "The Force Awakens" and "Zootopia" in 2016, according to the earnings release. Studio revenue dipped 1%, while operating income grew 21%.The theme parks segment logged the greatest revenue growth, up 9%. Operating income grew 20%, thanks to higher attendance and more spending on food and drink.Lastly, revenue at Disney's consumer products and interactive media unit dropped 11%, as strong "Frozen" and "Star Wars" sales last year provided tough comparisons. Operating income grew 3%.Up until last week, shares had been on a fairly steady upward march, making their way back up to 2015 highs. But Disney tumbled last week, falling below a buy point and its 50-day moving average.That was part of a broader media stock sell-off, spurred by sector jitters about ad revenue and subscriber losses following quarterly results from Viacom (VIAB), Time Warner (TWX) and others, plus the introduction of Hulu's live-TV beta service. (Disney is a joint owner of Hulu.)Broadly, investors appear to remain nervous about the power of cord-cutting and the state of the traditional pay TV system.During the session, Viacom fell 0.5%, while Time Warner sank 0.3%. 21st Century Fox (FOXA), which will report earnings on Wednesday, dipped 0.6%.Discovery Communications' (DISCA) results Tuesday revealed a "slight decline" in subscribers in its U.S. networks segment. Discovery shares retreated 2.2%.RELATED:Disney Earnings Preview: Movie Magic Vs. TV Static

Ahead of its earnings report, Walt Disney's (DIS) quarterly story remains something of a split personality, as its studio segment boasts more hits but its media networks unit — notably ESPN — encounters obstacles.Questions over its recent talent bloodletting at the sports cable network will now likely add to by-now-routine scrutiny over its subscriber figures when the media conglomerate reports after the close Tuesday.For Disney's fiscal second quarter, Street analysts are looking for profit and revenue growth of 4% to $1.41 a share and $13.45 billion, respectively.Late last month, ESPN laid off about 100 of its on-air talent, as network chief John Skipper said that the network navigates "changes in technology and fan behavior." Subscriber loss concerns continue to dog the network.A shift in viewership habits and the proliferation of online platforms have, over the years, hit media companies where it hurts: paid subscriptions and advertising revenue.Last week, HBO and Warner Bros. parent Time Warner (TWX) reported a decline in advertising revenue at its Turner network, while Viacom (VIAB) shares dove, despite a beat, amid concerns that its flagships channels were losing ground in distribution.Notably, "three of four biggest weekly sell-offs in media in the last decade have happened in the last three years, which shows the degree of uncertainty that has crept into the sector," wrote Barclays media analyst Kannan Venkateshwar.Additionally: Hulu, of which Disney is a joint owner, launched on Wednesday a live-TV beta service that promises around 50 channels for $39.99 a month, adding to the fray of over-the-top "skinny" bundle providers that includes Dish Network's (DISH) Sling TV and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation Vue.21st Century Fox (FOXA), Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal and Time Warner also have stakes in Hulu.Disney shares fell 0.5% to 111.42 on Monday, still below a 112.09 buy point after undercutting that level last week. Viacom slipped 1.1% after diving 13.5% last week. Fox dropped 2.5% Monday, on top of its 4.6% weekly loss.IBD's TAKE: It's not all doom and gloom for media companies in the subscriber wars. There's one — perhaps surprising — media company that is still adding accounts while others bleed subscriptions.Disney's media networks unit makes up the bulk of total revenue — over 42% in the December-ended quarter — which is why ESPN alone receives so much attention. And the strength of the legacy sports news brand may not carry as much weight in the future."In every evolution of OTT, the number of clicks needs to get to a program guide or a network viewing option is actually increasing," said Venkateshwar in his broad note on U.S. media. "Given the importance of consumer inertia in usage patterns, this is not a trivial shift."The interface of streaming platforms also means that coverage is divvied up by content and not by network, he added."Instead, the default interface is organized by sport and/or teams... . As a result, it is tough to see the brands of individual networks retaining any value in the coming years," wrote Venkateshwar.But Disney still has some tricks up its sleeve.ESPN and BAMTech are slated to launch a direct-to-consumer sports streaming service "probably" this calendar year, said CEO Bob Iger in the company's most recent earnings call, though it is designed to be a supplement — and not a replacement — to the main ESPN network. Disney has a one-third stake in streaming technology firm BAMTech.And massive hits for Disney's studio segment as well as optimistic projections for its movie pipeline, which is packed with "Star Wars," Marvel and Pixar films, have some analysts staying bullish."Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2" has so far earned over $427.6 million globally, debuting domestically this past weekend with a $145 million haul, according to Box Office Mojo. And Disney's March release of "Beauty and the Beast" remains the U.S. box office leader in 2017 with $487.6 million domestically, for a total of $1.19 billion worldwide."We continue to be buyers of Disney as we believe the robust film slate will continue to broaden the company's moat and drive significant value across key segments," wrote Piper Jaffray analyst Stan Meyers on Sunday. He has an overweight rating on the stock.RELATED:Viacom Tries To Calm Fears Its Channels Are Losing DistributionBig Media Stocks Unfazed Even As Hollywood Came To Brink Of StoppageIf You Think Netflix, Amazon Disrupted Hollywood, You'll Love Snap, FacebookESPN On-Air-Talent Layoffs Double What Was Expected

Futures for the S&P 500 index rose modestly early Monday morning, indicating possible record highs at the open, after France on Sunday elected centrist Emmanuel Macron as president, decisively defeating anti-immigrant, anti-euro populist Marine Le Pen.Last week the Dow industrials, S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite all enjoyed solid gains despite plunging oil prices and post-earnings declines from Facebook (FB) and Tesla (TSLA). The S&P 500 and Nadsaq set record closes on Friday, just one and two points, respectively, off all-time intraday highs. The Dow industrials are 0.3% below an record levels.Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 rose 0.1% above fair value. Nasdaq 100 futures edged up fractionally vs. fair value. Crude oil futures climbed 1.2%, trying to build on Friday's modest recovery from last week's five-month low, as Saudi Arabia said OPEC-led output cuts could continue into 2018.Meanwhile in Asia, Japan's Nikkei index surged 2.3% in intraday trade to a 2017 best, while South Korea's Kospi climbed 0.6% to an all-time high. Australia's S&P/ASX 200 advanced 0.5%. But China's Shanghai composite fell 0.9%.Alibaba's top e-commerce rival, JD.com (JD), reports before Monday's market open in New York, while top-rated Marriott International (MAR) releases results after the closing bell.In merger news, Sinclair Broadcasting was near a deal to buy Tribune Media (TRCO) for close to $4 billion, according to widespread reports Sunday, citing sources. The offer price is said to be around 44-45 a share. Tribune closed Friday at 40.29, but has rallied in recent weeks on buzz of a possible Sinclair takeover, as well as reports that 21st Century Fox (FOXA) might mount its own bid.The Chinese e-commerce giant JD.com has a Composite Rating of 92 out of 99, which means JD outperforms 92% of all stocks based on a variety of fundamental and technical factors.The consensus is for a 36% jump in revenue, with a profitable quarter vs. a year-ago loss.Adjusted EPS of 1 cent (0.10 yuan) on revenue of of $10.6 billion (74.546 billion yuan).Alibaba rival JD.com (JD) is extended, 10% above an entry at 32.57, trading in a tight range just above the 35 level.Alibaba and its ultimate rival Tencent (TCEHY) report earnings later this month. Tencent, which runs super-app WhatsApp, has a strategic stake in and alliance with JD.com.RELATED:Why These Top China Growth Stocks With Earnings Due Should Be On Your ListMarriott International has a best-possible 99 Composite Rating stock.Marriott is expected to report EPS of 91 cents, up nearly 5% vs. a year earlier. Revenue should advance 40% to $5.286 billion.Marriott stock is trading near all-time highs, with no proper buy point on the horizon.Marriott follows several other highly rated hotel stocks that have rallied on strong results, including Hilton Hotels (HLT) and Wyndam (WYN). IBD's Leisure Lodging group has steady risen to No. 14 out of the 197 industries that IBD tracks.Coming up on Wednesday, online travel booking giant Priceline (PCLN) reports earnings. Priceline is also a 99 Composite Rating stock. Hotels rely on Priceline and Expedia (EXPE) for travel bookings, but recent their market power and their commissions.RELATED:Which Companies Are Now Outperforming 95% Of All Stocks?Which Stocks Make This List Of The Fastest Growing Companies?Snap's First Time, Nvidia, Disney, Chinese Leaders: Investing Action Plan

Will Apple (AAPL) TV and CBS (CBS) be part of AT&T's (T) launch event for its DirecTV Now online video service on Monday?While CBS appears to be a holdout among AT&T's content partners, there's speculation the telecom giant could include Apple TVs and Amazon.com Fire TV sticks in its initial promotions. AT&T could not be reached for comment.It's not clear if AT&T would offer free Apple TV hardware with full functionality that would enable users to get programming from other sources, says Joel Espelien, an analyst at the Diffusion Group."To Apple, this is just another app running on their box, it does not really help their TV ecosystem," Espelien said. "It's not at all clear to me that AT&T will support the Apple 'TV app' search functionality."IBD'S TAKE: AT&T stock, along with Verizon Communications, were top performers in the first half of 2016 owing to their dividends. Apple, IBM and Cisco Systems are other companies that are increasing shareholder returns. Learn more at IBD's Income Investor. Fire TV sticks start at $40 while Apple TV costs around $150.AT&T has teased a $35 price point for the DirecTV service. It's not clear, however, if that's a discounted price for customers that buy both the online video service and wireless services.While 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA), Walt Disney (DIS) and NBC Universal have joined AT&T's programming line-up, there are other unknowns that will determine how big a threat DirecTV Now could be to cable firms Comcast (CMCSA) and Charter Communications (CHTR), said Bryan Kraft, a Deutsche Bank analyst, in a research report."We don't yet know if the $35 tier is an entry-level 100-plus channel tier with lots of filler channels, or if it is the flagship tier with 100-plus real channels," said Kraft. "If it is the former, then it's probably not that big a deal. However, if it is the latter, then it would appear that AT&T is using the service to show regulators its pro-consumer side, which is not good for cable."That said, we think this is a manageable headwind."If AT&T's DirecTV Now is a big success, it could pressure Comcast and Charter to acquire a wireless firm such as T-Mobile U.S. (TMUS), some analysts have speculated.CBS, which offers its own stand-alone streaming service, has not announced a deal with AT&T.Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL), though, in October signed CBS as a partner for its "Unplugged"-branded service. On the other hand, CBS also might not provide programming to Hulu's new live broadcasting service in 2017, some analysts say.Hulu is a joint venture of Walt Disney, Fox, Comcast and Time Warner (TWX). AT&T is seeking regulatory approval to acquire Time Warner for $85 billion.AT&T has stated DirecTV Now will have lower profit margins than its traditional, U-verse pay-TV services. Like other providers of so-called OTT (over-the-top) services, AT&T will not bear distribution costs, including network transport or set-top boxes.AT&T stock closed up 1.2% at 39.21 on the stock market today, as the half-day session ended at 1 p.m. ET.RELATED:AT&T Swallows Razor-Thin Margins On $35 Video Streaming DealHulu Live Service Gets Fox And Disney, Waiting On CBS, NBCUJohn Malone Talks Up Apple Buy Of Disney, Likes AT&T Strategy

When Walt Disney (DIS) reports fourth-quarter and year-end earnings late Thursday, it wouldn't be a stretch to expect more of the same: horn-tooting about the studio's hits, some nice words about the new theme park in Shanghai, and a vigorous defense of ESPN's health.Earnings are expected to dip 3% to $1.16 a share on flattish revenue growth to $13.52 billion.But expect ESPN to be in focus in the wake of Disney's data fight with Nielsen last week, in which the ratings company estimated that the sports network lost 621,000 subscribers in just one month. ESPN disputed the figures, but after pulling and double-checking its data, Nielsen reaffirmed Friday that its "estimates were accurate as originally released."ESPN reportedly called the figures a "historic anomaly."Either way, that will likely bring ESPN back to the forefront of Thursday's conference call, more than a year after CEO Bob Iger's comments about a modest subscriber decline at the cable network spurred a nervous breakdown across the media sector.Disney shares have yet to retake their all-time high of 122.08, reached on Aug. 4, 2015, the day Iger made those remarks during an earnings call.Separately, Stifel analyst Benjamin Mogil estimates that ESPN  is "at least 3 to 4 (million) subscribers lower than expectations heading into the new NBA contract from the time they signed it" two years ago.Shares of Disney closed up 2.1% to 94.43 on the stock market today amid a broad market rally. Peer Time Warner (TWX) — which recently agreed to be acquired by AT&T (T) — rose 1.5% to finish at 87.74, and 21st Century Fox (FOXA), which reported an increase in cable subscribers last week, added 1.7% to 27.39.IBD'S TAKE: Netflix, bandied about as a potential — but unlikely — acquiree of Disney, has been plunking down a pretty penny for original content. Here's how that is impacting its perception on Wall Street: "Netflix: Still A Hot Tech Play Or A Media Stock That Acts Like Tech?"While the media-networks segment has traditionally been Disney's biggest moneymaker, the studio arm continues to blaze a hot trail, led by a string of Marvel successes and a seemingly never-ending pipeline of "Star Wars" films.Marvel's "Doctor Strange" brought in $84.9 million at the domestic box office on opening weekend, according to Box Office Mojo, with a global gross of over $325 million so far. That, along with "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story," should make for a solid start to Disney's new fiscal year, although some analysts see a tough comparison to "The Force Awakens"' epic box-office haul last year.In focus for Thursday's Q4 report, however, should be "Finding Dory," the Pixar sequel to "Finding Nemo." Piper Jaffray analyst Stan Meyers expects the movie to help drive studio revenue up 10% for the quarter.In contrast to the analysts concerned about ESPN, Cowen's Doug Creutz offers up a different worry: that the House of Mouse is "earning an unsustainable portion of film industry profits (over 60% of the total in the first half of 2016), at a time when industry profits are under pressure."RELATED:Election, Nvidia, Disney, Acacia Dominate Investing Action PlanTime Warner Shrugs Off Low AT&T Breakup Fee, Merger NaysayersMedia Chatter: Tronc Dumped, N.Y. Times Goes 360, Discovery StreamsHulu Live Service Gets Fox And Disney, Waiting On CBS, NBCU

Efforts by Amazon (AMZN) to significantly expand its global video streaming service will put it near the same level as Netflix (NFLX) in how much they spend on content and distribution.Amazon on Thursday disclosed on a webpage it will expand its video streaming service to 200 countries, up from five currently, ratcheting up their competition with Netflix. Amazon said it will launch "The Grand Tour," an Amazon original series, worldwide in December. Starting Friday, the series will launch in the U.S., U.K., Germany, Australia and Japan.Netflix airs in some 190 countries, with China the only major holdout.Amazon did not issue a press release announcing the global expansion, leaving that role to CEO Jeff Bezos in a tweet.Long wait is over… Clarkson, Hammond, May are back… #TheGrandTour premieres tonight in UK, US, DE, JP. And globally in Dec. pic.twitter.com/dfQjGGuDFW— Jeff Bezos (@JeffBezos) November 17, 2016Jefferies analyst Brian Fitzgerald in a research note estimated that the launch of a global video streaming service by Amazon would require an additional $1 billion to $2 billion in video content spending in 2017. That would bring Amazon's annual content expenditure in line with Netflix, at about $6 billion for 2017, Fitzgerald wrote. The $6 billion is up from an estimated $4.5 billion Amazon will spend this year, he estimates."Three weeks ago Amazon reported a mixed quarter with solid top line performance and soft margins; margin guidance disappointed too. Now we know where a major piece of incremental investment might be going to — digital content for Amazon Video," Fitzgerald wrote.Amazon missed the consensus estimate on earnings per share by a wide margin when it reported third quarter earnings Oct. 27, while its profit guidance for Q4 also fell short. The main reason for the earnings miss was larger-than-expected investments in video content, Amazon Web Services and an expansion of fulfillment centers."Considering the fact that in general Amazon makes announcements of strategic initiatives only after the bulk of the necessary assets are already in place, we believe that the company has more or less secured the global rights for a core streaming video offering," Fitzgerald wrote.Amazon's global rollout begins with "The Grand Tour" and is expected to expand rapidly into new markets.Netflix, in addition to the increased competition from Amazon is confronting a more aggressive Hulu, which plans to launch a live streaming TV service in 2017, in addition to its original and third-party content. Hulu is co-owned by Walt Disney (DIS), NBCUniversal parent Comcast (CMCSA), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Time Warner (TWX).Jefferies analyst John Janedis, in a research note on Netflix, said Amazon appears to be aggressively securing digital rights for content in India, much more so than Netflix. In India,  Amazon has been developing relationships with local talent and has started making investments in high quality content, je wrote. Janedis has an underperform rating on Amazon and price target of 80. Fitzgerald has a buy rating on Amazon and price target of 950.Amazon stock rose 0.50% to 760.16 in the stock market today. Netflix stock rose a small fraction to 115.21.IBD'S TAKE: Amazon fell past its 50-day moving average in big volume on Oct. 28, a sell signal, in reaction to a disappointing third-quarter earnings report. With a big jump over the past two years, Amazon shares took up residence on IBD Leaderboard, an exclusive list of the very top stocks near or at buy points. But the stock Leaders can change fast. Amazon fell 16% from Oct. 6, its all-time high, though Nov. 14, and it's off the board, at least for now. Investors should keep daily track of Leaderboard.Bezos has said he wants Amazon to be "an invention machine." And so it's full throttle in such fields as delivery services, computerized warehouses, online video and music services, tablets, personal digital assistants, and no doubt more arenas besides e-commerce and cloud services. Even physical stores are now part of the plan.RELATED:Amazon Spreads Its Tentacles Far Beyond 'World's Biggest Bookstore' Amazon Confronts Microsoft, Google, IBM In Cloud Computing WarsAmazon Pushing Deeper Into Grocery Business With New Store Plans

Block-hugging lines reportedly filled the streets of Chicagoland late into the night after the city's beloved Cubbies triumphed over the Cleveland Indians to emerge as World Series champs for the first time since 1908.Where? Not at Nike (NKE) or Under Armour (UA) or Macy's (M) stores but at Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS), which opened after the game Wednesday night to throngs of fans waiting to get their hands on official championship gear.The line to get into Dick's Sporting Goods in Lincoln Park. At least 200 people. #Cubs pic.twitter.com/fJmw5DvMSN— Danny Ecker (@DannyEcker) November 3, 2016The line last night at Dick's after the Cubs #WorldSeries win. It went back much farther then I showed.#FlyTheW pic.twitter.com/Fd9mtiGinB— Jake Counselbaum (@jakecbaum) November 3, 2016Dick's shares rose as high as 57.17 but closed down 0.2% to 56.31 on the stock market today.Aside from the sporting gear chain, NPD sports goods analyst Matt Powell tweeted that Lids parent Genesco (GCO) and licensed apparel company Fanatics also stood to benefit from the win.@IBD_elow Fanatics will certainly benefit. Not many players left in licensed products— Matt Powell (@NPDMattPowell) November 3, 2016Susquehanna raised its estimates and price targets on Genesco following the game."We are confident that 103 (8%) of the 1,279 Lids stores will have had, and will continue to have, a material positive (same-store sales) inflection as a result of the Cubs' championship run and championship," wrote Susquehanna analyst Sam Poser, adding that the "Cubs victory is a gift that should keep on giving through the holidays" for the hat store.Genesco shares rose 0.5% Thursday.Another big winner from the night? 21st Century Fox (FOXA), which aired the game 7 that notably went into a 10th inning after being held up by a dramatically timed 17-minute rain delay.The broadcast's rating is the best in 15 years, said New York Times TV sports columnist Richard Sandomir.Game 7 overnight rating of 25.2 is highest since Game 7 in 2001.— Richard Sandomir (@RichSandomir) November 3, 2016Fox shares jumped 7.3% following a solid earnings report late Wednesday that showed an increase in cable subscribers, bucking an industry trend.

Amazon (AMZN) said Thursday that it will expand its video streaming to more than 200 countries, ratcheting up the competition with Netflix (NFLX).Amazon, which currently streams only in a few markets, announced on its website that it would launch "The Grand Tour" worldwide in December."The Grand Tour launches in the UK, US, Germany, Austria and Japan this Friday, 18 November. In December, the show will premiere in 200 countries and territories around the world, exclusively on Amazon."CEO Jeff Bezos also tweeted about the global launch.Long wait is over… Clarkson, Hammond, May are back… #TheGrandTour premieres tonight in UK, US, DE, JP. And globally in Dec. pic.twitter.com/dfQjGGuDFW— Jeff Bezos (@JeffBezos) November 17, 2016Netflix airs in some 190 countries, with China the only major holdout.The global reach comes with complications. Amazon may only have the rights to air third-party content in specific markets, and would have to extra to expand. That provides yet another incentive for Amazon and rivals to develop in-house programming. Also, outside of rich nations, users may lack the high-speed broadband or the income to get streaming TV.Still, the move shows that Netflix continues to lose its special status. Once the only major streaming service provider, it faces growing competition at home from Amazon and Hulu, which plans to launch a live streaming TV service in 2017, in addition to its original and third-party content.Hulu is co-owned by Walt Disney (DIS), NBCUniversal parent Comcast (CMCSA), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Time Warner (TWX). Time Warner owns HBO, and has agreed to a takeover by AT&T (T), which recently acquired DirecTV.And those media and entertainment giants are moving aggressively to a digital world.Netflix, which was up slightly, closed down 0.1% on the stock market today after the Amazon news spread. Amazon rose 1.3%, as its continues to rally after finding support near its 200-day line on Monday.RELATED:Netflix: Still A Hot Tech Play Or A Media Stock That Acts Like Tech?Time To Bite Into Apple, FANG Stocks: Piper Jaffray

New York Observer owner — and Donald Trump's son-in-law — Jared Kushner has had a "brief," informal chat with deal maker and LionTree chief exec Aryeh Bourkoff about a postelection Trump-brand media network, according to the Financial Times, citing sources familiar with the matter.Kushner reportedly reached out to the head of the boutique investment bank, a personal friend, over the last few months. Bourkoff is the financial advisor behind Walt Disney's (DIS) 2014 acquisition of Maker Studios, as well as a number of other deals.Trump had told the Washington Post in mid-September that he had "no interest in a media company," calling it a "false rumor," amid chatter that he, possibly with ex-Fox News chairman Roger Ailes, was mulling the creation of a network. He then told the Post that he remained focused on "win(ning) the presidency."But the most recent polls have shown Hillary Clinton to have anywhere from a 4-point to 11-point lead in the wake of the sexual assault allegations against Trump, an issue that has prompted numerous GOP lawmakers to withdraw their support for the Republican presidential nominee.It is unclear exactly when Kushner's conversation with Bourkoff took place.A theoretical Trump network could potentially siphon away viewers of Fox News, owned by 21st Century Fox (FOXA). Fox News also has a sister channel, Fox Business Channel.While the Financial Times points out that squeezing another channel into a cable package would be difficult, Recode imagines it as an over-the-top service, calling a Trump channel "one that could rival or even supplant Fox News."For better or for worse, the Trump campaign has easily dominated the daily and weekly news cycle, without the help of the right-leaning cable news network.Fox News' recent problems have not been a secret: Ailes was ousted in July following sexual harassment accusations from women at the network.Perhaps more pressingly, Megyn Kelly — Fox News' star — is reportedly waffling on whether she will choose to renew her network contract, which expires in July 2017. Then there's the well-publicized talk of rivalries between Kelly and Sean Hannity, as well as between her and Bill O'Reilly.Trump, meanwhile, has been steadily welcoming high-profile populist conservative media into the fold throughout the summer. In August, he hired Breitbart News Chairman Stephen Bannon as his campaign chief and brought Ailes on board as an advisor.Fox shares closed 0.2% lower at 24.68 in the stock market today. Disney shares dipped 0.5%, settling at a 7-month closing low.

Facebook (FB) and Alibaba (BABA) reported strong earnings, but their stocks sold off. Drug stocks suffered several blows. The major averages fell on earnings, tumbling oil prices and new uncertainty surrounding the presidential election.The S&P 500 fell 1.9% this week, closing just above its 200-day line. The benchmark index has fallen for nine straight sessions, the longest such streak in 36 years. The Nasdaq fell 2.8% in its worst weekly loss in nine months. Facebook (FB) was one of many leading stocks to tumble on earnings reports or outlooks, with Apple (AAPL) and Alphabet (GOOGL) also undercutting buy points. Plunging oil prices sank energy stocks.Facebook cruised past third-quarter earnings estimates but shares fell sharply when the social networking giant said growth rates would slow. Facebook reported earnings per share minus items of $1.09, beating the consensus of 97 cents and up 91% year over year. Revenue rose 56% to $7.01 billion, beating the consensus of $6.92 billion. Facebook said that the pace of ads placed on its website would decelerate, as would revenue growth in Q4 and 2017. It also expects 2017 to be an aggressive year for capital spending. Facebook fell 8% for the week, crashing through its 50-day line and multiple buy points.RELATED:Facebook Dives On Forecast For 'Meaningfully' Slower Ad Revenue GrowthAlibaba (BABA) reported better-than-expected fiscal Q2 earnings and sales, fueled by growth in its core e-commerce business and its booming cloud computing services. Earnings rose 46% to 79 cents a share as revenue rose 55% to $5.1 billion. Revenue from Alibaba's core e-commerce market rose 41% to $4.27 billion. Alibaba cloud computing revenue soared 130% to $224 million. Alibaba ended the quarter with 450 million mobile monthly active users, up 30% year over year. Alibaba is preparing for its Nov. 11 Singles Day, the world's biggest day for online shopping.But Alibaba shares fell 4.3% this week.U.S. crude futures tumbled 9.5% to $44.07 a barrel, their worst weekly decline since January, after losing 4.2% in the prior week. U.S. crude stockpiles jumped by 14.4 million barrels in the week ended Oct. 28, the largest-ever increase based on data doing back to 1982, the Energy Information Administration said. Meanwhile, OPEC and major oil producers couldn't agree on production curbs, raising doubts that they'll reach a deal.Shale bellwether Continental Resources (CLR) reported Q3 results short of Wall Street views but it plans to increase completions this year. Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) reported a surprise rise in Q3 profit and Apache (APA) posted a loss that wasn't as bad as analysts feared. BP (BP) lowered its capital expenditure outlook for 2016 and was cautious on 2017, while Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) downgraded its spending outlook for next year.General Electric (GE) and Baker Hughes (BHI) said that they will combine their oil and gas operations. Analysts expect this deal will pass regulators.The U.S. added 161,000 jobs last month, slightly less than expected, though August-September payrolls were revised up by 44,000. Average hourly wages rose 2.8% vs. a year earlier, the best gain since 2009. Meanwhile, the October ISM manufacturing index rose slightly, signaling modestly faster factory growth. But ISM's service sector gauge fell more than expected, indicating a slower rate of expansion.The Federal Reserve held rates steady, as expected, but said that the case for a rate hike "has continued to strengthen." Odds of a rate hike in December are high, but they have come down a bit as Donald Trump's poll numbers rebounded and financial markets stumbled.Video game publishers Electronic Arts (EA) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) got a lift from September quarter earnings reports while Activision Blizzard (ATVI)  sank.Activision beat estimates for Q3 sales and earnings, but its guidance for the holiday quarter was lighter than expected. For the December quarter, Activision forecast non-GAAP earnings per share of 74 cents on sales of $2.38 billion. Wall Street was modeling 80 cents and $2.48 billion.Activision on Friday released what many analysts expect to be the top-selling game of the year in "Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare," the latest in the company's lucrative "Call of Duty" franchise.Meanwhile, EA and Take-Two both topped expectations for the September quarter and raised their guidance.Mergers and acquisitions have overshadowed earnings reports from several major chipmakers.Mobile chip maker Qualcomm (QCOM), which plans to buy NXP SemiconductorsNXPI, on Wednesday said fiscal Q4 earnings per share excluding items rose 41% to $1.28 while sales rose 13% to $6.17 billion. Analysts expected EPS of $1.13 on sales of $5.84 billion.On Thursday, shares of chipmaker Microsemi (MSCC) soared on a report that fellow mixed-signal-chip expert Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) has approached it about a potential acquisition. Skyworks late Thursday delivered lower Q4 earnings and sales, but topped views.Separately, chipmaker Broadcom (AVGO) agreed to buy Brocade Communications Systems (BRCD) for $5.5 billion cash, plus $400 million of net debt. Broadcom plans to retain Brocade's fibre channel storage area network (SAN) switching business.CenturyLink (CTL) agreed to buy Level 3 Communications (LVLT) for about $34 billion in cash and stock. The combined company will be a stronger rival to AT&T (T) and Verizon (VZ) in the market for business services.  Broomfield, Colo.-based Level 3 operates one of the world's largest internet backbones. CenturyLink is the nation's third largest local phone company, behind Verizon and AT&T. CenturyLink plunged 24% for the week after rising 7.7% in the prior week on deal buzz. Level 3 initially rallied, but reversed down nearly 5% for the week after soaring 14.7% in the prior week.RELATED:CenturyLink Will Buy Level 3 For $34 Billion In Cash, StockOptical component makers Oclaro (OCLR), Inphi (IPHI) and Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI) reported earnings that topped expectations. Oclaro EPS rose 55%. Iphi reported EPS jumped 115% and said it will acquire ClariPhy Communications for $275 million in cash. Applied Optoelectronics' EPS fell 5%. However, NeoPhotonics (NPTN) missed on both the top and bottom lines.The Telecom-Fiber Optics group has been volatile, amid mixed guidance from Lumentum Holdings (LITE) and disappointing revenue from Infinera (INFN) in the prior week. Once white-hot IPO Acacia Communications (ACIA) reports Nov. 10.Oclaro and Inphi rose nearly 9% for the week and Applied Opto 10%. But NeoPhotonics crashed 19%.RELATED:Applied Optoelectronics Earnings Beat, NeoPhotonics MissesGeneral Motors (GM), Fiat Chrysler (FCAU), Ford Motor (F), Toyota (TM) and other major automakers reported lower U.S. sales in October vs. very tough comparisons from a year earlier. Industrywide sales fell 5.8% vs. a year earlier but it was the best in 2016 and above estimates. Ford released its figures a day after its rivals due to a Monday fire that knocked out power for its data systems at its Dearborn, Mich., headquarters.Teva Pharmaceuticals (TEVA), Mylan (MYL), Lannett (LCI) tumbled Thursday on reports that the Justice Department has been probing more than 12 generic drugmakers for possible price collusion, with charges likely by year-end. The report also appeared to hit drug distributors and pharmacy benefit managers. Meanwhile, Pfizer (PFE) missed Q3 earnings estimates, cut its full-year EPS target and ended work on a cholesterol drug. Allergan missed EPS and revenue targets.RELATED:Generic-Drug Makers Crash On Report DOJ Plans Collusion ChargesPfizer Ends Cholesterol Drug Development, Lowers EPS GuidancePapa John's (PZZA) topped third-quarter forecasts, following strong earnings from Domino's Pizza (DPZ) amid the pizza chains' attempts to draw more consumers through digital ordering platforms. Similarly, Starbucks (SBUX) said mobile payment has driven more transaction volume. The coffee chain beat fiscal-fourth-quarter estimates but issued 2017 profit guidance that missed views. Papa John's rose nearly 5% for the week, closing Friday right at its 50-day line. Starbucks rose 2% Friday after hitting a 14-month low on Thursday.Match Group (MTCH), which operates dating sites Match.com and Tinder, topped Q3 EPS estimates but missed on revenue. Match shares fell nearly 16% for the week.Cloud-based human payroll- and human-capital software firm Paycom (PAYC) topped Q3 views but guided light. Rival Paylocity (PCTY) topped fiscal Q1 results. But both stocks fell 17% for the week.Hulu struck content deals with 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Walt Disney (DIS) -- both Hulu part owners -- for its live online TV streaming service. Gannett (GCI) dropped its bid for Tronc (TRNC). Time Warner (TWX) and Fox both topped views. Meanwhile, the Wall Street Journal is shrinking its staff and consolidating print coverage as of Nov. 14, and Thomson Reuters (TRI) is cutting around 2,000 positions.

Netflix (NFLX) countersued 21st Century Fox (FOXA) in an employment dispute on Wednesday, accusing the media giant of imposing a "involuntary servitude" on its workers.Fox on Sept. 16 had sued streaming giant Netflix after the streaming giant hired away two key executives. Fox claimed Netflix willfully disregarded contractual agreements with its employees.Netflix is aggressively expanding into creating its own content and grabbing key talent from media entertainment companies. Media giants such Fox, Walt Disney (DIS), Time Warner (TWX) and Comcast (CMCSA) are struggling to adapt to streaming media. That includes uneasy cooperation and conflict with Netflix and Amazon (AMZN) Prime Video. Hulu is owned by Disney, Time Warner, Comcast and Fox.At the time, Netflix said it would fight back hard. On Wednesday, Netflix said it would look to hire more Fox employees and urged courts to declare Fox employment contracts unenforceable.IBD'S TAKE: Netflix has soared following its late Monday earnings report. But two other FANG stocks have also retaken buy points.Netflix noted in its California Superior Court filing that the state prizes employee mobility and enshrines it in public policy, statute, and case law."It added that Fox is bullying its workers with "take it or leave it" deals that unlawfully restrict employees and rivals."Through its widespread use of unlawful restrictive fixed-term employment agreements, Fox is facilitating and enforcing a system that restrains employee mobility, depresses compensation levels, and creates unlawful barriers to entry for Netflix and others competing in the film and television production business," Netflix said.Netflix shares rose 2.6% to 121.87 on the stock market today after surging 19% Tuesday following its strong Q3 earnings and subscriber gains announced late Monday.21st Century Fox shares rose 16 cents to 25.12, after retaking its 50-day line for the first time in four months on Monday.RELATED:5 Takeaways From Netflix Earnings Surprise, Stock SurgeNetflix Sued For Nicking Fox Execs But Claims 'Employee Mobility'

The NFL's crummy ratings have been blamed on a medley of factors — this over-the-top election season, anthem protests, "unendurable" officiating, a possible end to the Chicago Cubs' 108-year World Series drought — but the NBA doesn't appear to have the same troubles.Its season opener attracted 10% more viewers on TNT than last season's, according to CNN.And Time Warner execs on Wednesday morning pointed to a shift in basketball viewership toward digital platforms, which the media giant is trying to capitalize on as part of Turner's contract with the league."We have more digital rights — we're working really collaboratively with the NBA to try to dramatically accelerate the digital part of the business and digital profits as we continue to see more and more consumption happening on NBA digital," said Turner CEO John Martin on Time Warner's earnings call with analysts.Turner's TV umbrella includes CNN, TBS, TNT and Turner Sports, among others. The NBA extended its deals with ESPN (owned by Disney (DIS)) and TNT, giving Turner Sports a dozen extra games in the regular season.Martin said Turner is launching a Monday night NBA franchise as a result of the extra games."In the current environment, we're very pleased with how the season has started, with what ratings look like, and inventory has been extremely tight and there's been huge demand for our NBA properties, so I feel really good about advertising going into next year," he said.IBD'S TAKE: AT&T is acquiring Time Warner to the tune of $85.4 billion. Despite investor doubts about the regulatory hurdles it will have to face, Time Warner execs expressed confidence Wednesday that the deal is going to get done.Meanwhile, the NFL is making a good-faith effort to reach more eyeballs, namely through its partnership with Twitter (TWTR) to stream Thursday night games on the social network.Shares of Time Warner fell 1.1% to 87.28 in the stock market today. Disney, whose ESPN network also airs NFL games, slipped 0.5% to 91.91. Among other NFL broadcasters, CBS (CBS) dipped 1.2%, NBCUniversal owner Comcast (CMCSA) gained 2 cents to 61.47, and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) lost 1.4%.21st Century Fox reported better-than-expected earnings late Tuesday. Shares were little changed after hours.RELATED:Time Warner Shrugs Off Low AT&T Breakup Fee, Merger NaysayersTwitter Scores With NFL Live Streaming Debut; Stock Rises

The Obama administration's Department of Justice filed an antitrust lawsuit Wednesday against AT&T (T), charging that its DirecTV business engaged in unlawful information-sharing with other pay TV operators amid former Time Warner Cable's efforts to seek carriage fees for a Los Angles-area sports network carrying Dodgers baseball games.The DOJ filing comes 10 days after AT&T announced its proposed $85.4 billion acquisition of media giant Time Warner (TWX), which analysts say faces regulatory hurdles. AT&T acquired satellite broadcaster DirecTV in 2015."We respect the DOJ's important role in protecting consumers, but in this case, which occurred before AT&T's acquisition of DirecTV, we see the facts differently," said David McAtee, AT&T general counsel, in a statement.  "The reason why no other major TV provider chose to carry this content was that no one wanted to force all of their customers to pay the inflated prices that Time Warner Cable was demanding for a channel devoted solely to L.A. Dodgers baseball."We make our carriage decisions independently, legally and only after thorough negotiations with the content owner."Charter Communications (CHTR) acquired Time Warner Cable in 2015. TWC spent over $7 billion in 2013 to acquire rights to Dodger games, beating out Rupert Murdoch's 21st Century Fox (FOXA).IBD'S TAKE: AT&T stock has shed 16% since Oct. 1 amid speculation over rising interest rates and reaction to the Time Warner takeover bid. Look for news about other dividend paying stocks at The Income Investor.In 2011, Time Warner Cable had doled out an estimated $3 billion for rights to L.A. Lakers basketball games.Time Warner launched a L.A. sports network in 2014. Many pay TV providers claimed carriage fees sought by Time Warner Cable were too high, and did not carry the Dodgers channel.The Justice Department lawsuit alleges that DirecTV was the "ringleader" of an effort involving then rival AT&T as well as Cox Communications and Charter to undermine negotiations with Time Warner Cable.Federal regulators blocked Comcast's (CMCSA) proposed acquisition of Time Warner Cable in 2015.AT&T stock edged down a fraction in the stock market today to 36.37.RELATED:AT&T CEO On Time Warner Deal: Aiming To Set Pace In Innovation

The deal is going to get done. At least, that's the sentiment over at Time Warner (TWX), which, unlike many on Wall Street and elsewhere, doesn't believe its acquisition by AT&T (T) is going to succumb to regulatory troubles.In response to an analyst who pointed out that AT&T's share of the breakup fee -- $500 million — seems low, CEO Jeff Bewkes dismissed the concern."We want to get this done," he said Wednesday morning, after the HBO and Warner Bros. Studios parents reported better-than-expected third-quarter results and bumped up its full-year guidance."We think the combined company (is going to have) competition-spurring advantages and more choice," said Bewkes in a call with analysts. Both companies have made "significant commitments" to pass regulatory muster and therefore "don't think it's very important what the size of the fee is."Time Warner's general counsel, Paul Cappuccio, called the merger "plainly pro-competitive," adding that there's still competition at both levels of the vertical deal.The $107.50-a-share cash-and-stock deal is worth $85.4 billion, bringing HBO, CNN and Warner Bros. Studios under the wing of the telecommunications heavyweight. It is expected to close by the end of 2017.Despite the size of the transaction, Time Warner didn't allude to any major changes happening anytime soon.For instance, Bewkes said he anticipates "no change" to its involvement with Hulu, in which it has a passive 10% investment. Hulu is jointly owned by Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal and Time Warner."We don't think the merger here changes anything," he said, adding that is generally true of all of its deals with other distribution packages.Time Warner also noted that the Tencent (TCEHY) video service that it is a part of is now the No. 2 subscription video on demand service in China.Q3 EPS jumped 46% to $1.83, easily topping forecasts for $1.37, as revenue grew 9% to $7.17 billion, above views for $6.98 billion.The company now sees full-year EPS of $5.45-$5.55, above consensus views for $5.43 and up from a prior outlook of $5.35-$5.45.Shares were down 1.1% to close at 87.28 on the stock market today, as market skepticism that the merger will be realized continues to keep the stock below AT&T's bid price.IBD'S TAKE: Is Netflix still a tech company or a media company? The answer to that question may affect any price tag for Netflix as the two sectors converge.Meanwhile, 21st Century Fox is slated to disclose results later in the day. Analysts see EPS up 16% to 44 cents on 7% revenue growth to $6.49 billion.M&A is on the brain across the board in media, and Stifel continues to expect that Fox will be less focused on near-term capital return in favor of M&A and organic investments such as Hulu."While a less targeted capital return policy has weighed on the stock, given earlier tight capital return targets, we believe there is increased interest on the part of the company for a buyout of the share they don't own of BSkyB both because of its accretion, but also the diversification away from US advertising," wrote Stifel analyst Benjamin Mogil on Oct. 13.RELATED:Hulu Live Service Gets Fox And Disney, Waiting On CBS, NBCUApple Encouraged To Bid For Time Warner As TV Strategy FaltersDisney-Netflix Deal? Now Is The Time To Take The Risk, Says BarclaysAT&T + Time Warner: It's Happening, But A President Trump Would Kill It

Stocks opened flat Monday, as earnings reports and commodities trade drove early action, despite Sunday's critical election in France.The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average barely moved.The victory of centrist presidential candidate Emmanuel Macron over nationalist Marine Le Pen in France received a mixed reception from world markets. Markets in Europe grew more widely mixed in afternoon action: London's FTSE 100 was up 0.1%, the CAC 40 in Paris dropped 1.1%, while Frankfurt's DAX fell 0.3%.Markets in Japan and South Korea — both heavy trading partners with the European Union — surged Monday, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 and the Korea Exchange's Kospi each closing with 2.3% gains.  In China, Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose 0.4%, while mainland markets dived: the Shanghai Composite dropped 0.8% and the Shenzhen Composite tumbled 2%.Among the Dow industrials, Walt Disney (DIS) fell 0.2% ahead of its fiscal second-quarter report after Tuesday's close. Merck (MRK) was up a fraction.Earnings reporting season continues with Priceline (PCLN), Snap (SNAP) and Disney among the leading names set to report during the week. On Monday, Tyson Foods (TSN) fll 4.5% while Sysco (SYY) fell 1%. Both companies narrowly missed analysts' quarterly earnings targets.Rubbermaid and Sharpie maker Newell Brands (NWL) sealed up an early 11% gain, after first-quarter earnings and revenue topped expectations, and management hoisted full-year earnings guidance to above consensus views and raised the quarterly dividend 21%. Newell rallied back above its 10- and 40-week moving averages as it works on a consolidation.China-based online retail giant JD.com (JD) surged 7% at the open. The company's first report according to GAAP rules showed it turning to a profit from a year-ago loss and posting a 41% increase in revenue. Both results were better than expected. The stock is well-extended from a February breakout and a March rebound from support at its 10-week moving average.Mallinckrodt (MNK) climbed 1% as its fiscal second-quarter revenue and earnings growth bested views. The stock is trying to form a bottom in a deep, two-year-old consolidation.Petmed Express (PETS) jumped 9% in early action as fiscal fourth-quarter earnings and revenue cleared expectations by wide margins, and management raised its quarterly dividend by a penny, to 20 cents a share. The thinly-traded stock ended Friday in a buy range, 1% above a 23.88 buy point in a five-month cup base.Straight Path Communications (STRP) bolted 27% higher at the open. The owner of 39 spectrum licenses announced a new bid at $184 per share from a unnamed bidder, raising the enterprise value to $3.1 billion between AT&T (T) and another telco, widely assumed to be Verizon (VZ). Straight Path shares ended Friday up 500% from a March low.Charter Communications (CHTR) dived 1.5% after announcing it had entered a joint agreement with Comcast (CMCSA) to better manage their competing wireless services. Comcast shares rose 0.4%.Tribune Media (TRCO) jumped 5% after Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) said it would buy the television and radio station owner in a deal valued at $3.9 billion, including $2.7 billion in debt.  Shares of Twenty First Century Fox (FOXA) fell 0.3% after the company was reported the have ended its attempt to bid against Sinclair to acquire Tribune. There was a trading halt on Sinclair shares.Ore mining stocks were under early pressure as copper and other commodities traded lower. Freeport McMoRan (FCX), BHP Billiton (BHP), Vale (VALE) and Rio Tinto (RIO) all slipped 2%.Tribune MediaTRCO jumped 5% after Sinclair Broadcast GroupSBGI said it would buy the television and radio station owner in a deal valued at $3.9 billion, including $2.7 billion in debt.  Shares of Twenty First Century FoxFOXA surged 6% after the company was reported the have ended its attempt to bid against Sinclair to acquire Tribune.Oil prices, which dropped 6% to a six-month low last week, backed off in early trade. West Texas Intermediate was down a fraction to hold just above $46 a barrel. Losses may have been stemmed by comments from Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Khalid Al-Falih, who Bloomberg reported as expecting the production cap agreement between Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and its partners would hold through the second half of 2017.There are no significant economic releases scheduled during Monday's session. The Federal Reserve will be in motion, with St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank President James Bullard speaking at 8:35 a.m. ET, and Loretta Mester, president of the Cleveland Federal Reserve Bank, scheduled for an 8:45 a.m. ET speech.Gold rose 0.5% to above $1,232 an ounce. Copper dropped almost 2%. The dollar was mixed, down vs. the yen and up against the euro. Bonds rose, trimming the 10-year yield 2 basis points to 2.33%.RELATED:Snap, Nvidia, Disney, Chinese Leaders: Investing Action PlanMacron Beats Le Pen, Takes French Presidency In Boost For Europe

Despite a major earnings topper, Viacom (VIAB) stock fell as much as 11% Thursday amid concerns that its flagship channels are losing ground in distribution.The MTV parent's chief executive said Viacom properties that appear on Charter Communications (CHTR) are now only on the cable giant's priciest cable-bundle tier, but Bob Bakish assured analysts that it was "not a broad re-tiering," according to Bloomberg.Viacom shares ended the trading day down 7.7% to 37.85 on the stock market today, recovering from a low of 35.20 but extending the stock's two-day dive, which was sparked Wednesday by Time Warner's (TWX) soft subscriber numbers and advertising revenue.The HBO parent, which is being bought by AT&T (T), dipped 0.8% to 98.30 Thursday. Disney (DIS) ticked down 0.6% to 111.17 after losing 2.4% Wednesday, undercutting its 50-day line and a buy point. CBS (CBS), which reports late today, rose 0.6% to 63.85 after dropping 3.35% yesterday, and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) added 0.6% to 29.04 after tumbling 5.1%.Viacom's flagship channels, which also include Comedy Central, Spike, VH1, BET and Nickelodeon, aren't found on too many skinny bundles either, as online players rush to build out over-the-top package services.Sony's (SNE) PlayStation Vue stopped carrying Viacom-owned channels last November, because it was "the best way for us to continue to offer the most compelling value to our fans." Hulu's newly announced live-TV bundle does not include Viacom's stations in its 50 or so available channels.Comedy Central is part of the core packages on Dish Network's (DISH) Sling TV, but MTV and Spike cost an extra $5 a month.For the quarter, Viacom's adjusted diluted earnings grew 4% to 79 cents a share, crushing views for 59 cents. Revenue growth of 8.5%, to $3.26 billion, exceeded estimates for $3.02 billion, on strength in Viacom's filmed-entertainment and media-networks segments.Media-networks revenue rose 1%, including a 2% decline in domestic revenue and a 11% bump in international revenue.Viacom' s filmed-entertainment segment, which includes Paramount Pictures, drew in $895 million, above estimates, as "xXx: Return of Xander Cage" helped the studio nearly double its theatrical revenue abroad.RELATED:Dow's Disney Is Breaching This Key Level Before Earnings Next Week: Warning Sign?Media Giants Dive On Ad Woes; Hulu Debuts Live-TV ServiceBig Media Stocks Unfazed Even As Hollywood Came To Brink Of Stoppage

21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Blackstone (BX) plan to make a joint offer for Tribune Media (TRCO), which is also likely to get a bid from Sinclair Broadcasting (SBGI), according to multiple reports.Private equity giant Blackstone would provide the cash while 21st Century Fox would chip in its local stations as part of the possible joint venture, according to the Financial Times and Bloomberg News.Sinclair Broadcasting has been mulling a bid in the $30s-per-share range, Bloomberg said. Tribune Media, which closed Monday at 36.58, has a market cap of $3.2 billion.A Sinclair-Tribune combination might have a stronger negotiating had vs. Fox. Tribune owns 42 local stations, including 14 Fox affiliates.The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday lifted a cap on how many stations that companies can own, making a Fox or Sinclair bid for Tribune possible.Tribune Media is in a flat base with a possible buy point of 40.10, but recently fell below its 50-day moving average. Tribune Media rose 8.8% to 39.72 soon after the opening bell on the stock market today.Sinclair is in a flat base with a 43.15 potential entry, and also has dipped below its 50-day line, ending last week at 39.45. Sinclair shares fell 0.8% to 39.15 Monday morning.21st Century Fox briefly broke out of a flat base in late March but pulled back. Shares edged down 0.1% to 30.50 Monday morning, below their 50-day line. The old 31.85 buy point is still valid.Blackstone is in a flat base with 31.79 buy point, closing Friday at 30.84. Blackstone edged up 0.2% intraday Monday.

XBetween "Beauty and the Beast," "Star Wars: Episode VIII — The Last Jedi," "Guardians of the Galaxy 2" and "Thor: Ragnarok," Dow Jones industrial average component Walt Disney (DIS) is looking to dominate at the box office among teenagers, according to the latest Piper Jaffray teen survey.The results of the semiannual poll show that at the time of the survey, Disney films accounted for four of the nine most-anticipated movies over the upcoming year."Beauty and the Beast," which was released on March 17, has so far brought in $432.3 million domestically and almost a billion dollars worldwide. It led the box office charts for its first two weeks in theaters, before getting toppled by Fox's "Boss Baby."Piper Jaffray analyst Stan Meyers said Disney is "well positioned" among teens over the next year, capturing 57% share of the list.Despite the number of hot movies on the list, Disney didn't make the No. 1 most eagerly awaited film in the coming year, though: that belongs to Universal Pictures' "The Fate of the Furious," the eighth movie in the "Fast and the Furious" franchise, which premieres on Friday. The movie captured nearly a quarter of the vote.Universal Pictures belongs to Comcast (CMCSA) subsidiary NBCUniversal.IBD'S TAKE: Disney has once again stretched out the contract of Chairman and CEO Bob Iger, this time to July 2, 2019, as the search for a new top Mouseketeer remains fruitless. Shares of Disney, one of the better-performing Dow industrials stocks in 2017, fell 0.1% to 112.43 in the stock market today. Walt Disney is still in range from a 112.09 buy point.Comcast slid 1% to 37.66, still close to a 38.54 buy point. 21st Century Fox (FOXA) rose 0.55%.Here's the full list of most anticipated movies in the next 12 months, according to Piper Jaffray's survey:Disney, which is not in IBD's Dividend Leaders screen, pays a semi-annual dividend of 78 cents a share. That represents a yield of 1.4% on an annualized basis. IBD calculates a dividend growth rate of 62%.RELATED:Dow's Nike Is No Longer The No. 1 Brand Worn By Teen Boys: SurveyDow Stocks Wal-Mart, Disney See Upbeat Analyst Moves; Arista DowngradedDisney Stock Back In Buy Zone As CEO Bob Iger To Stay On Longer

AT&T (T), Comcast (CMCSA) and Verizon Communications (VZ) have more incentive to launch or expand nationwide internet TV services in the wake of Congress's repeal of data privacy rules, says a Pacific Crest Securities analyst.Lawmakers voted March 30 to overturn Federal Communication Commission rules that would have required Internet service providers to get customers permission before collecting data on web-browsing and app usage. A Democratic-led FCC had approved tougher data privacy rules in mid-2016.Comcast, Charter Communications (CHTR), AT&T and Verizon are the biggest internet providers. Pacific Crest Securities says internet providers will be better-positioned for targeted advertising, much like internet companies."The ability to collect data could compel (internet providers), particularly AT&T and Verizon, to more aggressively push their (video streaming) efforts in the hope of capturing more consumer share, which would create more opportunities to sell targeted 30-second video ads," Andy Hargreaves, a Pacific Crest analyst, said in a note to clients.Verizon is readying a new video streaming service, Bloomberg reported last week. Comcast has reportedly acquired rights from cable network owners to offer their channels nationwide. AT&T launched its DirecTV Now online streaming service in late November."We view the repeal of the FCC's pending Internet Privacy Order as positive for wireless ISPs, modestly positive for cable companies and neutral for Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and Facebook (FB)," added Hargreaves. "The new policy will improve ISPs' ability to target, which should help them monetize content, but will still meaningfully lag the breadth and depth of profiling data captured by Google and Facebook's logged-in experiences."IBD'S TAKE: Comcast stock shot up after President Trump's surprise election in November on expectations of lighter broadband regulation. Comcast stock has been consolidating more recently and has a buy point of 38.54.  Learn more about Comcast's growing institutional ownership and earnings growth at IBD Stock Checkup.Pay-TV providers such as AT&T, which acquired satellite broadcaster DirecTV Group in 2015, and Dish Network (DISH) have had an easier time obtaining streaming rights than industry outsiders, such as Apple (AAPL).Google-parent Alphabet in March announced YouTube TV, a $35 monthly paid subscription service. It's expected to launch this spring.Hulu — a joint venture of Walt Disney (DIS), Fox-parent 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA) and Comcast's NBCUniversal — is set to launch yet another live TV streaming service.The Pacific Crest Securities analyst also says internet providers have more reason to acquire content. AT&T in October agreed to buy Time Warner (TWX) for $85 billion. That deal needs to be approved by the Trump administration."Most major ISPs already own significant content assets; however, this (data privacy rules) could compel them to purchase more content, particularly on the digital side, where the improved data is likely to have the most immediately useful value for targeting," wrote Hargreaves.RELATED:Google Advertising Plans Key In YouTube TV Launch Vs. AT&T, HuluWill AT&T, Comcast, Verizon Seek Fees From YouTube TV, Hulu?
