Comcast (CMCSA), Charter Communications (CHTR) and other cable TV firms are becoming broadband-first companies as they take away internet customers of AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ).The top cable companies added 3.3 million broadband subscribers in 2016 — similar to the gains in 2015, and the most net additions in any year since 2007, says Leichtman Research Group. Cable TV firms, meanwhile, lost 278,000 pay-TV video subscribers in 2016, although Comcast added 161,000.Comcast had 24.7 million broadband subscribers vs. 22.5 million video customers at the end of 2016. The broadband gap is wider at Charter, which acquired Time Warner Cable. Charter had 22.59 million broadband subscribers vs. 17.2 million video subscribers as of Dec. 31.The top cable TV firms followed by LRG had 58.4 million broadband subscribers vs. 48.6 million video subscribers at the end of 2016. Top telephone companies — including AT&T, Verizon and CenturyLink (CTL) — had 34.5 million broadband subscribers, down 599,000 from a year earlier. In 2015, phone companies lost 185,000 broadband subscribers, says LRG.With more internet video services rolling out in 2017 and next year, pay-TV industry subscribers could fall further, analysts say. As cord-cutting goes on and the traditional video business for cable providers shrinks, their No. 1 product will be broadband and internet access. So even if internet video takes off, they still have broadband dominance.IBD'S TAKE: Verizon and AT&T have been favorites of investors looking for high dividends, but there are other options, such as banks, industrials and real estate investment trusts (REITs). Check out IBD's Income Investor for high-dividend-paying stocksGoogle-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) has announced YouTube TV, a $35 monthly paid subscription service. Hulu — a joint venture of Walt Disney (DIS), Fox-parent 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA) and Comcast's NBCUniversal — is set to launch yet another live TV streaming service in the spring. And, Amazon.com (AMZN) could follow in 2018.They'll join AT&T's DirecTV Now and Dish Network's (DISH) Sling streaming services.While cable TV firms outside of Comcast shed 278,000 video customers in 2016, phone companies lost 1.5 million, says LRG. AT&T's U-verse service accounted for 1.36 million subscriber losses as AT&T shifted marketing toward its DirecTV satellite TV service. DirecTV added 1.2 million customers last year, but Dish Network lost just over 1 million, says LRG.Comcast stock fell 0.5% to 37.47 in the stock market today. Comcast stock has been consolidating and is near a buy point of 38.54. Shares in AT&T rose 0.4% to 42.61 while Verizon stock climbed 0.7% to 50.39.RELATED:Will AT&T, Comcast, Verizon Seek Fees From YouTube TV, Hulu?

AT&T (T) will sell a 100 channel-plus video-streaming service branded "DirecTV Now" starting at $35 monthly, its CEO Randall Stephenson said at a conference on Tuesday. Programming may not include much content from CBS (CBS) or 21st Century Fox (FOXA), based on earlier reports.AT&T's $35 price-tag is about $15 below estimates by Wall Street analysts.AT&T's pricing could impact the strategies of Hulu, which is expected to launch a live-streaming TV service in early 2017, as well as Amazon.com (AMZN). Hulu is a joint venture of Walt Disney (DIS), Fox and Comcast (CMCSA).AT&T has stated DirecTV Now will have lower profit margins than its traditional, U-verse pay-TV services. Like other providers of so-called OTT (over-the-top) services, AT&T will not bear distribution costs, including network transport or set-top boxes.At $35 a month, AT&T's package might not include sports channels such as Disney's ESPN.IBD's TAKE: AT&T stock has dropped nearly 7% since reports of the Time Warner deal surfaced and subsequently announced. Time Warner stock is trading at near 87, roughly 20 below AT&T's cash and stock offer of 107.50 per share. Analysts say TWX shareholders may be unsure of regulatory approval. Analysts do not expect another bidder such as Walt Disney or Apple to swoop in for TWX. Media stocks have cooled off since Friday. Learn more about CBS and other media stocks at IBD Stock Checkup.Stephenson, while announcing AT&T's proposed $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner (TWX) on Monday, disclosed that DirecTV Now would be launched in November. Time Warner owns a 10% stake in Hulu.AT&T acquired satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV Group in 2015."We estimate monthly programming costs for DirecTV Now in the low $30 range, similar to the price AT&T will charge, meaning the company will not make much on this service," UBS analyst John Hodulik said in a research report. "However, it will avoid costs for satellites, set-top boxes and installations/trouble-shooting, while also reaching customers who have left the pay TV market or never joined."Strong growth in this product would support AT&T's vision for the TWX transaction and likely sit well with regulators concerned about the OTT ecosystem."

Dish Network's (DISH)"Sling" service starts at $20 monthly but does not provide programming from the four major broadcast networks. Dish has experimented with different Sling packages, with and without ESPN and Disney in the basic offering. Extra Sling programming tiers cost an extra $10 a month.AT&T will limit the DirecTV Now offering to two simultaneous video streams. The offering doesn't include DVR functions, analysts say.AT&T is also expected to launch a mobile version of the DirecTV Now product as well as a free, ad-driven version with fewer channels.AT&T's success or not in bundling video and mobile services, analysts say, is a big factor in whether Comcast, Charter Communications (CHTR) and cable TV firms decide to acquire a wireless network.AT&T stock was down a fraction, near 36.75, in late-afternoon trading in the stock market today.RELATED:AT&T's DirecTV Now Pricing Will Be Key For Comcast, Hulu, AmazonAT&T CEO On Time Warner Deal: Aiming To Set Pace In InnovationHow Aggressive AT&T Has Out-Maneuvered Verizon, Comcast

AT&T (T) has reached a deal to acquire Time Warner (TWX) for $107.50 a share, with an equity value of $85.4 billion, the two companies announced Saturday evening. But the merger faces major regulatory and political hurdles.The equal parts cash-and-stock acquisition, worth $108.7 billion including assumed debt, brings the parent company of HBO, CNN and Warner Bro. Studios under the umbrella of the telecommunications giant."Premium content always wins. It has been true on the big screen, the TV screen and now it's proving true on the mobile screen," AT&T CEO and Chairman Randall Stephenson said in a statement. "We'll have the world's best premium content with the networks to deliver it to every screen."The big merger is not the first in recent memory for AT&T, which acquired satellite provider DirecTV last year for nearly $50 billion.Nor is it an unusual trend: Comcast (CMCSA) fully acquired NBCUniversal three years ago, and Verizon Communications (VZ) -Yahoo (YHOO) deal is currently in the works. Sumner Redstone's National Amusements is pushing CBS (CBS) and Viacom (VIAB) to reunite.Even Apple (AAPL) reportedly approached Time Warner about a merger several months ago, said the Wall Street Journal.IBD'S TAKE: As internet giants such Alphabet's Google add video content and launch services, AT&T and others are being pushed to gain more content.Time Warner turned down an $85-per-share offer from 21st Century Fox (FOXA) two years ago.But in a stump speech on Saturday, Donald Trump opposed the AT&T-Time Warner merger, saying that if he wins the White House, the deal will not be approved. "Deals like this destroy democracy," the Republican nominee said, who vowed to go after the media "power structure" that he claims is opposing his presidential run.Whoever is in the White House, antitrust regulators likely would take a long look at the deal, with approval not certain.A combined AT&T-Time Warner would have a market cap around $300 billion. That's roughly equal to Comcast ($154 billion) and Walt Disney (DIS) ($150 billion) together.Separately, AT&T announced third-quarter results, ahead of Tuesday's scheduled release. AT&T earned 74 cents a share excluding various items, flat vs. a year earlier and meeting analyst estimates. Revenue, including DirecTV, climbed 4.6% to $40.9 billion, slightly below views.AT&T added 212,000 monthly wireless customers, slightly better than some forecasts.DirecTV added 323,000 customers, while AT&T added a net 171,000 broadband subscribers.AT&T said it's on track to meet or beat full-year targets. It also raised its quarterly dividend by a penny to 49 cents a share.It'll hold a webcast on Monday morning to discuss the Time Warner deal and its Q3 earnings.Shares of Time Warner closed up 7.8% on Friday to 89.48. AT&T shares fell 3% to 37.49. After Friday's close, Time Warner rose to about 93 and AT&T fell slightly further on reports that a deal could come this weekend.RELATED:Trump Expands Lead Over Clinton To 2 Points – IBD/TIPP PollNetflix: Still A Hot Tech Play Or A Media Stock That Acts Like Tech?

What's behind AT&T's (T) apparent pursuit of media giant Time Warner (TWX)? AT&T craves rights to more content, as internet giants such as Google, Amazon.com (AMZN) and possibly Apple (AAPL) push into web TV and entertainment services, analysts say.Telecom conglomerate AT&T reportedly is nearing a cash-and-stock deal to acquire media giant Time Warner, with an announcement possible as soon as this weekend or Monday, the Wall Street Journal reported. Media and entertainment stocks jumped Friday on views that internet, telecom and media companies will scramble to acquire content.Time Warner's media empire includes HBO and Turner Broadcasting, which has rights to sports telecasts. It also owns Warner Bros. film studio and cable networks TNT, TBS and CNN. Time Warner owns a 10% stake in internet video provider Hulu, a joint venture of Comcast (CMCSA), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Walt Disney (DIS).AT&T stock fell 3% to 37.49 in the stock market today on the WSJ report, the lowest since the end of February. Time Warner stock jumped 7.8% to 89.48.But after the close, AT&T fell about 1% while Time Warner popped 4%. Bloomberg reported that AT&T is near a deal to buy Time Warner for $110 a share.During the regular session,  Discovery Communications (DISCA), controlled by media baron John Malone, popped 3.6%, while CBS stock rose 1.9% and Walt Disney 1.1%.Shares of 21st Century Fox, which bid for Time Warner in 2014, rose 2.2%, Viacom (VIA) 2.7%, Scripps Interactive (SNI) 5.6% and AMC Networks (AMCX) 3.9%.IBD'S TAKE: Media consolidation has been expected, with CBS and Viacom possibly recombining and John Malone positioned to roll up smaller companies, analysts say. IBD's Media-Diversified group ranks No. 58 out of 197 industry groups, but should move up on M&A speculation. CBS has been the top-ranked stock, and you can find out why at Stock Checkup. Structuring a deal might be challenging for AT&T. Time Warner had a market cap of over $70 billion, and AT&T had just over $7 billion in cash on its books as of June 30. AT&T has about $120 billion in debt, while Time Warner has $24 billion in debt.Any AT&T offer for Time Warner would be mostly stock, says Craig Moffett, an analyst at MoffettNathanson."AT&T is much more levered than what it appears," Moffett told IBD. "You have to wonder what Time Warner's appetite would be if a large component of the deal is AT&T equity."Moffett adds that chances of regulatory approval would only be 50-50.Bloomberg reported that AT&T is in a rush because of other possible bidders. Apple raised the idea of buying Time Warner at a meeting between the two companies in late 2015, but talks never advanced, the Financial Times said in May.Speculation over AT&T's interest in Time Warner follows reports that Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google has signed up CBS as its first broadcasting partner for a web TV service."We believe that hyperscale internet companies will be looking to sell a full suite of communications/cloud services to customers to achieve maximum economies of scale," Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan said in a research report. "As they directly connect content with end users, the carriers will respond. Time Warner should fit in fairly well with AT&T's wireless and (internet video) services."AT&T's launch of DirecTVNow, an internet video service, might be a factor, analysts say."The upcoming launch of the DirecTV OTT/mobile product certainly provides a reason for AT&T to want to acquire quality content assets," said Colby Synesael, a Cowen & Co. analyst, in a research report. "However, the price paid for any deal could be overkill and exclusivity is not necessary and in fact may not be a good use of Time Warner's valuable content."Federal regulators placed tough conditions on Comcast's 2011 acquisition of NBCUniversal from General Electric (GE). Most of those conditions sunset in 2018.Amy Yong, analyst at Macquarie Capital, says AT&T would face regulatory scrutiny."The big strategic question is what sort of operating synergies could the combined company achieve? We presume regulators would require AT&T to maintain arms-length transactions with Turner, HBO and Warner Bros. Industry logic would say AT&T would want or need other networks' content on its pay TV offerings," Yong said in a report.While Apple has shelved a web TV service amid stalled talks with media companies, many analysts believe cash-rich Apple could re-emerge as a player. There's been speculation over the years that Apple and Walt Disney could be a match.RELATED:AT&T, Time Warner Merger Talk Is Back, Merits QuestionedGoogle Nabs CBS As AT&T, Amazon, Hulu Seek OTT Partners

Netflix's (NFLX) whopping $6 billion content budget for 2017 may resemble a young tech company's strategy for growth before profit.But its Hollywood spending spree — like a reported $120 million budget for "The Get Down" and a $40 million price tag for two Chris Rock specials — has trained a glaring soundstage Klieg light on what could be Netflix's emerging identity crisis."This is just idiotic," Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter told Investor's Business Daily. "What's the replay-ability of Chris Rock? I mean, he's funny, but come on. I think Netflix's spending is out of control. I think they're doing really dumb things, like a four-picture deal with Adam Sandler."Netflix's stock is nearing its record high, but concerns over costs — and plans for 1,000 hours of original content next fiscal year — are prompting a new question: Should investors still view the company as a tech disrupter shaking up Big Media, or has its seduction by Hollywood left it unable to still act like a nimble tech startup?The distinction between being considered a tech vs. a media stock isn't just a philosophical one. As the media and tech sectors converge, it may affect any takeover price for Netflix, and there's been chatter it could become a target for Walt Disney (DIS). While the pairing has been seen as unlikely, reports that AT&T (T) and Time Warner (TWX) are near a megamerger lifted shares of Netflix (3.3%), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) (2.2%), CBS (CBS) (2.1%) and Viacom (VIAB) (2.7%) as well as Time Warner's (7.8%) on the stock market today.Categorizing Netflix as a media stock vs. a tech stock would also prompt Wall Street to view its financials with a different lens.Tech hotshots can shell out big bucks, and investors hardly blink. Facebook's (FB) $2 billion acquisition of Oculus in 2014 knocked down shares for a bit, but even then analysts appeared to go easy on the Mark Zuckerberg-helmed Silicon Valley darling as they looked far into the future.Netflix has gotten "a lot of free passes" over the last few years, said Tim Nollen, a Macquarie media analyst."I think internet companies are given a lot of credit for just growing viewership figures, or in this case subscriber numbers, without much regards to the cost," he said, adding that "the cost is viewed as the driver of those subscriber figures, and 'We'll worry about earnings later on,' seems to be the attitude."Not so with media companies, whose near-term and longer-term earnings figures get more scrutiny."Costs are a major, major element here," said Nollen.Netflix's budget is already bigger than comparable ones at most entertainment conglomerates. The streaming company is expected to spend $4.93 billion on content this year, outdoing nonsports cable and broadcast programming expenses at Time Warner ($4.89 billion), Disney ($4.5 billion) and Viacom ($3.7 billion), according to MoffettNathanson's estimates.Indeed, Netflix's free-spending ways have caused friction with the incumbent companies by outbidding them for coveted new shows and films or often pushing up the price tags on deals they do secure.But rather than a tech company like Apple (AAPL), whose iTunes store helped transform the music industry, Silicon Valley-based Netflix has pointed to a media superstar when signaling its aspirations: Content Chief Ted Sarandos memorably told GQ three years ago that the company's goal was to "become HBO faster than HBO can become us."Wedbush's Pachter points out that HBO owns its originals, unlike Netflix, which could only count summer hit "Stranger Things" as a completely in-house effort during its conference call. And to label Netflix a media company like Disney, he said, would be "unflattering to Disney."But it was licensed shows like "Orange Is The New Black" and "House of Cards" that put Netflix on Hollywood's map, figuratively and literally. The company is leasing the 14-story, 323,000-square-foot Icon tower and several stages at Sunset Bronson Studios in Los Angeles.Now, like an actor-turned-director, Netflix appears to be yearning for more creative control, and is increasing investments in original programming.The step up from licensing other people's content to creating its own is a "natural progression" from its early days of being a content-licensing pure-play, said BTIG Research analyst Rich Greenfield.In his view, however, Netflix "doesn't want just to be HBO; it wants to be HBO, FX, Nickelodeon, ABC, CBS." (Time Warner owns HBO, 21st Century Fox owns FX, Viacom owns Nickelodeon and Disney owns ABC).But that evolution arguably nudges Netflix into the more traditional territory of being a hit-driven business, which is a risky business."That helps when it's good," said Nollen. "But all studios go through winning and losing streaks. And they could have high expectations for a show that maybe doesn't work so well and doesn't attract subscribers, and they're definitely exposing themselves to more of that."In the near term, Netflix's growth-first strategy could be tested as Amazon (AMZN), the original tech disrupter that keeps disrupting new sectors, ramps up its video offerings and threatens to do to Netflix what it has done to Big Media.Like Netflix, Amazon spends aggressively to grow in new markets. Unlike Netflix, Amazon has pockets that are even deeper than those of the media conglomerates that dominate Hollywood. Netflix's projected 2016 revenue is $8.8 billion, while Amazon's is $136.8 billion.And Amazon CFO Brian Olsavsky said in July that the company is "nearly doubling" its content spend in the second half of 2016 vs. the latter half of last year. (It spent $1.3 billion on content in 2014.)Netflix's current share price "fails to address the potential for meaningful competition from Amazon" and its paid Amazon Prime Video-only offering, even if Netflix currently has the stronger brand as a subscription video-on-demand service, said Pachter in a recent note."(W)e are confident that with its new stand-alone service, Amazon declared war on Netflix," he wrote.Meanwhile, investors largely overlooked Netflix's "unacceptably high" negative $1.5 billion in projected 2016 free cash flow, he added.For now, Netflix's stock looks to continue taking investors on a wild ride, especially around earnings season. The last three quarterly reports sent the stock soaring 19%, diving 13% and plunging 13% the following day."I think we can all see that it's time for me to apologize for the volatility again," said Netflix CEO Reed Hastings in response to an analyst question during the earnings call. "This time it's in a good direction. But I think more and more investors are able to look at the multiyear picture and they see the patterns emerging, and so then it will be less and less about our guidance."That doesn't bother BTIG's Greenfield: "The reality is, as the world shifts to (internet protocol) television, the legacy TV industry isn't equipped to meet the changing landscape and Netflix is taking advantage of that."RELATED: Is Netflix Back On The Road To Prosperity, Or A Trail Of Tears?

Speculation that telecom conglomerate AT&T (T) and media giant Time Warner (TWX) are in merger talks is back.Senior executives at AT&T and Time Warner have met in recent weeks to discuss various business strategies, including a possible merger, according to a Bloomberg report posted just before the close of regular trading Thursday. Time Warner stock jumped more than 4% on the news but was flat in after-hours trading, as was AT&T stock.CNBC in September said AT&T was exploring a jump into the media business following its 2015 acquisition of satellite broadcaster DirecTV Group. The New York Post first reported in January that AT&T had been kicking the tires at Time Warner.AT&T spokesman Fletcher Cook on Thursday declined to comment on the Bloomberg report."We view a merger scenario as unlikely," said Mike McCormack, a Jefferies analyst, in a research report. "AT&T has publicly stated that its 'plate is full' integrating the DirecTV asset, leading us to believe another large transaction isn't in the offing near term."We wouldn't be surprised if the two parties were discussing strategy, particularly as Time Warner content is being offered as part of the pending launch of DirecTV Now, and AT&T is looking to develop innovative video services."A Barclays analyst, though, says AT&T could be interested."TWX is one of the few media companies without super voting shares and has the potential to provide immediate industry scale," said Barclays analyst Kannan Venkateshwar in a recent research note.Cable TV firm Comcast (CMCSA) acquired NBCUniversal in 2011 from General Electric (GE)."Though there could be some industrial logic to the speculated TWX-T combination (similar to CMCSA-NBCU in hindsight), we believe the upfront financial benefits do not seem as readily apparent," the Barclays analyst added. "It is difficult for us to see the positive financial benefits on a stand-alone financial basis. Therefore, the logic for the transaction would largely have to be predicated on competitive necessities, opportunity costs and revenue synergies with benefits unlikely to accrue immediately."AT&T rival Verizon Communications (VZ) acquired AOL for $4.4 billion in 2015. It agreed to buy Yahoo (YHOO) for $4.83 billion in July, although that deal may be renegotiated or scuttled because of an email breach at the internet firm.Time Warner rejected a takeover bid by 21st Century Fox (FOXA) in 2014. According to the Bloomberg report, Time Warner CEO Jeff Bewkes "is a willing seller, if he gets an offer he thinks is fair."Time Warner has rights to sports content through Turner Broadcasting.RELATED:Verizon, Yahoo Lawyers Hash Out Data Breach: Who Has Burden Of Proof?

Google has signed up its first broadcasting content partner -- CBS (CBS) --  for a web TV service set for an early 2017 launch.The over-the-top (OTT) market is expected to heat up with new offerings from AT&T (T), Amazon.com (AMZN), Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and Hulu. What differs in this new wave from earlier Internet video services is the expected inclusion of more live broadcast content. Most OTT services have featured on-demand programming.Google has gain edrights to all of CBS' content, including live NFL games, Reuters and the Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday. CBS has marketed its own stand-alone, direct-to-consumer, web TV service.IBD'S TAKE: The new "Unplugged" OTT service will be part of Google's YouTube platform. Google has not disclosed YouTube's profitability or revenue. Read this IBD in-depth report about YouTube's mysterious financials.AT&T is expected to launch DirecTV Now this quarter. AT&T has leveraged satellite broadcaster DirecTV's programming deals to cobble together an Internet video service. But AT&T has not finalized deals with CBS and 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA), analysts say."The Google deal is understood to pay CBS a rate card premium to its traditional (pay-TV) services," said Stifel analyst Benjamin Mogil in a report. The deal does not include Showtime movies and TV shows, he said.Google reportedly is in talks with  21st Century Fox and Walt Disney (DIS), owner of broadcast network ABC.Dish Network (DISH)  launched SlingTV, its OTT service in early 2015. Sony (SNE) offers PlayStation Vue, a high-end option.AT&T is expected to price its DirecTV Now service at around $50 to $55 monthly. Google's "Unplugged"-branded service may be priced lower, say reports.Hulu is a joint venture of Disney, Fox, and Comcast (CMCSA). Time Warner (TWX) recently bought a 10% stake in Hulu.Apple (AAPL) last year shelved its web TV service as talks with programmers stalled. Cost-sharing to distribute the service was reportedly one issue.Google stock climbed 0.7% to 827.09 in the stock market today, earlier touching an all-time high for the second day in a row.RELATED:AT&T's DirecTV Now Pricing Will Be Key For Comcast, Hulu, Amazon

In Friday's roundup of Twitter (TWTR) chatter are reactions to Sony's plans to release five or more smartphone games by March 2018 and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google Fact Check feature. Plus, Netflix's (NFLX) $40 million deal with Chris Rock.Netflix is said to have outbid Amazon, Time Warner's (TWX) HBO and Hulu, according to Variety. (Hulu is jointly owned by Walt Disney (DIS), Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal and 21st Century Fox (FOXA).)Boom: Netflix is paying CHRIS ROCK $40 MILLION for two specials. By far a new record for a standup. https://t.co/bQ2x8zKNNG— Matthew Belloni (@THRMattBelloni) October 13, 2016That's a lot of money.Damn @chrisrock, congratulations.— Mindy Kaling (@mindykaling) October 13, 2016One can never underestimate the value of @chrisrock #Netflix— Ken Hommel (@APKeatonLunchbx) October 13, 2016Meanwhile, Google debuted its new fact-checking feature, which is conveniently being rolled out just weeks before the presidential election. The "Fact Check" label will be displayed alongside search results that meet certain criteria.Now the fight over what constitutes a fact-check. Do this right, Google. https://t.co/Up84O7sPmG— Zeynep Tufekci (@zeynep) October 13, 2016Some aren't convinced it'll do much good.#Google search added a fact-check feature on news stories. Not sure it will help. https://t.co/V50w0Qd8b5 via @bi_contributors #Election2016— David G Zeiler (@DavidGZeiler) October 14, 2016@zeynep @WarrenPearce Of course, we can trust Google ... cant we?— sarah hartley (@Sarah_A_Hartley) October 13, 2016In gaming news, Sony's decision to roll out mobile games -- notably in the wake of the success of  "Pokemon Go," in which Nintendo has a stake --  has prompted tepid enthusiasm.I’d like to see some mobile games from Sony, provided some real effort is put into them.— George Oscar Bluth (@johnd0p3) October 14, 2016The inclusion of smartphone-game development has console gamers a little worried.Sony and Nintendo doing mobile games.
