Tesla (TSLA), McDonald’s (MCD) and General Electric (GE) all got higher price targets Monday, while media/entertainment giants 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and CBS (CBS) also saw analyst action.Goldman Sachs raised its price target on Tesla to 245 from 230 and maintained its neutral rating on the stock. The electric car maker’s stock price is up about 80% since touching a more than two-year low of 141.05 on Feb. 9.Shares of Tesla rose early but closed down 0.8% to 251.62 on the stock market today.General Electric’s stock price was hiked to 35 from 33 at RBC Capital Markets, which maintained its outperform rating on the stock. On Friday, GE topped quarterly earnings views but reported sluggish organic revenue growth.Shares of GE dipped 0.3% to 30.66 after losing 0.7% Friday. So far GE stock is finding support at the 50-day line.McDonald’s stock price target was raised to 140 from 135 at RBC Capital Markets, which rates the stock an outperform. Cowen & Co. also raised its price target on McDonald’s to 127 from 125 and maintained its market perform rating.On Friday, the fast-food giant beat quarterly earnings and sales views as it continued to benefit from its all-day breakfast and McPick initiatives. McDonald's rose 1.6% Monday to 127.46 after falling intraday to 125.01, nearly undercutting its 124.93 buy point.Wedbush raised its price target on 21st Century Fox to 34 from 33 and its price target on CBS to 63 from 60. 21st Century Fox rose 0.4% and CBS fell 0.35%.Honeywell (HON) got a couple of price target hikes following Friday’s better-than-expected first-quarter sales and earnings results. Stifel raised its price target on the stock to 129 from 127 and maintained its buy rating on the stock. RBC Capital Markets raised its price target to 122 from 121 and maintained its outperform rating on the stock. Honeywell, which announced a $5 billion stock buyback Monday morning, fell 0.8% to 113.25.LinkedIn (LNKD) saw its price target lowered to 130 from 200 at Wedbush, which has a neutral rating on the stock. LinkedIn, which reports earnings on Thursday, rose 0.9% to 120.48.

After amassing a portfolio of critically acclaimed original TV series, Amazon.com (AMZN) has decided the time is right for its subscription streaming video service to go head-to-head with industry leader Netflix (NFLX).The Seattle-based e-commerce giant late Sunday revealed that it will offer its Amazon Prime Video as a stand-alone service for $8.99 a month, a dollar less than Netflix's standard streaming plan.Amazon Prime Video was launched five years ago as an extra for subscribers of Amazon Prime, a program that offers free two-day shipping on millions of items. Amazon Prime costs $99 a year. In addition to the stand-alone video service, Amazon also is offering full Prime membership on a monthly basis. Customers can pay $10.99 a month with no annual commitment or save 25% by paying for the full-year plan.Like Netflix, Amazon has been investing in original content as well as signing exclusive licensing deals for cable and broadcast shows. Amazon original series include “Transparent,” “Mozart in the Jungle,” “Catastrophe,” “Bosch,” “The Man in the High Castle” and “Red Oaks.”Other competitors in the Internet video sector include Hulu and Time Warner's (TWX) HBO. Hulu is co-owned by Comcast (CMCSA), Disney (DIS) and Fox (FOXA).Amazon's move comes as many long-time Netflix customers will see the price of their service jump from $7.99 to $9.99 a month starting next month. Netflix boosted its pricing starting two years ago, but it provided grace periods for existing customers.Netflix stock was down about 3% to near 108 in afternoon trading on the stock market today. The Los Gatos, Calif.-based company is scheduled to report first-quarter earnings after the market close today.Amazon stock was up almost 1% to about 631. Amazon gets an IBD Composite Rating of 84 out of a possible 99, and Netflix a 51.For when to buy, hold or sell off Amazon and other top stocks, sign up for a free trial of IBD LeaderboardAmazon is offering the stand-alone video service only in the U.S. for now, but it is likely to take it to international markets soon, CCS Insight analyst Paolo Pescatore said in a research note Monday.Amazon’s new video offer will limit Netflix’s ability to grow its domestic subscriber base, Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter said in a research note Sunday.“The monthly video offering reflects Amazon’s determination to capture an increased share of Netflix’s addressable market,” he said. “While we don’t expect a significant number of current Netflix customers to defect to Amazon Instant Video, it is likely that Amazon and Netflix will divide the remaining uncommitted market on a roughly equal basis, severely impacting Netflix’s continued domestic growth.”Pachter believes Amazon timed the offer to take advantage of the impending price increase at Netflix.An estimated 30 million domestic Netflix subscribers will see their monthly subscription fees go up starting May 9, he said.Pachter rates Amazon stock as outperform with a price target of 700 and Netflix as underperform with a price target of 45.RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney said Monday that the Amazon offer “creates a negative headwind for Netflix.”However, Mahaney reiterated his outperform rating on Netflix with a price target of 140.“We view this move by Amazon as a significant negative development for Netflix,” he said in a report. “Amazon certainly has the brand name, the customer relationships and the focus on high-quality consumer experiences to impact the growth in Netflix’s U.S. subscriber base, and perhaps eventually its global subscriber base.”Netflix is facing growth challenges in the U.S. market. In the fourth quarter last year, it missed its own target for new domestic subscribers. But its international growth easily beat expectations and offset U.S. weakness.In a survey released last week, consumers ranked Netflix as No. 1 for original programming. It topped HBO for the first time in the six years that Morgan Stanley has tracked consumer preferences in premium video services.Some 29% of survey respondents said Netflix was best in original programming, up from 23% last year, while HBO came in second place at 18% (compared with 31% last year), Morgan Stanley said. Amazon.com, Hulu and CBS (CBS)-owned Showtime were each near 5%.Netflix original shows include “House of Cards,” “Orange Is the New Black,” “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt,” “Narcos” and Marvel comic-book hero shows “Daredevil” and “Jessica Jones.”

Here's your Investing Action Plan: What you need to know as an investor for the coming week. Earnings season kicks into high gear, led by tech giants like Alphabet (GOOGL) and Microsoft (MSFT), industrial heavyweights like General Electric (GE) and General Motors (GM), and leading consumer names like McDonald's (MCD) and Starbucks (SBUX). Oil futures plunged after Sunday's a long-awaited…

Streaming service Hulu debuted a virtual reality app Thursday, just months after Netflix (NFLX) introduced its own app for fans of 3D content.The Hulu VR app, like its Netflix peer, is supported on the Samsung Gear VR headset and powered by Facebook (FB)-owned Oculus. Viewers will be able to watch original 3D content as well as the existing Hulu library in "immersive 360-degree environments," said Hulu's Head of Experience Ben Smith in a release.The Hulu announcement comes as Facebook prepares to start shipping its Oculus Rift headsets on Monday.Some of those new VR films include titles from Discovery Communications (DISCA), National Geographic, Viacom (VIAB) and Showtime Sports. Then there's the meteor-shower-filled short film "The Big One," which Hulu made in partnership with Lions Gate (LGF).Non-Hulu subscribers can also access the site's 3D movies, Smith said. While the app is available only for Samsung Galaxy users, more supported devices and platforms are on the horizon.Hulu is co-owned by Disney (DIS), Comcast (CMCSA) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA). Disney shares rose 0.4%. Comcast added 1.3%. Fox dipped 0.2%, and Netflix lost 1.25%.Ahead of the Oculus Rift debut on Monday, Baird analyst Colin Sebastian tempered those expectations, warning that virtual-reality gear makers like Oculus, HTC and Sony (SNE) might initially face a "trough of disappointment" in adoption and consumer reaction.Facebook shares edged 0.45% higher.RELATED:Virtual Reality Could Disappoint Initially, Baird SaysContent Is King In The War For First Generation Virtual RealityThese Activision, Disney Alums Are Making VR Shows For Oculus, Vive.

Comcast (CMCSA)-owned NBCUniversal is turning up the heat on satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) amid contract renewal talks for programming.Dish Network already is facing tough negotiations with Viacom (VIA). Comcast, on the other side as a pay-TV provider, has been in a dispute with sports channel YES Network over programming fees.NBCU has launched a marketing campaign warning viewers they could be blacked out on Dish Network by March 20, says Broadcasting & Cable. NBCU owns cable channels USA Network, Syfy, Bravo, CNBC and  MSNBC.Dish on Tuesday afternoon said it expects to file for arbitration in the dispute with NBCU.“Under the conditions imposed by the FCC and Department of Justice in approving the Comcast-NBCUniversal merger, NBC is forbidden from blacking out its networks if a pay-TV provider chooses, in its sole discretion, to exercise its right for binding arbitration,” Dish said in a statement.Viacom’s 24 cable networks, meanwhile, include MTV, Nickelodeon and Comedy Central. Dish Network has had disputes with CBS (CBS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Time Warner's (TWX) Turner Broadcasting unit.Comcast is at an impasse with YES Network. Fox took majority control of the YES Network in 2014 from the New York Yankees’ parent company. The Comcast-YES Network dispute affects about 900,000 Comcast customers in New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania.According to an Oppenheimer research report, Fox Networks sought a 33% fee increase for YES programming. Walt Disney’s (DIS) ESPN garners the highest content fees.“We believe programming costs will rise sharply in the near term  but will moderate in the longer term as lower advertising revenues and cord cutting weaken the bargaining power of the content providers and ultimately break the paid-TV model,” wrote Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan. “Programming costs have risen at three times the growth rate of (cable company) revenues during the last five years.”

Netflix (NFLX) has long drawn comparisons to Time Warner’s (TWX) HBO for its critically acclaimed original programming. But the "Game of Thrones" premium cable network has no intentions of becoming more like its online-only peer.In response to a question about the depth of content at streaming service HBO Now, and its $14.99 monthly price vs. Netflix's $7.99-$11.99, Time Warner chief exec Jeff Bewkes dismissed the comparison."We don’t want and we haven’t intended to take that HBO brand and the original programming, and move it to essentially a bulk syndicated (video-on-demand), which is what the new (subscription video-on-demand, or SVOD) entrants mostly have," he said Tuesday at the Deutsche Bank 2016 Media, Internet & Telecom Conference."We do have a very strong current theatrical film offering at HBO that nobody else has, and it should not be overlooked."Bewkes added, "We don’t think it’s to HBO’s advantage to join the other three or four SVOD services that are essentially doing broad-reach syndication services," likely referring to Netflix, Amazon (AMZN) Video and Hulu, which is jointly owned by Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal.Those services are essentially providing a "syndication product with originals," he said, in contrast to HBO's "well-established originals strategy and strong movie slate."He added that HBO Now has "nearly a million" subscribers, up from the 800,000 reported during the company's most recent earnings call.Time Warner shares closed down 2% Tuesday. The stock has been bobbing around its 50-day line for months after more decisively breaking support at the key level last August amid the greater media-stock meltdown over the state of the pay-TV environment.Even in distancing the HBO brand from Netflix and Amazon, Bewkes sounded positive on the network’s ability to gain market share among consumers whose viewing habits are increasingly shifting away from traditional TV sets and to mobile devices, citing Vice and Jon Stewart programming that appear or are scheduled to appear on HBO.A lot of that programming is "aimed at millennials," he said. "It’s great for the broadband product, and it’s very well matched up to the increasing mobile use of HBO Go or HBO Now."

Most cord-cutters still replace cable TV services with Netflix (NFLX) -- no surprise there -- but Apple TV gained in an annual Morgan Stanley survey of consumers who watch Internet video.Apple (AAPL) rolled out its fourth-generation TV hardware in late 2015, but it has shelved plans, at least temporarily, for a Web-based TV service amid stalled negotiations with programmers.The Apple TV streaming device costs from $149 to $199. Apple customers can subscribe to Netflix, HBO and full-season sports subscriptions as well as watch movies and TV shows served up from the iTunes store.Among those planning to cancel pay TV subscriptions, some 35% of the 2,500 consumers surveyed say they are most likely to switch to Netflix, says Morgan Stanley.  That’s down from about 40.7% in the year-earlier study. Apple TV moved up to 23%, from about 17% a year earlier.YouTube, the video website of Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned Google figures two ways in the survey, in which respondents could give more than one answer. Some 20% of respondents said they might replace pay TV with YouTube Red, the new subscription service, while 29% cited the free, ad-supported version of YouTube.Amazon.com’s (AMZN) online video service and Hulu were tied at 27%, with Time Warner’s (TWX) HBO Now service right behind, with 25% of pay TV subscribers saying they were likely to switch to the service.“Among those without a pay TV subscription, Netflix usage is meaningfully higher (47%) vs. Amazon Instant Video (21%), suggesting Netflix is viewed as more of a replacement service to traditional pay TV,” said the Morgan Stanley report.“Netflix remains the leading online video platform for TV/film content in the US, with 40% of respondents saying that they use the service, still well ahead of YouTube (33%), Amazon Instant Video (22%) and Hulu Plus (14%).”Hulu is a joint venture of 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA), Walt Disney (DIS) and Comcast (CMCSA).

Hulu is expected to emerge as a greater threat to Netflix (NFLX) as it expands globally and invests in content, but Hulu may prove "problematic" to its traditional media owners once it reaches a certain subscriber threshold, wrote Jefferies analyst John Janedis late Sunday."Although Netflix has dominated the SVOD (subscription video on demand) landscape to date, we expect the platform will face increased competition from Hulu over the next 2-3 years," he wrote.Janedis believes that Hulu, the "domestic (over-the-top) service to watch in '16," will increase programming investments and likely seek international audiences in the next 1-3 years, a move that will challenge Netflix's expansion goals abroad.And Hulu may bring another partner into the fold, bolstering its efforts against Netflix. Hulu's owners -- Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Comcast’s (CMCSA) NBCUniversal -- have reportedly been in talks to bring on board Time Warner (TWX) as a fourth equity owner.Legacy media makers like Disney, Fox and others have been looking for new ways to connect with viewers as more consumers opt to "cut the cord," nixing their cable subscriptions in favor of online options like Netflix or Amazon (AMZN) Prime Instant Video.Hulu has sought to differentiate itself by offering currently airing series, vs. Netflix's library of past seasons and older shows. And it has been "more aggressive" than Netflix and Amazon in making programming investments during recent months, said the report.Netflix remains a favorite among viewers, with 80% of polled millennials calling it "essential," according to a Jefferies survey. But as it gains steam, its relationship with traditional media companies is seen shifting down the road.Janedis anticipates that Netflix will license "even less" content from networks in the future as it focuses on original content. And the networks will likely respond by looking to monetize more content on Hulu, he said.But Hulu could be a double-edged sword for Big Media companies."The longer-term concern is whether a growing Hulu will serve to benefit the networks, by slowing the growth of Netflix, or if its emergence only establishes another threat to traditional television," wrote Janedis.Better content, Hulu's new ad-free subscription tier and increased marketing are likely driving subscriber growth. That could be a positive in the short term but ultimately wind up drawing consumers away from traditional broadcasters."The risk is whether a commercial-free offering, with improved programming, will only serve to accelerate cord cutting. Above a certain level -- 20-30 mil subs -- will likely prove to be problematic," Janedis said.Netflix stock rose 3% on the stock market today. Amazon advanced 4.6% as the e-commerce giant raised its minimum order for free shipping to $49 for non-Prime members. That could fuel more Prime customers.Walt Disney stock climbed 1.4%, 21st Century Fox 2.7%, Comcast 0.6% and Time Warner 1.6%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Walt Disney’s (DIS) first-quarter results trounced expectations as “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” boosted the studio and consumer products segments, though the media and entertainment giant continued to lose subscribers for its cable channels.But Disney CEO Robert Iger said Tuesday that ESPN, which lost 7 million subscribers in the last two years, has “actually seen an uptick” in subscribers in recent months, and has benefited from the growth of light cable packages, particularly from Dish (DISH).In what amounted to a vigorous defense of ESPN during a conference call, Iger said skinny bundles with the sports cable channel had even wooed cord cutters back. The idea that ESPN is cratering is “ridiculous,” he said. “Sports is too popular.”Disney shares fell 3% late.Iger also clarified the reason behind ESPN’s subscriber decline, blaming faulty Nielsen figures. Once Nielsen corrected those numbers, “we concluded that our sub loss was largely due to the fact that ESPN was not part of skinny bundles that had launched,” he said.He said Disney is exploring “new platform providers,” hinting at more over-the-top, or streaming, options for ESPN.Revenue from Disney’s media networks division, which includes ESPN, grew 8% in fiscal Q1. The segment logged higher ad revenue, offset by lower ratings. Higher programming costs weighed on the sports cable channel, due to the timing of the College Football Playoff bowl games, but that was partially offset by an increase in ad and affiliate revenue, said the company."Affiliate revenue growth was due to contractual rate increases, partially offset by a decline in subscribers and unfavorable foreign currency translation impacts," Disney said in a statement.The hubbub over ESPN comes amid industry-wide concerns that cable viewers are taking their dollars elsewhere — namely, to Netflix (NFLX), Amazon (AMZN) Prime and other over-the-top streaming services.During the quarter, adjusted earnings climbed 28% to $1.63 a share, well above views for $1.45 per share. Revenue grew 14% to $15.24 billion vs. consensus estimates for $14.75 billion.“Driven by the phenomenal success of ‘Star Wars,’ we delivered the highest quarterly earnings in the history of our company, marking our 10th consecutive quarter of double-digit EPS growth,” said Iger in a statement.“The Force Awakens” crossed the $2 billion threshold in global box office sales over the weekend. Studio revenue skyrocketed 46%, year over year.Disney’s theme park and resorts segment revenue rose 9%, said the company. Consumer products and interactive media revenue rose 8%.Earlier Tuesday, Viacom (VIAB) shares tanked 21.5% after the media company logged its fourth consecutive quarter of revenue declines and Q1 revenue fell short of expectations.Earnings fell 8.5% to $1.18, in line with consensus estimates, as sales fell 6% to $3.15 billion, below analysts’ forecasts for $3.26 billion.Viacom's filmed entertainment revenue tumbled 15% on theatrical and home-entertainment revenue declines. Media-networks revenue fell 3% as domestic ad revenue dropped 4% and ratings declined.

"Star Wars: The Force Awakens" hit the $2 billion mark over the weekend, but Walt Disney (DIS) investors are likely focusing on ESPN subscriber figures ahead of the media conglomerate's first-quarter earnings report late Tuesday. The Lucasfilm epic has brought in an estimated $906 million domestically, according to Box Office Mojo, with almost $2.01 billion in worldwide ticket sales. It joins "Titanic" ($2.19 billion) and "Avatar" ($2.79 billion) as…

Shares of Disney closed down 3.8% Wednesday. Here are five takeaways from Iger's sometimes exasperated comments on ESPN and Disney's plans to adapt to…

Netflix (NFLX) received a bullish upgrade from Piper Jaffray on Tuesday, but with the overall market taking a sharp step down the stock quickly reversed lower.The analyst believes that Netflix could nearly double its current subscriber base of 75 million by 2020. And the 142 million-subscriber estimate could be conservative since the projection models just a 15% international penetration rate, including 1% penetration in China.Piper Jaffray has a 122 price target on Netflix, which represents about a 30% premium to Monday’s closing price.Netflix staged a downside reversal in the stock market today in above-average volume, dropping 2.9%. Shares have been trading in five-month-low territory for the last few sessions, after breaching support at the 200-day line last month. Netflix is now trading 30% below its early December high.Amazon’s (AMZN) 54 million U.S. Amazon Prime subscribers gives it more potential viewers than Netflix, with its nearly 45 million U.S. subscribers. But according to a report by Consumer Intelligence Research Partners late last month, Netflix has significantly more actual viewers.Still, Amazon’s streaming service is gaining traction from critical acclaim for its original shows.Amazon sank 4%, falling for a third session in a row in above-average volume after issuing a lackluster quarterly earnings report last week.The stock is still holding above the critical 200-day line. It’s trading about 20% below its late December high.Netflix and Amazon both face competition from Hulu, a joint venture between Disney (DIS), Comcast (CMCSA) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA). Time Warner (TWX) is reportedly in talks to buy a 25% stake in the streaming service.In early January, Time Warner retook its downward-sloping 50-day line in heavy volume. The stock is now trading about 20% below its high reached last July, and was down 1.8% Tuesday.Disney has been drifting lower since November amid fears about ESPN-subscriber losses. Volume has been heavy more for down days than for up days. Disney is about 23% below its July peak.Comcast is trading 15% below its 52-week high while Fox is about 24% below its 52-week high.

Time Warner (TWX) reportedly doesn't like that viewers can watch the latest episodes of shows like "Brooklyn Nine-Nine" or "Modern Family" on Hulu -- and the issue is factoring into discussions over the media conglomerate's interest in the streaming service. Amid ongoing talks about Time Warner potentially buying a 25% equity stake in Hulu, Time Warner said it ultimately does…

Viacom (VIAB) said it is exploring the sale of a "significant strategic" minority stake in its film studio, Paramount Pictures, after possible investors expressed interest. But who might those future partners be?"We have received indications of interest from potential partners seeking a strategic investment in Paramount Pictures and I have decided to pursue discussions with a select group of potential investors," said Viacom CEO Philippe Dauman in a Tuesday statement. He announced the news at the Jefferies Media & Communications Conference in New York City.Viacom shares were briefly halted and rose as high as 39.45 intraday, but in closed up just 0.4% at 37.01 on the stock market today.Dauman, who recently took the reins from Sumner Redstone as executive chairman, said in the company's Feb. 9 earnings release that 2015 was a "challenging year" as Viacom redesigned itself and adapted to "significant industry disruption." Revenue missed estimates, though earnings matched views. Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN), among other over-the-top services, have been shaking up entertainment consumption for several years now.Don't expect the new interest in an equity stake to come from anyone else in Hollywood, says one analyst."We would expect minority partners to likely be from China, given that country's global box office ambitions and possibly as well as from India (Reliance)," said wrote Stifel analyst Benjamin Mogil. "We would not expect any domestic or European suitors."Such a development would be favorable, he said, "given that Paramount, from a replacement value, could be worth north of $10 (billion), in our view, compared to the current Viacom enterprise value of $28 (billion)."Other traditional media companies, including Walt Disney (DIS), Time Warner (TWX), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and others, have had to adapt to the modern viewer. Uncertainty in the industry has weighed on media stocks.Netflix fell 3.1% and Amazon 1.2%. Walt Disney fell 1% and 21st Century Fox 1.5%, while Time Warner advanced 0.6%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Amazon (AMZN) and Netflix's (NFLX) Sundance shopping spree continues, and price tags at the film festival have reached monumental proportions. But traditional studios aren't surrendering to the streaming heavyweights. Netflix reportedly offered up $20 million for the slave-rebellion period drama, "The Birth of a Nation," driving the price up. But 21st Century Fox's (FOXA) Fox Searchlight ultimately walked away with…

But it is exploring options to become part of some skinny bundles and over-the-top streaming offerings. "We can sell ESPN as a standalone product, but we do not believe…

21st Century Fox (FOXA) led the Oscar pack Thursday morning, as "The Revenant" racked up 12 nominations, and "The Martian" picked up seven nods for an Academy Award. Both were distributed by the media conglomerate's studio arm, 20th Century Fox. "The Revenant," backed by New Regency Pictures, received nominations in a dozen categories, including best picture and best director. The…

JPMorgan is bullish on the upcoming “Broadcast Incentive Auction,” which will free up prime, low-frequency airwaves owned by local TV broadcasters for wireless data services.Naysayers continue to contend that the Federal Communications Commission faces many challenges in pulling off a successful auction, which for now is scheduled to start late next month. One risk is that broadcasters might drop out of the auction if they determine that bidding prices are disappointing.The auction is key for T-Mobile US (TMUS), which needs spectrum. AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ) own most of the available low-frequency spectrum, in which waves travel longer distances, among other advantages over higher-frequency spectrum.JPMorgan expects at least 70 MHz of airwaves, and possibly more, to be auctioned. The key is that broadcasters that own two local TV stations will sell off airwaves from one and keep spectrum from the other, says JPMorgan.“We estimate that 70-100 MHz will be auctioned, for $25 billion to $35 billion,” said JPMorgan in a research report.Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA) and CBS (CBS) are expected to sell airwaves in some markets. While Comcast’s (CMCSA) cable company is a potential bidder, it also owns media firm NBCUniversal, a likely seller of airwaves.Smaller local TV station owners include Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) and Gray Television (GTNA).“We view FOX and CBS as best positioned to monetize duopoly affiliates in large markets, followed by Comcast and Sinclair,” said JPMorgan. Walt Disney (DIS), which owns ABC, is not expected to sell airwaves. Private investment firms such as Columbia Capital are eyeing the auction, says a Washington Post report.JPMorgan predicts cable TV firms will show up, but it doubts that Internet giants will bid."We expect that AT&T, Verizon, and T-Mobile will be the biggest bidders ($21 billion-$30 billion cumulative spend), that Sprint (S)/SoftBank (SFTBY) will not register, and Dish Network (DISH) will at most be an opportunistic buyer," said the JPMorgan report. "We estimate Comcast, potentially in partnership with other cable companies, could spend $3 billion-$5 billion, and private equity funds in aggregate could spend $1 billion-$2 billion."We do not expect digital economy players like Alphabet-Google (GOOGL) or Amazon.com (AMZN) to bid, though they can never be ruled out.”

Since Time Warner (TWX) chief Jeff Bewkes reportedly said Monday that he might be open to a sale of the company, Apple (AAPL), AT&T (T) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) have all been floated as potential buyers of the entertainment conglomerate.

According to the New York Post, Bewkes disclosed to investors in a series of closed-door meetings Monday that he didn't see the sense in selling or spinning off premium cable network HBO or the Turner Broadcasting cable unit, reportedly saying that "splitting up can destroy value."
Last week, the same publication reported that activist shareholders might pressure the media giant into splitting off "Game of Thrones" broadcaster HBO.

But Bewkes "hinted" that he might be amenable to selling all of Time Warner. And tech heavyweight Apple, which is rolling out a streaming TV service and previously teamed up with Time Warner on the launch of HBO Now, is "staying extra close to any possible movement on this front," said the New York Post, citing a senior tech insider.
AT&T and Fox have also been tossed around as possible suitors. In 2014, Fox made a bid to acquire Time Warner but withdrew after Time Warner shunned its efforts.

Meanwhile, activist investor Carl Icahn told Reuters that he does not have a position in Time Warner, despite earlier reports that he was building a stake in the company. About 10 years ago, Icahn made a unsuccessful attempt to break up Time Warner.
Time Warner shares finished the session down 0.6% in the stock market Wednesday. Apple shares fell 2.6%, AT&T dipped 0.5%, and Fox lost 2.1%.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.

Thanks to Netflix, Twitter and a seemingly bottomless well of material to rehash, the movie business has fundamentally transformed into a go-big-or-go-home arena — and chances are, it won't ever change back.

Out of the 691 titles released theatrically last year, just two brought in over 10% of domestic grosses, and they weren't based on new material, but on sequels to a 23-year-old dinosaur adventure and a space epic from the late '70s.

"Between 'Jurassic World' and 'Star Wars' alone, in 2015, they made over $1.2 billion," said Rentrak (RENT) box office analyst Paul Dergarabedian. "You're talking about two movies making over a billion. Two."

The lopsided box-office takes for "Jurassic World" and "Star Wars" were not for lack of new releases. The major studios, including Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Viacom's (VIAB) Paramount, Comcast's (CMCSA) Universal and Time Warner's (TWX) Warner Bros., collectively put out 86 movies last year, up 16% from 2014's 74 releases, according to Exhibitor Relations data.
And 2015 proved to be a banner year in film: Ticket sales in the U.S. and Canada climbed 7.4% to hit a record $11.1 billion.
But not all movies are created equal. The top-20 grossing movies carried 50% of last year's box office, up from 41% in 2014 and 42% in 2013, as Hollywood shifts its development strategy.
"You're sort of seeing a bifurcation of what studios are really looking to invest in," Morningstar analyst Neil Macker told IBD.

Studios are migrating to a "barbell strategy," he said, developing more high-budget, blockbuster-type movies, as well as more lower-budget films that don't require crushed box-office records to prove profitable. That means mid-budget movies — often rom-coms and talky dramas — get left by the wayside.

This is partly a reflection of viewer trends. The average moviegoer has become more discriminating, said Stifel analyst Benjamin Mogil, as online streaming-video options like Netflix (NFLX) or Apple (AAPL) iTunes movie rentals gain steam.
Also not helping movies is the "explosion of prestige drama" on TV, as Macker puts it, from networks like Time Warner's HBO, Fox's FX, Netflix and Amazon (AMZN) Video.
"That's where a lot of the (screen)writers are going and a lot of the viewers are going also," he said.

So when consumers do plan on a Friday night at the movies, they want the "full theatrical experience," Mogil told IBD. And surround sound and big screens merit explosions, special effects and pop culture fanfare.
Last year "clearly marked one where dramas and comedies, along with many kids films and horror, had challenges," he wrote separately in a Jan. 3 note.

"While ticket prices have largely remained in check of late, the increased proliferation/ease of (video on demand) and (subscription video on demand) have made the theater-going experience one which outperforms for the major event titles but has difficulty for middle-of-the-road fare."
Even Apple Flops In Theaters

That might explain why "Steve Jobs," the biopic on the Apple co-founder, took in less than $18 million, despite being penned by Aaron Sorkin and starring heavy hitters like Kate Winslet and Michael Fassbender.
Meanwhile, 2015 box office winner "The Force Awakens" has raked in more money than all eight Oscar-nominated best picture contenders combined, both domestically and abroad.

Action-heavy spectacles appear to translate across cultures better than other films. Universal's "Furious 7" — the seventh installment of "The Fast and the Furious" franchise — is the No. 6 grossing film of all time, according to Box Office Mojo.

But that's not to say that simply making any old blockbuster or sequel will do. Plenty have bombed. "Fantastic Four," which had a reported $120 million production budget, brought in only $56.1 million domestically last year.
The Twitter Effect

This broad shift in cinema trends has contributed to a repetitive theatrical cycle of "Groundhog Day" proportions, with more franchise-based blockbusters, more people watching those blockbusters, and more studios making blockbusters because that appears to be what's working.
Only two of the top-grossing 2015 releases were originals: Disney Pixar's "Inside Out" and Twentieth Century Fox's "The Martian."
"Hollywood has always had the attitude of: If something succeeds, do it again and again and again until people get sick of it," said Exhibitor Relations analyst Karie Bible.

Online chatter can also add to the snowball effect that nudges people toward already-popular tentpole titles instead of smaller critical darlings, widening the chasm between blockbusters and average performers, as well as shrinking the margin of error for studios.

"Often when studios try to get very creative or original ... the audience just stays away," Dergarabedian said. "It just depends on the movie and the buzz. All the marketing dollars in the world can't change the social media sentiment, and that's the thing the studios can't control."
Mogil echoed the idea that the Twitter (TWTR)-verse has sway as a collective culture influencer.
"Because of social media, people know really quickly if it's a good movie or not," he said.

In 2016, more sequels and reboots are expected to lead the box office again. Stifel predicts that March's release of "Batman v. Superman" and December's "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story" will each make about $400 million apiece. "The Force Awakens," which came out in mid-December, is expected to deliver another $300 million this year for Disney.
'Fast and the Furious 27'?

If viewers' habits line up with all of Stifel's top-10 predictions, that will mean that all but one film — Disney's new animated princess, "Moana" — will be spinoffs or sequels to existing properties, such as "Harry Potter," "Star Trek," "Independence Day" and "Alice in Wonderland."
Will moviegoers ever weary of superhero sequels and epic franchises?

"It's a tougher question because you need a bunch of sequels to bomb out before you decide not to make them," said Mogil. "And if they work abroad, you're still going to be making them. There will always be breakout hits from (intellectual property) that are brand new. (But) for the foreseeable future, (the industry will) go with stuff that works and stuff that's known."Thanks to Netflix, Twitter and a seemingly bottomless well of material to rehash, the movie business has fundamentally transformed into a go-big-or-go-home arena — and chances are, it won't ever change back.Out of the 691 titles released theatrically last year, just two brought in over 10% of domestic grosses, and they weren't based on new material, but on sequels to a 23-year-old dinosaur adventure and a space epic from the late '70s."Between 'Jurassic World' and 'Star Wars' alone, in 2015, they made over $1.2 billion," said Rentrak (RENT) box office analyst Paul Dergarabedian. "You're talking about two movies making over a billion. Two."The lopsided box-office takes for "Jurassic World" and "Star Wars" were not for lack of new releases. The major studios, including Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Viacom's (VIAB) Paramount, Comcast's (CMCSA) Universal and Time Warner's (TWX) Warner Bros., collectively put out 86 movies last year, up 16% from 2014's 74 releases, according to Exhibitor Relations data.And 2015 proved to be a banner year in film: Ticket sales in the U.S. and Canada climbed 7.4% to hit a record $11.1 billion.But not all movies are created equal. The top-20 grossing movies carried 50% of last year's box office, up from 41% in 2014 and 42% in 2013, as Hollywood shifts its development strategy."You're sort of seeing a bifurcation of what studios are really looking to invest in," Morningstar analyst Neil Macker told IBD.Studios are migrating to a "barbell strategy," he said, developing more high-budget, blockbuster-type movies, as well as more lower-budget films that don't require crushed box-office records to prove profitable. That means mid-budget movies — often rom-coms and talky dramas — get left by the wayside.This is partly a reflection of viewer trends. The average moviegoer has become more discriminating, said Stifel analyst Benjamin Mogil, as online streaming-video options like Netflix (NFLX) or Apple (AAPL) iTunes movie rentals gain steam.Also not helping movies is the "explosion of prestige drama" on TV, as Macker puts it, from networks like Time Warner's HBO, Fox's FX, Netflix and Amazon (AMZN) Video."That's where a lot of the (screen)writers are going and a lot of the viewers are going also," he said.So when consumers do plan on a Friday night at the movies, they want the "full theatrical experience," Mogil told IBD. And surround sound and big screens merit explosions, special effects and pop culture fanfare.Last year "clearly marked one where dramas and comedies, along with many kids films and horror, had challenges," he wrote separately in a Jan. 3 note."While ticket prices have largely remained in check of late, the increased proliferation/ease of (video on demand) and (subscription video on demand) have made the theater-going experience one which outperforms for the major event titles but has difficulty for middle-of-the-road fare."Even Apple Flops In TheatersThat might explain why "Steve Jobs," the biopic on the Apple co-founder, took in less than $18 million, despite being penned by Aaron Sorkin and starring heavy hitters like Kate Winslet and Michael Fassbender.Meanwhile, 2015 box office winner "The Force Awakens" has raked in more money than all eight Oscar-nominated best picture contenders combined, both domestically and abroad.Action-heavy spectacles appear to translate across cultures better than other films. Universal's "Furious 7" — the seventh installment of "The Fast and the Furious" franchise — is the No. 6 grossing film of all time, according to Box Office Mojo.But that's not to say that simply making any old blockbuster or sequel will do. Plenty have bombed. "Fantastic Four," which had a reported $120 million production budget, brought in only $56.1 million domestically last year.The Twitter EffectThis broad shift in cinema trends has contributed to a repetitive theatrical cycle of "Groundhog Day" proportions, with more franchise-based blockbusters, more people watching those blockbusters, and more studios making blockbusters because that appears to be what's working.Only two of the top-grossing 2015 releases were originals: Disney Pixar's "Inside Out" and Twentieth Century Fox's "The Martian.""Hollywood has always had the attitude of: If something succeeds, do it again and again and again until people get sick of it," said Exhibitor Relations analyst Karie Bible.Online chatter can also add to the snowball effect that nudges people toward already-popular tentpole titles instead of smaller critical darlings, widening the chasm between blockbusters and average performers, as well as shrinking the margin of error for studios."Often when studios try to get very creative or original ... the audience just stays away," Dergarabedian said. "It just depends on the movie and the buzz. All the marketing dollars in the world can't change the social media sentiment, and that's the thing the studios can't control."Mogil echoed the idea that the Twitter (TWTR)-verse has sway as a collective culture influencer."Because of social media, people know really quickly if it's a good movie or not," he said.In 2016, more sequels and reboots are expected to lead the box office again. Stifel predicts that March's release of "Batman v. Superman" and December's "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story" will each make about $400 million apiece. "The Force Awakens," which came out in mid-December, is expected to deliver another $300 million this year for Disney.'Fast and the Furious 27'?If viewers' habits line up with all of Stifel's top-10 predictions, that will mean that all but one film — Disney's new animated princess, "Moana" — will be spinoffs or sequels to existing properties, such as "Harry Potter," "Star Trek," "Independence Day" and "Alice in Wonderland."Will moviegoers ever weary of superhero sequels and epic franchises?"It's a tougher question because you need a bunch of sequels to bomb out before you decide not to make them," said Mogil. "And if they work abroad, you're still going to be making them. There will always be breakout hits from (intellectual property) that are brand new. (But) for the foreseeable future, (the industry will) go with stuff that works and stuff that's known."

The end of last year brought a host of predictions about how Apple (AAPL) might spend its more than $200 billion in cash and investments. Currently the Cupertino, Calif.-based company is using its cash on hand for stock buybacks and dividends.But some on Wall Street are itching for Apple to pull off a big acquisition with its pile of dough. The latest speculation has Apple among those interested in buying TV and movie giant Time Warner (), which has a current market cap of about $57 billion.The biggest deal Apple has ever made was purchasing Beats Music and Beats Electronics for $3 billion in August 2014.A New York Post article on Tuesday suggested that Time Warner CEO Jeff Bewkes is open to the possibility of a sale of the company. Since then, Apple, AT&T (T) and 21st Century Fox ()have been rumored as potential buyers of the entertainment conglomerate.The Post report said Apple would be interested in Time Warner's assets to support the launch of a stand-alone streaming TV service. Time Warner owns CNN, HBO, TBS, TNT and other cable channels.Fortune writer Philip Elmer-DeWitt outlined the reasons for a deal in a column titled "Why Apple Should Buy Time Warner."Apple has been trying for years to assemble a "skinny bundle" of popular cable channels for an Internet TV service but without success. Buying Time Warner would give that to Apple in an instant, he said.But just because Apple has the cash doesn't mean they will spend it on a big acquisition. Apple has been loath to make large acquisitions for fear of harming its corporate culture. Apple likes to make small tuck-in acquisitions of companies with interesting technologies or talented engineers. It also has a reputation for wanting to build new products and services in house rather than acquire what someone else has developed.In a Dec. 10 [PAGE[research]] report, FBR analyst Daniel Ives put together a "Christmas M&A list" of deals that Apple might consider in 2016. He listed Adobe Systems (ADBE), Box (BOX), GoPro (GPRO) and Tesla Motors (TSLA)."Although we clearly can see Cupertino focusing on a number of skunkworks initiatives (e.g., Project Titan, virtual reality Faceshift, etc.) in 2016 and not pursuing major M&A prospects, with $200 billion of cash in the coffer (and growing), we can finally envision Apple making a larger acquisition, as the conditions are ripe for (CEO Tim) Cook to make a move," Ives said.Research firm CCS Insight predicted Nov. 20 that Apple might buy either Box or Dropbox in 2016 to extend its iCloud package of services into the enterprise market.On Dec. 31, Investors.com published a list of "The wildest tech M&A predictions for 2016." Among those predictions, the writers and editors of entertainment magazine Variety predicted that Apple will buy a movie studio in 2016 to support its goals for a subscription Internet video service.Variety listed Viacom (VIAB), Sony (SNE) and Time Warner's HBO as possible targets.

Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN) are transforming Hollywood with apparent clarity about what they want: original content, a solid library and paying viewers.But does Big Media, rooted in almost-quaint traditions like upfronts and Nielsen ratings, know how to fight back in this brave new world of cord cutting? Or will the entertainment industry's center of gravity shift permanently to Silicon Valley?The threat of over-the-top (OTT) streaming services keeps raising the stakes for the incumbents, whose varied responses face a daunting task. Channels once deemed impervious are now bleeding subscribers, advertising dollars are getting plowed into digital media, and the disruptors are piling up awards.The trends are once again expected to be scrutinized as media giants report quarterly results in the coming week.Millennials and teens largely consider televisions to be old-school technology. Most 18- to 34-year-olds prefer watching shows on a laptop or mobile device, not a TV, according to a Magid Advisors poll.Major networks have followed young eyeballs over to the web. A hodgepodge of streaming services are available to viewers, ranging from multi-network Hulu to NBC's new comedy-centric outlet, SeeSo.More than 30 new OTT services were introduced in 2015 alone, said research firm SNL Kagan, which tracks over 100 such offerings. The overwhelming number of options might make it seem like traditional media outlets are having a hard time refining their strategies."I don’t think they’re hyper-focused; I don’t think they’re being sloppy," SNL Kagan analyst Ali Choukeir told Investor's Business Daily.But at the same time, there are so many different kinds of online streaming choices out there that it's "like spinning plates," he added. "There’s just a lot going on."NBCUniversal parent Comcast (CMCSA) has Stream for Internet-only customers. Walt Disney (DIS) launched OTT services abroad. Viacom (VIAB) introduced Noggin for kids.TBS and CNN parent Time Warner (TWX) allows users to watch its content from any device. It also offers premium cable network HBO in two streaming forms, HBO Now and HBO Go, the former being a standalone service available to non-cable subscribers.Time Warner is also said to be in talks to acquire a 25% equity stake in Hulu, the online streamer jointly owned by 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Disney and Comcast's NBCUniversal.Wall Street is increasingly paying attention to the paid subscription service with Big Media backing. Once dismissed as "Clown Co.," Hulu is now nothing to laugh at.The service has emerged as a viable OTT competitor to Netflix, Amazon and others, wrote Jefferies analyst John Janedis in a note to clients, highlighting its investment in content and new $11.99 ad-free subscription tier."We think Hulu is 'the OTT service to watch in 2016,'" he wrote last month, "as the impact of these changes starts to unfold, not only to the extent that it may slow Netflix’s subscriber growth, but also if the value proposition accelerates cord cutting of traditional linear television."Hulu has only 9 million subscribers to Netflix's nearly 45 million video customers in the U.S. (and over 75 million subscribers worldwide). But its growth rate outpaces that of Netflix and its broadcast parentage affords a unique feature: the ability to offer shows that have just aired on linear TV."With all these guys, especially Netflix and Amazon, they’ve all got original content," said Choukeir. "Original content is a differentiator for sure, but with Hulu, next-day (content) is a further differentiator."Potential investor Time Warner reportedly is not a fan of the feature, but Choukeir said he doesn't see the core of Hulu's business changing.If Time Warner comes on board, that'll leave CBS (CBS) as the only major network not on the service.But it may be happy to be left alone as it focuses on its streaming service CBS All Access, which offers both a live CBS feed and previously aired content, and mulls a possible streaming subscription service for the CW network, which it co-owns with Time Warner's Warner Bros.So how are Hulu, HBO and the rest of the field faring against digital pure plays?There are no clear winners or losers just yet, said SNL Kagan's Choukeir."There’s still a lot to be learned," he said. "There’s a lot of experimentation going on."Strategies may also evolve as media giants find their footing online. Netflix is a double-edged sword for them: Licensing revenue they receive is an appealing source of cash, but giving Netflix access to content is essentially feeding the competition.Time Warner and Fox executives have in recent months raised concerns about the issue, with Fox CEO James Murdoch reportedly saying the company might license more of its programming to Hulu instead.Advertising dollars are at risk, as marketers take their money to digital platforms at the expense of TV. Cowen & Co. believes that "digital is likely to take several hundred basis points of ad share away from national TV in 2016 and 2017."Additionally, one area that has long been considered a pay-TV stronghold -- live sports -- faces uncertainty. Disney's longtime moneymaker, ESPN, lost 7 million subscribers between 2013-15, bringing its total to 92 million as of late last year.Concern over subscriber losses and cord-cutting prompted a media meltdown last August. Cowen analyst Doug Creutz noted that media stocks should get "a bit of a reprieve" in the first half of 2016 as ad trends have improved, cord-cutting doesn't appear to be accelerating, and the group is trading at a discount to the market.But he also said the major media names "remain difficult as longer-term investments."When it comes to online efforts, it may simply be a matter of kicking back on the sofa and watching which streaming subscription services find fame and fortune -- and which get voted off the island."It’s tough to forecast when we’re going to see a shakeout, because the marketplace is very saturated." said Choukeir. "But at the same time, there are a lot of services out there catering to audiences who are buying their content."

Special Report: CES 2016 Tech Show NewsLAS VEGAS — Hollywood movie studios are rethinking video entertainment as the industry approaches the coming age of high-definition virtual reality.Studios will need to offer more than just 360-degree surround video and audio for upcoming headsets such as Facebook's ([STOCK[FB]]) Oculus Rift, HTC's Vive and Sony's ([STOCK[SNE]]) PlayStation VR. They will need to provide interactive, immersive storytelling in virtual worlds, members of a Consumer Electronics Show (CES) panel discussion said Wednesday.While the Harry Potter films were about watching a boy wizard grow up, a VR game of the same concept would have to be about the experience of actually being a wizard, said Andy Cochrane, director of interactive and new media and special projects lead at Mirada."It's not 360 video. That's not VR," Cochrane said. "The stories we're going to be able to tell to mass audiences and the experiences we're going to be able to create are going to get bigger and better and more immersive and involving."Ted Schilowitz, futurist with Twenty-First Century Fox ([STOCK[FOXA]])-owned 20th Century Fox, said that the major studios are "dipping their toes in" VR content and want to be ready when the installed base is large enough for it to sell content.Virtual reality games are expected to be the first killer app for VR.Sony's PlayStation VR will have an early edge in the market because of its large installed base of PlayStation 4 owners, said Guy Primus, co-founder and CEO of The Virtual Reality Co.Sony announced Tuesday that it has sold more than 35.9 million PS4 video game consoles globally as of Jan. 3, including over 5.7 million units during the holiday shopping season.PlayStation VR is expected to be available in the first half of 2016, but pricing for the goggles has not been announced.Meanwhile, Oculus announced Wednesday that its headset will cost $599, which is at the high end of expectations. It will be available in March. But it requires a high-end PC to work."We have to give people a real reason to want to pay $600 for a headset and $1,500 to $2,000 for a super computer, and to make an investment in the content," Primus said.Entertainment professionals are excited about the potential for VR."We see virtual reality as being the fusion of [PAGE[technology]] and storytelling," said Aaron Koblin, co-founder and chief technology officer of Vrse. "We're at the earliest stages, so that doesn't really exist yet."

When Twitter (TWTR) reports earnings on Wednesday, analysts will be looking to see if the social media firm known for its global reach has managed to boost its user numbers. During the past year, Twitter has brought in a new CEO, made numerous other executive suite changes, acquired new companies and added new services. Still, its user numbers are…

AT&T (T) on Wednesday became the latest pay-TV company to lash out at Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) in the wake of the Federal Communications Commission’s proposal to open up the set-top box market to more suppliers.FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler last week proposed a new rule that would make it easier for consumers to switch from set-top boxes rented from cable TV companies to devices sold by consumer electronics or Internet companies.Pay-TV providers such as Comcast (CMCSA) lease broadband cable modems as well as set-top-boxes to consumers, charging them on a monthly basis. The FCC aims to make programming bundles sold by pay-TV companies accessible from a wider range of devices.After Wheeler announced the initiative, Google followed up by demonstrating a set-top box to Congressional staffers at its Washington D.C. office, according to the “Future of TV Coalition,” a lobbying group formed by cable TV companies, industry groups, programmers and others.AT&T, in a blog post on Wednesday, took a shot at Google.“When you get beyond all the hype, Google and its affiliated proponents of this technology mandate are simply trying to take our competitive service and repackage it as their own, without ever having to negotiate with us or with the content owners with whom we had to negotiate to create our service offering. It’s akin to the FCC mandating that we get access to Google’s home page so that we can redesign and rebrand it as our own,” said Stacy Fuller, AT&T vice president of federal regulatory issues.A Comcast blog post last week said that companies concerned about the FCC proposal include: set-top box maker Arris Group (ARRS), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Roku, as well as Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Comcast's NBCUniversal and Viacom (VIA).Scott Cleland, head of consultancy Precursor Group said: “The FCC would be giving Google access to most of the benefits and business value of their pay-TV competitors for free. The real story here is Google wants to add TV advertising as their next-most-coveted market to dominate.”

Amazon (AMZN) battled back from midday weakness to end a seven-session losing streak in the stock market today as the e-commerce giant's streaming video service impressed at Sunday night's Golden Globe awards.

Amazon's original "Mozart in the Jungle" won best comedy TV series and best actor in a comedy TV series. Netflix (NFLX) received eight nominations but no awards, while Hulu, which is co-owned by Disney (DIS), Fox (FOXA) and Comcast (CMCSA), also received a nomination.
Amazon shares popped up as much as 2% in average volume Monday morning, entered negative territory by the afternoon, and recovered to close the session 1.8% higher.
The move halts a streak of losses that have put the stock over 10% below its high and a profit-taking zone in just a week and a half.
The stock is trading just out of buy range of the base it broke out of in October and is below its 50-day moving average.
As activist investors pressure Time Warner (TWX) to sell or spin off HBO, there's speculation that Amazon could potentially buy or invest in the network to better compete with Netflix.

Netflix announced at the Consumer Electronics Show last week that it has essentially completed its global expansion, with the service now available in 130 additional countries. Netflix has yet to enter China, but has plans to do so soon.

Netflix's stock has struggled to hold above its 50-day moving average in recent sessions, but it's still trading well above its 200-day line. Netflix rose 3.2% on Monday, but found resistance at the 50-day line.
Shares are about 14% below their high reached about a month ago, as the stock tried to break out of a consolidation.
Meanwhile, Apple (AAPL) hopes for its own streaming video service have stalled.
Apple is trading nearly 27% below its April high. Shares were up 1.6% in slightly above-average volume Monday amid several positive analyst reports.

Shares of Time Warner (TWX) ticked up 1.4% Friday following a New York Post report that activist shareholders might pressure the media conglomerate to either sell or spin off its premium cable network HBO.

No official moves have been made, but New York-based Corvex Management — headed by Carl Icahn disciple Keith Meister — is considering taking action, said the Post, citing people familiar with the matter.
The news comes a day after Time Warner CFO Howard Averill reportedly said that the company is pursuing "stacking rights " from studios so that full seasons of shows can be aired all at once.

Such a move would allow viewers to binge-watch television programs, Netflix (NFLX)-style, giving Time Warner the chance to better compete with online streaming services as both Netflix and Amazon (AMZN) Prime Instant Video encroach on traditional broadcaster territory.

Earlier in the week, Netflix announced that it had expanded into 130 additional countries, effectively making its streaming service available globally, with the exception of China. The over-the-top content provider appears to gaining steam as media stocks largely struggled through 2015.

Meanwhile, one Credit Suisse analyst said Wednesday that 21st Century Fox (FOXA) investors are overlooking the "unrecognized" value of assets like online streamer Hulu, which is co-owned by Fox, Walt Disney (DIS) and Comcast (CMCSA). The service has a fraction of the subscribers of Netflix but is growing at a quick clip.
Netflix shares fell 2.8%. Amazon shares edged down 0.2%.

Netflix Completes Global Rollout In One Fell Swoop

Why Fox Investors Shouldn't Ignore Netflix Peer Hulu.Shares of Time Warner (TWX) ticked up 1.4% Friday following a New York Post report that activist shareholders might pressure the media conglomerate to either sell or spin off its premium cable network HBO.No official moves have been made, but New York-based Corvex Management — headed by Carl Icahn disciple Keith Meister — is considering taking action, said the Post, citing people familiar with the matter.The news comes a day after Time Warner CFO Howard Averill reportedly said that the company is pursuing "stacking rights " from studios so that full seasons of shows can be aired all at once.Such a move would allow viewers to binge-watch television programs, Netflix (NFLX)-style, giving Time Warner the chance to better compete with online streaming services as both Netflix and Amazon (AMZN) Prime Instant Video encroach on traditional broadcaster territory.Earlier in the week, Netflix announced that it had expanded into 130 additional countries, effectively making its streaming service available globally, with the exception of China. The over-the-top content provider appears to gaining steam as media stocks largely struggled through 2015.Meanwhile, one Credit Suisse analyst said Wednesday that 21st Century Fox (FOXA) investors are overlooking the "unrecognized" value of assets like online streamer Hulu, which is co-owned by Fox, Walt Disney (DIS) and Comcast (CMCSA). The service has a fraction of the subscribers of Netflix but is growing at a quick clip.Netflix shares fell 2.8%. Amazon shares edged down 0.2%.RELATED:Netflix Completes Global Rollout In One Fell SwoopWhy Fox Investors Shouldn't Ignore Netflix Peer Hulu.

Wall Street is overlooking the "unrecognized" value of assets like Hulu in 21st Century Fox's (FOXA) current stock price, according to Credit Suisse analyst Omar Sheikh, who raised Fox's price target to 38 from 34 on Wednesday. Like Netflix (NFLX), the online streaming service is a "must-have" for the modern digital consumer, he said."After years of investment, we believe investors have lost sight of the potential payback from Hulu and STAR India," he wrote. "We believe the two businesses can deliver meaningful profitability by 2020 ($1.5bn/$883m EBITDA respectively), and that visibility on this trajectory will become more apparent over the next 12 months." Fox-owned STAR India is a 51-channel broadcaster that operates online streamer Hotstar.Hulu, which is jointly owned by Fox, Walt Disney (DIS) and Comcast (CMCSA), gets far less attention than Netflix and Amazon (AMZN) Video, though the over-the-top (OTT) service is growing at a quick clip: Hulu said earlier in 2015 that it has 9 million subscribers, a 50% climb from the previous year. But that still pales in comparison to Netflix's 69.2 million member base.Credit Suisse estimates that Hulu has lost $1 billion cumulatively at a net income level since it first launched in 2008, a loss which in the past year has been driven by higher programming and marketing costs.But it is now in a "good position to grow strongly," said Sheikh. If Hulu can reach 37.5 million-42.5 million subscribers by 2020, it "could justify valuations in the $12bn-$18bn range, with $15bn at the mid-point." His analysis sees Hulu bringing in more than $1 billion in net income by that time.The online TV service — which streams currently airing programs from ABC, NBC, FOX and other channels, thanks to its traditional broadcast parentage — is seen as benefiting from its content offering, pricing and marketing strategy."In particular, we think the service should benefit from the addition of an ad-free option; the expansion into commissioning original series; and more circumspect content licensing activity by big media owners to rival SVOD (subscription video on demand) services, including Netflix," wrote Sheikh."Ultimately, we argue that Hulu will be a cornerstone OTT service for consumers — a 'must-have' digital subscription for cord-cutters and cord-nevers alongside Netflix and potentially (Time Warner (TWX)-owned) HBO NOW."Sheikh has an outperform rating on Fox.Fox shares closed up 0.5% in the stock market Wednesday. Walt Disney dipped 0.5%, and Comcast eased 0.8%.Netflix shares climbed 9.3% following an announcement at CES that it has entered another 130 countries.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.RELATED:Disney Slides As Pay-TV Concerns 'Won't Go Away'.

TV broadcasters and wireless phone companies are in store for a “spectrum extravaganza,” says FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler, but others question whether the upcoming government airwaves auction will live up that billing.The Federal Communications Commission plans to begin the “Broadcast Incentive Auction” on March 29. The auction, which could last as long as five months, will free up an estimated 60 megahertz to 80 MHz of prime, low-frequency radio spectrum owned by local TV broadcasters.Wireless firms and other companies can file as bidders from Tuesday through Feb. 9.TV broadcasters need to be persuaded to relinquish their airwaves. The FCC has set opening prices in hundreds of markets, but bidders likely will end up paying less, under the auction’s complex structure.The deadline for broadcasters to file as auction participants was Jan. 12; the FCC has not said how many local TV stations, out of roughly 2,000 eligible nationwide, filed.The National Association of Broadcasters says it expects “robust” participation by local TV broadcasters. The rub, points out William Bird, an analyst at FBR & Co., is that broadcasters could walk away at any point.“There is little risk to participating since broadcasters may drop out of the bidding in any round if they decide the prices are too low,” he said in a research report.Paul de Sa, an analyst at Bernstein Research, says it’s still unclear “how much spectrum will ultimately be auctioned.” Broadcasters have 120 MHz in all.In the wireless industry, AT&T (T)  and Verizon Communications (VZ) more than 70% of low-frequency airwaves in the top 100 U.S. markets. Low-frequency airwaves travel over long distances and also through walls, improving in-building services.The auction is an opportunity for smaller T-Mobile US (TMUS) to grab what Wheeler calls “beachfront spectrum.” Sprint (S) has said it will not bid, but parent SoftBank might, some analysts say.Observers speculate cable TV leader Comcast (CMCSA) will bid for airwaves, most likely in local markets where it sells cable services, and perhaps an Internet giant such as Alphabet’s (GOOGL) Google.The last spectrum auction, AWS-3, ended in January 2015, and it raised $41 billion. The TV broadcast auction will have trouble matching that total, analysts say, unless dark horses such as Comcast emerge.“Without non-traditional bidders, the auction results are likely to disappoint broadcasters,” said a Moody's Investors Service research report.Analysts at Morgan Stanley, Citigroup, Jefferies and Deutsche Bank have estimated Comcast could spend $4 billion to $6 billion in the auction. On the other hand, Charter Communications (CHTR), which is seeking regulatory approval to buy Time Warner Cable (TWC) and Bright House Networks to become the No. 2 cable firm, is not likely to bid, analysts say.Both AT&T and Verizon have talked down their interest in the broadcast airwaves.

Verizon CFO Fran Shammo in October told analysts Verizon isn’t sure the TV broadcasters’ 600 MHz spectrum is a good fit with Verizon’s 700 MHz footprint because of potential interference issues.John Donovan, AT&T’s senior executive of technology, at a Citigroup conference in January said the low-band, 600 MHz spectrum might be better suited for rural areas than urban markets.These comments might just be pre-auction posturing, some analysts say. Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan estimates both AT&T and Verizon could spend at least $10 billion in the auction.The FCC, meanwhile, plans to set aside a large chunk of spectrum that AT&T and Verizon cannot bid for, a policy the agency says is aimed at fostering competition.Some 30 MHz of spectrum would be set aside for smaller carriers, if at least 70 MHz is put up for bid overall.The FCC’s Wheeler expects lots of action. At the consumer electronics show, CES, in early January, he said, “I think it is safe to say that you are going to see a spectrum extravaganza — that you are going to see lots of interest in selling the spectrum and lots of interest in buying the spectrum, and that is going to be transformational.”There’s disagreement over when the sold spectrum would be available for wireless firms. AT&T says not until 2020. T-Mobile says as soon as 2018 in many cases, because local TV stations will want to get paid.T-Mobile says it could spend up to $10 billion in the auction.The exact number of frequency blocks and licenses to be auctioned will not be set until broadcasters state their intentions. The FCC plans to take a patchwork of vacant TV channels in local markets and create tighter blocks of spectrum for wireless firms to use — a process called “repacking.”While local TV stations have the option of vacating all their airwaves and thus going off the air, most are expected to move to a new frequency band or share spectrum. Opening prices are meant to persuade TV stations to part with airwaves. Telemundo’s UHF station in the New York City market has the highest opening price, at more than $900 million.Barclays analyst Kannan Venkateshwar, in a report, forecasts that more airwaves will come from independent TV stations rather than local stations owned and operated by the four major broadcasters — Walt Disney’s (DIS) ABC, CBS, Fox and NBC.Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA) and CBS (CBS) are expected to sell airwaves in some markets. While Comcast’s cable company is a potential bidder, it also owns media firm NBCUniversal, a potential seller of airwaves.

Smaller local TV station owners include Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) and Gray Television (GTNA).“On the supply side, we foresee potential robust participation from the major broadcasters, excluding ABC,” Credit Suisse analyst Omar Sheikh wrote in a recent research note. “Sinclair, Media General (MEG) and Tribune Media have clearly vocalized their interest in the auction.“Nexstar (NXST), E.W. Scripps, and Entravision (EVC) have been less vocal on their strategy, and Meredith has stated it doesn’t believe a material opportunity exists for its footprint.”While other wireless carriers were little changed in the stock market Monday, Sprint plunged 12.2% to 2.52, ahead of its Tuesday-morning earnings report. The company has axed at least 2,500 jobs in customer care centers and at its headquarters since last fall, the Associated Press said in a Monday-afternoon report. Last week Sprint notified employees at six customer service centers around the country that it would be closing those locations or reducing the staff there, AP reported.

Viacom's programming contract renewal with Dish Network (DISH) looms as a major event not only for the content provider and satellite TV broadcaster but also for other pay TV and media companies, says Pacific Crest Securities in a report. Investors have been down on both stocks. Shares in Dish Network fell 22% in 2015 while Viacom's  (VIA) stock plunged…

The jobs report pushed stocks toward fresh all-time highs in a busy week. Tesla Motors (TSLA) announced a deal to buy SolarCity (SCTY) as tech M&A was strong. General Motors (GM) and Ford (F) fueled a sell-off in consumer-related stocks, while oil prices briefly undercut $40 a barrel. Also, the Bank of England cut rates and revived bond buying.The major averages were little changed through Thursday, but rallied Friday on the strong jobs report. The Nasdaq climbed 1.1% for the week for a record close Friday and just 10 points below its July 2015 intraday peak. The S&P 500 rose 0.4%, hitting a fresh intraday best. The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 0.6%. Energy stocks fell as oil undercut $40 early in the week, but rallied as crude recovered somewhat.The U.S. economy added 255,000 jobs in July, the second straight month of much-better-than-expected hiring, allaying fears about the economy. ISM's manufacturing index and nonmanufacturing index fell a little more than forecast, but still pointed to growth. Strong hiring and wage gains should support consumer spending and housing demand, despite many consumer-related firms reporting stalling demand.Tesla took a step closer toward acquiring SolarCity for $2.6 billion as a special committee of "independent and disinterested" SolarCity board members evaluated the proposal and alternatives, stating its approval of the merger. The deal still needs to be approved by shareholders and regulators.Tesla reported Q2 earnings that missed estimates but showed improvements in electric-car production. Its production is on track to support about 50,000 deliveries in the second half of 2016, which reaffirmed previous guidance.The electric-car company's losses ballooned to $1.06 a share from 48 cents in the year-earlier figure, much greater than the 52-cent loss estimate. Tesla reported non-GAAP revenue of $1.56 billion, up 33% but missing the consensus of $1.62 billion.Tesla fell 2% for the week, while SolarCity lost more than 7%.Ride-hailing giant Uber Technologies is selling its Chinese operations to Apple (AAPL)-backed rival Didi Chuxing Technologies, capitulating on an expensive battle for a foothold in China. The deal has Uber swapping its Chinese business for a 20% stake in Didi, making the former foe the largest stakeholder in Didi. In turn, Didi will become the de facto ride-hailing leader in China, valued at more than $35 billion. Uber's most recent valuations put it north of $68 billion.Verizon Communications (VZ) agreed to buy Fleetmatics (FLTX), a vehicle tracking system maker, for $2.4 billion, or $60 per share. The acquisition expands Verizon' push into web-connected vehicles, part of the Internet of Things. Ireland-based Fleetmatics' mobile-software platform lets businesses manage commercial fleets by providing data on vehicle location, fuel usage, speed and mileage.Verizon fell 3.2% for the week, dropping below a buy point and its 50-day moving average. Fleetmatics jumped 38.5% to 59.50.Time Warner (TWX) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) both turned in mixed results, but Time Warner's move to buy a 10% stake in Netflix (NFLX) rival Hulu – joining current co-owners Walt Disney (DIS), Fox and Comcast (CMCSA) -- stole headlines. Viacom (VIAB) reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue, as did Lions Gate (LGF), which posted a surprise Q1 profit.U.S. oil prices fell below $40 per barrel early in the week, following July's 14% tumble, as OPEC production climbed on strong output from Nigeria and Iraq. Saudi Arabia continued to pump out oil near record highs. U.S. crude stockpiles rose in the latest week, according to the Energy Information Administration, but U.S. production dipped and gasoline supplies fell. Shale producers Continental Resources (CLR), Oasis Petroleum (OAS), and Laredo Petroleum (LPI) all lifted their output forecasts. Oil closed the week higher, at $41.80.Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) plunged 16% Friday after its cancer drug Opdivo ended a string of clinical-trial successes with its failure in a trial as a single therapy of newly diagnosed lung-cancer patients. Merck (MRK) had succeeded with a similar patient group in a trial of its competing drug Keytruda, though it was aiming at a smaller potential market. Merck stock jumped 10.4%, hitting its highest level since June 2001.Earlier, Merck was reported to be talking with Biogen (BIIB) about a possible Biogen buyout, as was Allergan (AGN). This further boosted Biogen's stock a day after its partner Ionis Pharmaceuticals (IONS) announced the unexpected success of a clinical trial of nusinersen, a treatment for a rare spinal disease with blockbuster potential. Biogen rose nearly 9% for the week.Meanwhile specialty drugmakers Mallinckrodt (MNK) and Shire (SHPG) rose 19% and 3.5%, respectively, after they beat estimates and raised guidance, while Pfizer (PFE), Novo Nordisk (NVO) and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) slipped after they beat Q2 numbers but issued so-so guidance. Animal-health company Zoetis (ZTS) also rose after beating and raising.General Motors (GM) and Ford (F) led auto stocks lower after reporting slower U.S. sales for the month of July, with Ford projecting U.S. industry sales to fall in 2016 and 2017 after years of big gains. Department stores, grocery stores, restaurants and airlines also declined, but recovered somewhat by week's end.The sell-off among consumer stocks triggers a warning for the broader U.S. economy amid falling business investment and homebuilder spending. Consumer spending rose at a strong 4.2% annual rate in Q2, but if that falters, the economy may not be able to match its anemic Q2 GDP growth of 1.2%.Texas Roadhouse (TXRH) beat Q2 earnings estimates, with EPS up 57% to 47 cents, but revenue growth of 12% to $508.8 million missed views. The steakhouse chain also said early Q3 same-restaurant sales growth had slowed from Q2.The outlook comes amid growing worries about the restaurant sector overall. Starbucks (SBUX) and McDonald's both recently reported weak U.S. comps amid warnings from analysts about the retail sector.But pizza delivery chains including Papa John's (PZZA) are bucking the trend. Papa John's said EPS jumped 30% to 61 cents to top views, and raised guidance for the rest of the year. Also, chicken-themed El Pollo Loco (LOCO) and Wingstop (WING) rallied on their results, while Jack In The Box (JACK) soared on its earnings.Separately, Monster Beverage (MNST) reported weaker-than-expected earnings growth, but topped on revenue forecasts. Monster Beverage, a Leaderboard stock, rallied Friday, hitting a new high.IBD'S TAKE: Investors should look for growth stocks clearing proper buy points. IBD Leaderboard is a premium service that provides detailed chart analysis of leading stocks. See what other top-rated growth names are at or near buy points.The Bank of England cut interest rates by a quarter-point to 0.25%, as expected, as the U.K. economy slows in reaction to the Brexit vote. But policymakers went further, reviving government bond purchases and announcing that the BOE would buy corporate debt. They also signaled that a rate cut to near-zero is likely by year-end, but BOE Gov. Mark Carney said he's opposed to negative rates and "helicopter" money.Martin Marietta Materials (MLM), which makes crushed stone, sand and other aggregates used in construction, fell short of second-quarter forecasts. Rival aggregates supplier Vulcan Materials (VMC) also badly missed. In the related ready-mix concrete market, U.S. Concrete (USCR) reported that Q2 EPS plunged 59% to 54 cents, missing by 41 cents. Revenue rose 12.7% but also missed. All three blamed bad weather and said they expect better results in the second half.
