"Comcast ($192 billion valuation) and Netflix ($42 billion) are the most logical candidates for an arranged marriage. While it stands to reason that the larger company will swallow the smaller one, it's not inconceivable that the reverse will happen — not unlike AOL's acquisition of Time Warner 15 years ago, but perhaps with better results."Apple Buys A Movie StudioVariety magazine's writers and editors are predicting a lot of M&A activity in Hollywood in 2016. Most notably, they think Apple will buy a movie studio to support its goals for a subscription Internet video service."With more than $200 billion in cash on hand, the Cupertino colossus is poised to rewrite the rules of the media game," the Variety staff wrote. "Viacom (VIAB) or HBO might seem the likeliest prey, but Sony (SNE) is a juicier target, given the mix of hardware and programming under its hood."Variety thinks Chinese Internet giant Alibaba Group (BABA) also is interested in buying a Hollywood player. Possible targets for Alibaba include Viacom, CBS (CBS), Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF) and DreamWorks Animation.However, John Malone is most likely to snap up Lions Gate and merge it with cable channel Starz (STRZA), Variety said.Time Warner (TWX), parent of HBO and Warner Bros., could become an M&A target in 2016, Variety said. One likely bidder would be 21st Century Fox (FOXA), the trade paper said.Intel Or Qualcomm Buys InvenSenseU.K.-based research firm CCS Insight makes a lot of annual tech industry predictions, including some about mergers and acquisitions.It predicts that Intel (INTC) or Qualcomm (QCOM) will acquire InvenSense (INVN) in 2016."The acquisition follows a large fall in the market capitalization of InvenSense in the second half of 2015," CCS Insight said in a report. "Its purchaser recognizes the opportunity to snap up InvenSense's assets in sensor technology. As sensors take on greater importance in the Internet of Things and wearable devices, the buyer integrates InvenSense's technology into a wider range of semiconductors."CCS Insight also predicts that Samsung will acquire chipmaker GlobalFoundries by 2017."GlobalFoundries is currently struggling to compete against Intel, Samsung and TSMC (TSM)," it said. "Chip manufacturing becomes increasingly capital- and scale-intensive, with huge pressure on capacity as demand balloons for silicon for the Internet of Things. Samsung's foundry business accounts for a growing proportion of the company's profit, and the acquisition helps cement Samsung's position in this area."Dish Network Gets MarriedDish Network (DISH) will merge with someone in 2016, says Phillip Swann, president of TVPredictions.com."The nation's second-largest satellite TV service needs help to stay competitive, and that assistance can only come from a merger," Swann wrote. Possible merger partners include T-Mobile (TMUS), Verizon, Amazon.com (AMZN) and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google."Out of full disclosure, I have predicted in the past that Dish will merge with someone, and it hasn't happened yet," Swann said. "But this time, well, this time I really think it will happen."RELATED:Apple 2016 Predictions: Acquisitions, Accessories.Cloud, Virtual Reality Among Top Tech Trends For 2016.

Walt Disney (DIS) and Alibaba (BABA) have struck a multiyear licensing deal to bring non-cable, over-the-top streaming service DisneyLife to China, as the Mouse House bolsters its defenses against online entertainment outlets like Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN) Prime.

The DisneyLife Mickey Mouse-themed streaming device, which includes a year-long DisneyLife base package, is available on Alibaba's Tmall.com for about $125. The family-oriented programming includes movies such as "Cinderella" and "Frozen," as well as e-books, TV shows and music. As part of synergistic cross-promotion, DisneyLife users also can learn about Disney and Alibaba products, plus Hong Kong Disneyland and the yet-to-be-opened Shanghai Disney Resort.

The move comes as TV viewers increasingly give up traditional cable bundles in favor of streaming services from Netflix, Amazon and Hulu. (Hulu is jointly owned by Disney, Comcast (CMCSA) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) .) Late last month, Disney disclosed that money-making cable channel ESPN had lost 7 million subscribers in two years.
The media conglomerate rolled out DisneyLife in the U.K. in November and plans to debut the streaming service in France, Spain, Italy and Germany in 2016.

Meanwhile, with its updated estimates, Goldman Sachs analyst Drew Borst predicts that the highly anticipated "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" will become the third-highest grossing film of all time, a spot currently held by an entry from earlier this year, "Jurassic World," which made $1.67 billion for Comcast's Universal Studios unit.

The firm lifted its price target on Disney to 112 from 110 and boosted its global box-office estimate for the seventh "Star Wars" movie installment to $1.95 billion, up from $1.5 billion. "Avatar" and "Titanic" currently hold the top two spots, with $2.8 billion and $2.2 billion, respectively.
Goldman Sachs also projects $6 billion in "Star Wars" consumer product sales in fiscal 2016, "double the sales when Disney acquired Lucas in 2012."
Walt Disney shares closed up 2.6% in the stock market today, closing above the 200-day line but failing to end above the 50-day average. Alibaba finished up 2.4%.
RELATED:
Disney's 'Bad Dinosaur': ESPN Loses 7 Mil Subscribers
New 'Star Wars' Movie Could Aid Imax Global Expansion
Disney May Make 'Different Decisions' About Netflix

Netflix (NFLX) scored more Golden Globe nominations this year than any other TV network, snagging eight nominations for its original shows like "Orange is the New Black" and "Narcos."The Internet television network beat cable rival HBO, a unit of Time Warner (TWX), which earned seven nominations for shows like "Game of Thrones," "Veep" and "Silicon Valley." The nominations were announced Thursday by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, which will name the winners at a ceremony on Jan. 10.The Starz (STRZA) cable channel came in third among TV networks for nominations with seven for shows such as "Outlander" and "Blunt Talk."Online TV networks had a big showing overall in the Golden Globe nominations. Amazon.com's (AMZN) Prime Video tied for fourth with the FX cable channel, owned by 21st Century Fox (FOXA), with five nominations each. And Hulu scored its first nomination for its comedy series "Casual."Netflix's good showing in the Golden Globe nominations comes three months after its lackluster showing at the 67th Emmy Awards. It was nominated for 34 Emmy Awards this year and won a total of four, including just one award during the prime-time ceremony.Analysts say Netflix needs a steady string of hit TV shows to attract and retain subscribers. And winning awards for critically acclaimed series and movies is a great way to draw attention to the service.In October, entertainment [PAGE[news]] website Exstreamist did a study of shows by six major TV networks to see which does the best at green-lighting critically acclaimed original programs. It determined that Netflix does a pretty good job at picking original shows that get good reviews from critics, but it's still not as good at it as HBO.

If anyone at Walt Disney (DIS) had a bad feeling about its 2012 acquisition of Lucasfilm, this past weekend's record-breaking box office figures probably laser-blasted those concerns into a galaxy far, far away.

"Star Wars: Episode VII — The Force Awakens" reportedly raked in $248 million in the U.S. and Canada on opening weekend, bumping previous record holder "Jurassic World" down to the No. 2 spot on the charts.

Globally, the seventh installment of the sci-fi cinematic franchise made $529 million, also rendering the dinosaurs' worldwide record of $524.9 million extinct — a hefty feat considering the new "Star Wars" flick doesn't even premiere in China until Jan. 9.

Disney shares rose 1.5% in the premarket, but fell 1% in the stock market by Monday's close. Imax (IMAX) also boasted box office records for "Force Awakens," grossing $48 million worldwide. But Imax shares ended down 4.2%.
Han Solo and company premiered to overwhelmingly positive (and mostly spoiler-free) reviews, earning a 95% on the critic aggregation site Rotten Tomatoes.

In a departure from previous iterations, "The Force Awakens" prominently features a strong female lightsaber-wielding lead, Rey (played by British newcomer Daisy Ridley), in addition to familiar face Leia Organa (played by Carrie Fisher).
Men made up 63% of the audience on Friday, notes Stifel analyst Benjamin Mogil, but over the weekend the gender imbalance lessened to a 58-42 split.

"(W)ith strong reviews and a strong female lead, 42% of the Saturday/Sunday audience was female (a high figure for the genre)," he wrote, "and we view this expansion of the market place as likely granting the film a higher multiplier."
Mogil raised his estimates on Disney, citing the film's stronger-than-expected opening weekend numbers, and lifted his domestic box-office estimate to $800 million from $700 million.

Disney's $4 billion acquisition of Lucasfilm is likely looking like a good deal in light of the film's performance. Wall Street analysts predict that this movie alone will bring in about $1.5 billion-$2 billion worldwide, and Macquarie had earlier projected that "Star Wars" merchandise sales could produce $5 billion in revenue in the first year.

The media conglomerate has faced scrutiny in recent months, however, as ESPN registered subscriber losses and traditional TV viewers consider cutting the cord and moving over to services such as Netflix (NFLX), Amazon (AMZN) Prime or Hulu. (Disney co-owns Hulu with Comcast (CMCSA) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA).)
Be that as it may, "The Force Awakens" is not Disney's only hope. There is... another. Two others, in fact. The next two episodes of the sequel trilogy are scheduled for 2017 and 2019.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.

Disney's 'Bad Dinosaur': ESPN Loses 7 Mil Subscribers

Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned video unit YouTube is seeking streaming rights to TV shows and movies in order to bolster its new subscription service, turning up the volume on its rivalry with Netflix (NFLX), Amazon.com (AMZN) and Hulu in the competitive online video market, according to a Wall Street Journal report.

Executives at YouTube — the world's largest online-video service — have met with Hollywood studios and other production companies in recent months to consider pitches and negotiate licenses for new content, according to the report. It said those efforts appear to be in early stages.

Netflix, Amazon and Hulu have been snapping up streaming rights for years, but YouTube wants to secure premium videos to stoke its recently launched ad-free video and streaming music service, the report said.

"YouTube is dominant in ad-supported online video, but they have missed the subscription side," Mark Terbeek, a partner at tech- and media-focused venture capital firm Greycroft Partners, was quoted as saying in the report. "To get people to pay, they will have to have higher-end content."
Terbeek, though, called YouTube "a legitimate threat" to Netflix, Amazon and Hulu.

Global revenue from online TV and video services will reach $51.1 billion in 2020, up from $26 billion this year, according to estimates from market tracker Digital TV Research. Revenue from subscription-based streaming-video services will surpass revenue from ad-supported services by 2020, it said.

This year, Hulu — jointly owned by Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Comcast (CMCSA) — is expected to double its spending on content to $1.5 billion, putting it roughly on par with Amazon.
Netflix, though, is expected to boost its content spending nearly 18% to $3.3 billion, according to RBC Capital Markets analyst David Bank, quoted in the news report.
Last month, Google launched its much-anticipated YouTube Music app in the U.S., for both the Apple (AAPL) iOS and Google Android operating systems.

The streaming music service and app aims to use YouTube's massive music video collection to go up against Internet streaming music offerings including Apple Music — which Apple launched in June — and Spotify.
YouTube Music is part of YouTube Red, the no-ad $9.99 per month subscription service the company started in October.

Expectations for "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" are of galactic proportions, with projections for over $2 billion in global box office sales. And that hype is already making history. Fandango told Variety the movie from Walt Disney (DIS) set a new record, with over $50 million in pre-sales ahead of the Dec. 18 debut. The latest installment of the Star…

There's a lot of hype surrounding Disney 's  (DIS) Dec. 18 premiere of "Star Wars: The Force Awakens." But is there too much hype? Barclays seems to think so, saying that investors who are putting a lot of focus on the performance of the upcoming movie are likely to be disappointed if it doesn't meet expectations. The analyst also…

The new Star Wars movie could be a force that lifts a lot of companies this holiday season: cinemas, toy makers, video game publishers ... and big-screen theater firm Imax (IMAX).Rosenblatt Securities analyst Martin Pyykkonen on Monday reiterated his buy rating on Imax stock, based in part on the impact of Walt Disney's (DIS) "Star Wars: The Force Awakens," which opens Dec. 18."The advanced domestic ticket sales for Disney's 'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' are already setting new records (about $50 million) nearly a month before its opening weekend, and Imax is over-indexing so far, with about one-third of those advance tickets sales domestically," he said in a research note.The Imax percentage of advance ticket sales for the movie likely will decline as the release date approaches, due to Imax screen capacity, Pyykkonen said."The highly anticipated new 'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' film could be a new catalyst for another foreign screen growth cycle beyond the current global (total addressable market that) Imax is projecting," he said.Pyykkonen noted that another blockbuster film, 21st Century Fox's (FOXA) "Avatar," released five years ago, was a key catalyst to kick-starting Imax screen growth in China. The new Star Wars flick could have a similar effect, he said."Our key focus continues to be on Imax's long-term foreign screen growth outlook," Pyykkonen said. "We estimate that even by the end of 2016, the Imax foreign screen base will still only be about 35% of the total addressable market (TAM) across foreign regions. Imax's global TAM estimate is 2,450 total global screens (1,000 in Greater China)."Pyykkonen has a price target of 47 on Imax stock. Imax was down a fraction, near 38, in afternoon trading on the stock market today.Other companies benefiting from Star Wars mania include Electronic Arts (EA), which released its video game "Star Wars Battlefront" on Nov. 17; and toy licensees like Hasbro (HAS) and Lego Group.RELATED:EA's New 'Star Wars' Game Gets 'Disappointing' ReviewsCan Stores Keep Pace With 'Star Wars' Toy Demand?'Star Wars' To Help 3D Cinema Leap Into Hyperspace.

When it comes to the television and movie streaming service Hulu, one question abounds: When will this once-promising cutting-edge beacon of media and technological innovation make some serious money?
Today, Hulu faces an uncertain future. Like many other innovations that once signaled a new technology-media industry direction, Hulu's stranglehold has been weakened by ambitious competitors.

The video-streaming company's quagmire is similar to any number of entities whose arrival seemed to signal a shining new way of presenting content to consumers, who didn't want to be tied any longer to the constrictions of their network and cable television schedules.

Hulu was trying to sell a stake to Time Warner (TWX) as a part of a transaction that would value Hulu at more than $5 billion "and advance its effort to compete with Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon.com (AMZN)," the Wall Street Journal reported in November, citing sources familiar with the matter. According to the Journal, the rival companies had been discussing the prospect of Time Warner becoming an equal stakeholder in Hulu, along with its current joint-venture owners Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Comcast (CMCSA) .
That these partners are reportedly pondering the addition of media behemoth Time Warner may be telling in its own right.

"Hulu's exploration of a deal with Time Warner makes little or no sense and will dilute Fox, Disney and Comcast down from 33% to 25%, not a sign of confidence on the part of Hulu's owners," noted Porter Bibb, an analyst at Mediatech Capital Partners.

Does Hulu need yet another media industry powerhouse behind it, potentially making it difficult for these partners to achieve a consensus? Most successful enterprises have a single visionary — not several — calling the shots.

"Hulu's owners, in fact, are probably better off putting their own content OTT ('over the top,' or delivered via the Internet), but they all consider Hulu a learning experience and a foot in the door of the New Paradigm for content distribution," Bibb said. "It is something of a miracle that the founders could ever agree on anything, but Hulu is trying their patience and is not likely to have a long future."
Black Box Of Profitability
The issue of Hulu and making money remains a concern.

"Hulu's profitability will only come at the expense of its media owners' own profits and strategic interests," said Chunka Mui, a partner at The Devil's Advocate, a media and technology consulting firm.
"Those owners need to craft meaningful strategies against the cord cutters who are fleeing to Amazon, Netflix, etc.," Mui said.

With its complicated structure, Hulu has tantalized and frustrated Hollywood and the media industry for several years. The powers that be watched as Hulu lost much of its buzz, thanks to crafty competitors such as Netflix and Amazon.

Most recently, Amazon on Tuesday said its customers can now add Showtime and other video subscriptions into their Prime memberships, with CBS (CBS)-owned Showtime at $8.99 a month. That follows up the same-price Showtime deal that Hulu launched in July.
As Hulu and its creators have found out the hard way, a buzz can vanish like a cloud as rivals spring up and offer variations on what once seemed to be an original idea.
"Hulu may be generating a small profit," Bibb said. But only because it benefits from low cost of content, when its owners "could get significantly more from Netflix, Amazon or even YouTube."

The business model for Hulu "is based around access to mainly television content supplied (or) sold by NBC, Fox and ABC and is, in my opinion, not sustainable despite having launched a pay tier on top of its basic, free programming," he said.

Hulu's innovation in TV and movie streaming has failed to keep a solid loyal audience. Its image as a library underscores how it may be out of step in popular culture. Netflix and Amazon have scored big by offering culturally daring programming, such as "House of Cards" and "Orange Is the New Black" for Netflix and "Transparent" by Amazon.

"Netflix got out of the gate in 2013 with with much-talked-about original programming, and Amazon has followed suit with 'Transparent' — and Amazon has also even signed on Woody Allen to create a series," said Robert Thompson, a television-studies professor at Syracuse University. "These kinds of original productions, which can get a major buzz in a very short time period, count for a lot more with the public today than having a reputation as a TV library — like Hulu has."

Hulu started with such promise, with its allure of a U.S. online entity, a partly advertising-supported streaming operation providing various television shows, clips, movies and additional streaming media. It counted on appealing to subscribers wanting to search for content in a visually attractive, high-definition format from Walt Disney's ABC, the CW, 21st Century Fox and Comcast's NBC on the day after air.
Free TV Limits Viewing

Hulu makes its online service available on personal computers and laptops. It offers a free service, but just on subscribers' personal computers and laptops. People who pay a monthly charge can access the more extensive Hulu Plus service — available not only on computers and laptops, but also on Internet-connected game consoles, set-top boxes, smart phones, tablets, TVs and other equipment.
"With HBO now gaining traction OTT, the future for Hulu gets cloudier everyday," Bibb said.

Media conglomerate Viacom (VIAB) failed to beat fiscal fourth-quarter consensus views as Paramount Pictures didn't deliver any big-screen hits and domestic ad revenue slid as its youth-oriented channels face competition from Netflix (NFLX) and other streaming options.
But shares rallied as management expects ratings improvement and chief Philippe Dauman promised that its film studio "will come back and come back strongly," according to Variety.

Adjusted diluted per-share earnings in the September-ended quarter fell 10% to $1.54 as revenue dipped 5% to $3.79 billion. Both results missed analyst views for $1.55 a share on $3.88 billion in revenue.

Viacom's media networks division revenue grew 5% on affiliate fee and international ad revenue growth. The Nickelodeon and Comedy Central parent said U.S. advertising revenue slid 7% on a tumble in traditional television ratings, but that was a narrower decline than some analysts had expected.
Dauman said that ratings have improved recently and that Viacom had secured renewals of important distribution agreements.

The company's stable of media properties includes a number of youth-oriented channels, including MTV, VH1, Spike, Nick. Jr. and others. Traditional broadcasters have been competing fiercely for younger viewers as they contend with offerings from YouTube (owned by Alphabet (GOOGL) unit Google), Netflix, Amazon (AMZN) Prime Video and the rest of the cybersphere.

Filmed entertainment division revenue tumbled 24% on a tough year-over-year comparison with Q4 2014's release of "Transformers: Age of Extinction" and no stand-out theatrical releases during the quarter. Within the segment, movie revenue fell 20% and home entertainment revenue plunged 54%, said the company, which owns Paramount Pictures.
For the September-ended quarter, Viacom repurchased 21.1 million shares under its buyback program.

Shares tumbled on Nov. 4 amid a greater media stock backslide after Time Warner (TWX) issued light 2016 earnings guidance and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) revenue fell shorts of Street estimates. In August, Walt Disney (DIS) and other media stocks were torched amid concerns over affiliate fee revenue growth and viewers dropping pay-TV bundles in favor of Netflix and Amazon subscriptions.
Viacom's B shares rose to 51.67, but close up 0.9% to 49.79 on the stock market today. That's still below where they were before the Time Warner warning and 21st Century results.

Management said during the post-earnings call that they expect an improvement in ratings and pricing opportunities from cutting back on primetime ad loads, according to Reuters. By upfronts of next year, it also expects 33 major advertisers to have signed up for its Vantage service, which essentially pairs advertisers with suitable programs.
21st Century Fox closed flat while Time Warner shares fell 0.9% and Walt Disney 0.3%.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.

Facebook (FB) on Wednesday released its news app Notify for Apple iPhone users in the U.S., deepening the social network giant's relationship with media giants such as Fox News (21st Century Fox (FOXA), CNN (Time Warner (TWX), Bloomberg, The New York Times (NYT) and Buzzfeed. That comes even amid reports that Facebook is revising advertising on its Instant Articles platform…

Discovery Communications (DISCA) is said to be launching its own streaming app, Discovery Go, as it vies to compete with the increasingly crowded field of online-video offerings from traditional media networks like Walt Disney (DIS) and pure-play streamers like Netflix (NFLX). Nine of its networks — including Discovery Channel, TLC, Animal Planet and others — will be available to authenticated…

Charter Communications'  (CHTR) $55 billion acquisition of Time Warner Cable, announced on Tuesday, will reward TWC shareholders with a nearly 50% premium over what Charter offered to pay for the company in January 2014, and more than 20% over what Comcast had agreed to pay in its doomed acquisition bid. Charter early Tuesday announced it had agreed to pay…

Not only are young adults more likely to "cut the cord" and give up pay-TV services, they're also more likely to switch among providers of Internet video streaming services, says a BMO Capital Markets report.The report cites data from TV ratings provider Nielsen.Young adults, oft-called called millennials, have been big users of Netflix (NFLX), Amazon.com 's (AMZN) video service, and Hulu. Dish Network (DISH) and Sony early in 2015 launched over-the-top (OTT) services — so called because they piggyback landline broadband services sold by other companies. Even if consumers don't buy a traditional pay-TV package, they still need broadband Internet to stream video.Apple (AAPL) is widely expected to launch a new Web TV service. Apple's entry could spur some subscription video-on-demand (SVOD) users to switch, a trend already underway, says Daniel Salmon, a BMO Capital Markets analyst, in his research report."SVOD households generally churn at a higher rate than multi-channel video programming distributor (cable TV) households," Salmon said. "We expect this is in part due to SVOD services' generally non-restrictive cancellation policies."For example, over a three-month period, Nielsen generally finds that 99% of the households in the sample who had cable still have cable. However, 5-7% of people who had SVOD won't have it three months from now."According to Nielsen data, 10% of persons aged 18-34 use only OTT services when they turn on a TV. SVOD users tend to watch less television overall.Among U.S. households, 41% now subscribe to a video streaming service, up from 36% a year earlier, said a Nielsen study released this year. Netflix by far is the most popular streaming video service, with Amazon No.2. Netflix stock recently got a boost when the company announced a 7-for-1 stock split.Another rival is Hulu — owned by 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Walt Disney (DIS) and Comcast (CMCSA). It offers a free option with ads, as well as a paid service.
Dish Network (DISH) early Monday said it had a net loss of 134,000 subscribers in Q1, but earnings beat analyst views as contract disputes with content providers shaved programming costs.
Dish said it earned 76 cents per share in Q1 as revenue rose 3.6% to $3.72 billion, missing estimates. Analysts had modeled EPS of 40 cents and revenue of $3.74 billion.
While programming interruptions might have angered customers, Dish spent less on content than expected. Dish's contract dispute with 21st Century Fox (FOXA) ended in mid-January.
Dish Network edged down a fraction in early trading in the stock market today, near 67.
Net income nearly doubled to $351 million from $176 million in the year-earlier period, the company said.

Dish had added 40,000 video customers in Q1 2014. Dish had 13.84 million pay-TV customers as of March 31, down slightly from a year earlier. On Tuesday, DirecTV (DTV) reported a net add of 60,000 U.S. subscribers in Q1, up from 12,000 additions in the year-earlier period.
Dish said average revenue per monthly pay-TV subscriber edged up in Q1 to $86 from $82.36 in Q1 2014.

In its earnings release, Dish did not disclose the number of Sling TV online customers it signed up in the period. Dish Network launched its Sling TV Internet video service in January, and Sony (SNE) also started an OTT video service last quarter. Apple (AAPL) reportedly is ramping up a service of its own.

Dish Network stock weakened after the satellite TV broadcaster reported Q1 earnings results. Some analysts question CEO Charlie Ergen's strategy of amassing radio spectrum with no apparent buyers of those airwaves, or a strategic wireless partner, in sight.
Federal regulators are probing Dish Network's tactics in a recent U.S. radio spectrum auction, including $3 billion in discounts won by using bidding partners.

"The now-settled carriage dispute with Fox continued to impact Dish operating performance into the first quarter, pressuring subscriber trends, but boosted EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) on lower costs," Jefferies analyst Mike McCormack said in a research report. "We believe today's results are unlikely to shift investor focus away from the AWS-3 regulatory process, the ultimate outcome of DISH's spectrum, and M&A potential in the space."Dish Network (DISH) early Monday said it had a net loss of 134,000 subscribers in Q1, but earnings beat analyst views as contract disputes with content providers shaved programming costs.Dish said it earned 76 cents per share in Q1 as revenue rose 3.6% to $3.72 billion, missing estimates. Dish's contract dispute with 21st Century Fox (FOXA) ended in mid-January.Dish Network edged down a fraction in early trading in the stock market today, near 67.Net income nearly doubled to $351 million from $176 million in the year-earlier period, the company said.Dish had added 40,000 video customers in Q1 2014. Dish had 13.84 million pay-TV customers as of March 31, down slightly from a year earlier. On Tuesday, DirecTV (DTV) reported a net add of 60,000 U.S. subscribers in Q1, up from 12,000 additions in the year-earlier period.Dish said average revenue per monthly pay-TV subscriber edged up in Q1 to $86 from $82.36 in Q1 2014.In its earnings release, Dish did not disclose the number of Sling TV online customers it signed up in the period. An Apple (AAPL) TV service will likely feature dynamic ad insertion technology based on viewing data that provides upside for media and entertainment companies that partner with Apple, speculates Pacific Crest Securities in a research report.

Satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH) and Sony (SNE) this year launched new OTT (over-the-top) Internet video services. The services are dubbed OTT products because they piggyback landline broadband services sold by other companies.
Apple has been widely expected to join them this year or next. Pacific Crest says this year.
Companies are racing to acquire ad technology as consumer viewing habits shift to mobile and on-demand platforms.

Verizon Communications (VZ) agreed to buy AOL (AOL) on Tuesday for $4.4 billion. The acquisition will give Verizon key advertising technology as well as content to offer on its mobile video platform, analysts said.

Pacific Crest analyst Andy Hargreaves does not expect Apple to sell new consumer hardware as part of the TV service launch. Nor does Hargreaves expect a significant EPS lift for Apple from a TV service, at least not in the near term.
Hargreaves says media firms that would get a boost from Apple paying higher programming fees include Time Warner Cable (TWC), Walt Disney (DIS), CBS (CBS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA).
He called an Apple TV service "disruptive" to the pay-TV ecosystems of Comcast (CMCSA), Charter Communications (CHTR) and other cable TV firms.

"We expect Apple to provide detailed viewing data directly to (cable) network owners ... in addition to collecting data, Apple's service should be able to provide dynamic ad inventory in content that is live, served on-demand, or recorded by the consumer," he wrote. "At the moment, network owners do not get paid for advertising that is recorded and watched outside of the Nielsen-rated three- or seven-day windows. An Apple service should be able to serve ads based on the viewer, content and time of viewing regardless of whether the viewing is done live.

"We expect the service to be a medium-sized bundle of traditional linear networks with significant stacking rights and a heavy emphasis on on-demand viewing, likely with a base price around $40 or $50 per month. We believe Apple will market based on a superior consumer experience, which, if executed well, is likely to be much more disruptive than a 'skinny bundle' (with fewer channels)."

For the first time ever, the U.S. pay-television industry lost customers in the traditionally strong first-quarter, highlighting the difficulties subscription-based TV providers face amid an Internet onslaught from Netflix (NFLX), Dish Network's (DISH) Sling TV, Hulu and others, with Apple (AAPL) and others possible players down the road. Pay-TV lost a net 31,000 customers in Q1 and has an annual…

Timothy Parton has been at the helm of JPMorgan Mid Cap Growth Fund for a little more than 10 years. He has steered the $2.6 billion portfolio to a 9.11% average annual gain in that period, topping 81% of his midcap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc.For the rest of this year, as of his Sept. 30 commentary, he expects earnings growth to be harder to come by for S&P 500 companies.His team has cut earnings estimates for energy firms and regional banks.On the other hand, his team boosted estimates for autos, transportation and retail. He expects financials in general and health care to have the strongest earnings growth of all sectors for this year.Signature Bank (SBNY) looks like an exception to Parton's concerns about regional banks.On Monday afternoon the New York City metro area bank was trying to reclaim a 154.50 cup-with-handle entry point.The bank, which is on IBD's Leaderboard, serves mainly commercial and high-net-worth clients.As of Sept. 30, 721 mutual funds held the bank, up from 630 at the end of 2014.Car-parts retailer O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) is up 38% this year.The chain store has expanded from its traditional customer base of do-it-yourselfers to more professional repair shops.Earnings per share grew 20% and 25% the past two quarters.Its most recent report beat analysts' consensus expectations.Revving UpThe stock was a top contributor to the fund's recent performance.Since an intraday peak of 277.96 on Oct. 29, shares have pulled back. Closing Tuesday near267, they are still slightly north of their recent 258.25 buy point.The fund also owns strong names in other sectors.Veeva Systems (VEEV), which makes cloud-based sales and marketing software for life science companies, has IBD's Composite Rating of 95, strong on a scale of 1-99.The stock, trading around 27, is 18% below its 52-week high and working on a new consolidation with a potential 33.20 buy point.This month the company debuted a system for managing the contents and activities associated with activating websites for clinical trials. The new system aims to replace traditional approaches, which are typically slower and non-automated.ServiceNow (NOW) makes cloud-based software to help companies automate and streamline their processes.Jump In EarningsLast month the company reported third-quarter earnings per share of 15 cents, which were a 400% leap over the Q3 last year.That adjusted net income was nearly double what analysts had forecast.Revenue, which jumped 46%, was also above expectations.Also, Shebly Seyrafi, an analyst for FBN Securities, recently told IBD that the company's guidance on upcoming margins may be too cautious.Despite EPS declines in the past four quarters, Netflix 's (NFLX) share price is up 140% this year.Netflix is facing a possibly enhanced challenge to its Web video streaming service from Hulu.Hulu is much smaller than Netflix. But Hulu has deep-pocketed owners in Comcast (CMCSA), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Walt Disney (DIS).

Apple's (AAPL) rumored pay-TV service, consisting of a skinny bundle of cable and broadcast channels, isn't likely to appeal to many consumers, UBS analyst Doug Mitchelson said in a report Monday.Consumers like the idea of a less expensive pay-TV service, but not when it's missing some of the channels they want, Mitchelson said.Current skinny bundles are "unpopular because consumers have a surprisingly wide variety of channel bundles that they prefer," he said.Skinny bundles such as Dish Network's (DISH) Sling TV and Sony's (SNE) PlayStation Vue offer fewer channels for a lower price than regular pay-TV services.Meanwhile, over-the-top Internet television services like Amazon's (AMZN) Prime Video, Hulu and Netflix (NFLX) typically supplement linear TV services by providing a selection of on-demand TV shows and movies.UBS reached its conclusions based on data from a survey of 1,855 U.S. pay-TV households. Its study sought "to understand whether a la carte pay TV was viable (it is not), whether slimmed down bundles could prove to be popular (they are not) and the level of importance that each major media network group has to the bundle (all are quite important, including Viacom (VIAB), but some much more than others)," Mitchelson said.Apple has been in talks with media companies over the past year about launching an online pay-TV service with a bundle of channels that includes live and on-demand video, to be paired up with its Apple TV hardware, Mitchelson said. Those companies include CBS (CBS), Discovery Communications (DISCA), Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Time Warner (TWX). Apple has discussed offering a service costing $25 to $39.95 a month, he said.But media companies have been "unwilling to let Apple cherry pick channels from their line-up," Mitchelson said.Content companies currently have little incentive to break up traditional pay-TV bundles. Cord-cutting, or pay-TV subscribers canceling their service, has not posed a big enough threat for content companies to change their business models, Mitchelson said.Also, media companies are mandating "new entrant pricing," which is at a significant premium per customer than what the fully scaled traditional distributors have to pay, he said. "Offering a healthy selection of high quality channels at a low price quickly becomes impossible under the constraints demanded by the media companies," Mitchelson said.Apple isn't the only tech company actively pursuing Internet-delivered pay-TV bundles, he said. Amazon.com and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google also are in the hunt, Mitchelson said."In fact, Amazon and Google might beat Apple to market as Apple may be frustrated with the pricing and carriage demands of the media companies," Mitchelson said.UBS survey data indicate that Apple could be successful if it can pull together a compelling lineup of channels.Some 16% of U.S. pay-TV households surveyed indicated that they would consider signing up for an Apple TV service with 25 live TV channels (including CBS, ESPN and FX) costing $30 to $40 a month, Mitchelson said."Not surprisingly, interest in the Apple TV offer skewed toward younger households, higher income homes, larger households and families with children, as well as streamers being significantly more interested than non-streamers," he said. "Perhaps the most promising for media companies, among 18-34 year olds, 42% suggested they would definitely or probably subscribe to the Apple OTT service."When asked to put together a custom bundle of channels, most survey respondents came up with bundles that would cost more than their current setups.The average custom bundle cost would be $127, 20% higher than their existing package, Mitchelson said. Only 28% of those who designed custom packages thought it was a better value, he said.Pacific Crest Securities analyst Andy Hargreaves came to a similar conclusion — doubting Apple's prospects in the pay-TV realm — two weeks ago."Odds may be increasing that Apple has decided the opportunity is not worth the effort," Hargreaves said in a Nov. 16 report.Follow Patrick Seitz on Twitter @IBD_PSeitz and on Facebook.

The transaction would reportedly put a $5 billion-$6 billion valuation on Hulu, a video streaming service that has been ramping up…

Warner Bros. video games and HBO licensing revenue helped Time Warner (TWX) top Wall Street's third-quarter forecasts, but weak 2016 earnings guidance hit Time Warner shares — as well as those of 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Walt Disney (DIS), as audiences switch to Netflix (NFLX) and other streaming services.The HBO parent reaffirmed full-year adjusted profit guidance for $4.60-$4.70 per share, in line with current consensus views. But on the conference call, management guided 2016 earnings to $5.25 per share, well below analyst estimates for $5.60 a share and a significant slash from previous guidance for "close to $6" per share next year. The strong dollar is expected to weigh on earnings.Time Warner stock closed down 6.6% in the stock market on Wednesday. IBD's Media-Diversified industry group, ranked 101 out of 197, is down 1.6%.21st Century Fox, which reported another quarter of declining earnings on Wednesday, sank 5.2%. Walt Disney, which reports Thursday, retreated 2%.In Q3, Time Warner's adjusted diluted earnings grew 2% to $1.25 a share, easily topping analyst estimates for $1.09 a share, as revenue rose 5% to $6.56 billion vs. views for $6.51 billion.HBO revenue rose 5%, with the premium cable channel's higher domestic licensing revenue driving a 13% gain in content and other revenue. Higher domestic rates helped subscription revenue climb 4%.Subscriber revenue growth was "weaker than expected" but offset by better-than-expected content revenue growth, Stifel analyst Benjamin Mogil wrote Wednesday.Media stocks, including Walt Disney, took a beating in August following the previous quarter's string of results amid concerns over subscriber growth and cord-cutting. Viewers are increasingly turning to Netflix and Amazon (AMZN) Prime for entertainment. Netflix stock rose 3.9% during the regular session; Amazon advanced 2.5%.Time Warner's HBO dominated the Emmys in September with 43 wins, including 14 during the prime-time broadcast, besting every other network, including Netflix.The Q3 releases of games "LEGO Dimensions" and "Mad Max" boosted Warner Bros. revenue, which climbed 15% on higher video game and television licensing revenue. The TV results were helped by "2 Broke Girls" and "Person of Interest" licensing.Meanwhile, 21st Century Fox continued a streak of earnings and revenue declines, with a 3% year-over-year dip in per-share earnings to 38 cents, which topped Q1 views by a penny. Revenue fell 6% to $6.08 billion, short of estimates for $6.42 billion.Fox's cable networks segment delivered double-digit earnings gains on higher affiliate fees, ad revenues and lower expenses, CEO Rupert Murdoch said in a statement, but Q1 results also "reflect the expected impact of challenging comparisons for our film studio due to the timing of key releases, as well as the poor performance of 'The Fantastic Four.'"Television ad revenues fell 5% due to one less week of NFL broadcasts during the quarter, though the television segment benefited from lower programming expenses.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.RELATED:Netflix: Will Media Firms Hint At Tougher Deals?Will 'Three-Headed Monster' Haunt Media Firms?

In a research report reviewing media and entertainment company Q3 earnings, analyst Andy Hargreaves sees upside for Netflix (NFLX), despite management…

Can satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network reinvent itself like Netflix, the one-time DVD renter that became a streaming-video giant? Dish (DISH) founder and CEO Charlie Ergen was careful making comparisons on the satellite broadcaster's Q1 earnings conference call Monday, but Ergen said he expects Dish's fledgling Internet over-the-top video service Sling TV to one day provide significant revenue."We're excited about where it's going to go," he said. "I think it's going to be meaningful revenue."Dish Network, which lost 134,000 video subscribers in Q1, isn't ready to say how many customers have signed up for the $20 monthly Sling service, launched in January.Sony launched its own OTT service this year, while Verizon Communications (VZ) is ramping up a mobile video service.Apple (AAPL) could join the mix by 2016, some analysts say.Content providers HBO andCBS (CBS) have also launched Web-only services.The services are dubbed OTT because they piggyback landline broadband services sold by other companies. Even if consumers don't buy a traditional pay-TV package, they still need broadband Internet to stream video."The (early Sling) results are encouraging," Ergen said. "We're really encouraged with it. We don't think it's a flash in the pan."Netflix (NFLX), meanwhile, had 41.2 million U.S. streaming customers as of March 31 and only 5.6 million DVD-by-mail customers.Ergen concedes the conventional pay-TV market is mature. Dish had 13.84 million pay-TV customers at the end of Q1, down from 14.1 million a year earlier.Ergen says there are many technical and marketing challenges for Sling, which has suffered streaming setbacks during high-demand periods. Ergen says the economics of the streaming business are much different than broadcast TV."This (OTT) is not as dramatic as perhaps what Netflix went through, but it's somewhat similar in the sense that when Netflix went from a DVD business in the mail to being able to deliver something instantly through the Internet, they started focusing on that (streaming) side of the business. I'm not saying that's going to happen here, but I do think that things like Sling TV are going to become more and more prevalent."Ergen says that for the pay-TV industry, a generation of potential customers, millennials ages 18 to 34, are increasingly cancelling pay-TV service in favor of more affordable, on-demand content.Ergen expects pay-TV providers, including Dish, to continue adjusting the product bundles offered to consumers. Verizon recently sparked a fight with content firms, including Walt Disney's (DIS) ESPN, over plans to offer consumers a new "slim" TV package for its landline FiOS pay-TV service."Linear pay television business probably peaked a couple of years ago," Ergen said. "But it's not declining as fast as I would have thought it would."Ergen says pay-TV companies have gained some negotiating clout over content firms as consumers resist price hikes. Contract disputes with content providers contributed to Dish's Q1 subscriber losses as unhappy customers cancelled service. Dish's programming dispute with 21st Century Fox (FOXA) ended in mid-January.In Q1, Dish said it earned 76 cents per share as programming expenses and customer acquisition costs fell. Revenue rose 3.6% to $3.72 billion. Analysts had modeled EPS of 40 cents on sales of $3.74 billion.Average revenue per monthly pay-TV subscriber edged up 4% in Q1 to $86 from $82.36 in Q1 2014.Some analysts question Ergen's strategy of amassing radio spectrum with no apparent buyers of those airwaves — or a strategic wireless partner — in sight.In a recent airwaves auction, Dish achieved its main goal: securing licenses in major markets in order to pressure wireless firms such as Verizon or T-Mobile to negotiate, some analysts say.Ergen said T-Mobile remains a potential partner."We're keeping all our options open, and we admire what (CEO John Legere) and his team have done with T-Mobile," Ergen said.

CBS' (CBS) potential revenue from the launch of a Web-only version of Showtime and an online video deal with Hulu highlighted the TV network's Q1 earnings conference call, as its relatively flat Q1 results beat estimates.
CBS late Thursday said Q1 profit rose a penny to 78 cents while revenue fell 2% from the year-earlier quarter to $3.5 billion. Analysts had modeled sales of $3.44 billion and EPS of 75 cents.
CBS stock, though, was down 1.5% in early afternoon trading in the stock market today. Media stocks 21st Century Fox Entertainment Fox (FOXA) and Walt Disney (DIS) were flat.
IBD's Media-Diversified group ranks No. 30 out of 197 industry groups. Besides CBS, Fox and Disney, the 22-company group includes Time Warner (TWX).
CBS aims to increase non-advertising revenue, and signaled that it plans to launch a Web-only version of movie channel Showtime.
HBO's stand-alone Internet streaming service is off to a good start with Apple (AAPL) as a partner, Time Warner said on its Q1 earnings call last month.

CBS on Thursday also announced a licensing agreement for TV show "CSI" with Hulu, which has stepped up content deals, aiming to be a more serious challenger to top video streaming service Netflix (NFLX). Hulu acquired exclusive subscription video-on-demand rights for CSI to all previous seasons.

"On the call, management sounded optimistic regarding the imminent Showtime OTT offering, saying it is expected to be a 'meaningful driver' of cable results in the near future," said David Bank, an analyst at RBC Capital, in a research report.
Nicole Black, a Wells Fargo analyst, said in a report that discussion of Internet video overshadowed speculation over control of the media company.
Sumner Redstone is chairman of both CBS and Viacom (VIA), and there has been speculation over Redstone's successor.

Hulu acquired exclusive subscription video-on-demand rights for CSI to all previous seasons."On the call, management sounded optimistic regarding the imminent Showtime OTT offering, saying it is expected to be a 'meaningful driver' of cable results in the near future," said David Bank, an analyst at RBC Capital, in a research report.Nicole Black, a Wells Fargo analyst, said in a report that discussion of Internet video overshadowed speculation over control of the media company.Sumner Redstone is chairman of both CBS and Viacom (VIA), and there has been speculation over Redstone's successor."We were very much surprised that there was absolutely no mention of the Redstone family trust on the Q1 2015 earnings call," wrote Black.

21st Century Fox (FOXA) announced Tuesday that "The X-Files" will return to TV as a six-episode "event series." David Duchovny and Gillian Anderson will reprise their roles a Mulder and Sully in the science-fiction drama, which originally aired from 1993-2002, and spawned two feature films. Creator Chris Carter will be back at the helm.If a Hollywood studio can bring back a show that arguably outstayed its welcome, what about a critically acclaimed show that was cancelled too soon? Specifically, can we finally bring back "Firefly," the short-lived sci-fi western with a big cult following?"The X-Files" revival isn't about the future, but about the past. A few new episodes won't do much for Fox's ratings. But it could make the old content valuable, especially on streaming networks."The X-Files" is available on Netflix (NFLX), Amazon (AMZN) and Hulu. New episodes could let Fox sign a much more lucrative deal by generating viewer interest in streaming the entire series.That's what Fox did with "24." It brought back the Jack Bauer series in a limited run last summer — "24: Live Another Day." It got relatively low ratings. But Fox was able to sell exclusive streaming rights for the entire series to Amazon.'Firefly' Lives?Which brings us to "Firefly." Fox aired just 11 episodes out of 14 made for the 2002 TV series. But it quickly became a cult hit among rabid science-fiction fans. Creator Joss Whedon managed to turn "Firefly" into a 2006 feature film, "Serenity." The movie got good reviews, but didn't make its money back — until strong DVD sales and other follow-on revenue."Firefly" has lived on in comic books, an unauthorized online "spinoff" and at Comic-Con. It's almost a rite of nerd culture to say that you're a "Firefly" fan."Firefly" could return to Fox. It presumably wouldn't make money by itself, but might make "Firefly" more lucrative as streaming content, like "The X-Files" and "24."Firefly also could return as a streaming only series. Netflix brought back the Fox comedy "Arrested Development" for a streaming-only season, but has said previously that it would pass on reviving "Firefly.""Firefly," with its custom sets, special effects and large cast, would be expensive. But Amazon, Hulu Plus or Yahoo Screen might decide that "Firefly" could make the winner a must-have streaming service and be a loss leader that pays off long term.Yahoo (YHOO) revived "Community" this month on Yahoo Screen after the comedy aired five seasons on Comcast (CMCSA)-owned NBC. The online giant hopes that "Community" will raise interest about the no-subscription Yahoo Screen, which is airing more original content.A sticking point for rebooting Firefly may be getting the key players back together. The show had a large ensemble cast that has gone its separate ways. In particular, Nathan Fillion (Captain Mal on "Firefly"), is the title character in "Castle," on Walt Disney (DIS)-owned ABC.Fillion has made it clear that he would love to see "Firefly" return. He and co-star Alan Tudyk recently crowdfunded "Con Man," which will be a series of 10-minute shorts about two actors on a sci-fi show canned too soon. Hmm...But could — or would — Fillion actually commit to a "Firefly" return?"Firefly" also would be unthinkable without Whedon. He directed the hugely popular "Avengers" movie as well as the upcoming sequel. He apparently passed on making the next two Avengers films to avoid burnout. But it's unclear if the creator of "Buffy," "Angel" and "Cabin In The Woods" would want to re-till old ground with "Firefly."Other Possible Cult-Hit Revivals?What other shows could get a (revenue) streaming or TV/streaming revival?* "Chappelle's Show" (2003-2006). The Viacom (VIA)-owned Comedy Central sketch comedy show (2003-2006) still gets good ratings in reruns. An "event series" could introduce Chappelle to a new generation.* "Pushing Daisies" (2007-2009). A critical hit, but a ratings bust. It's unclear if this sweet, quirky dramedy would generate huge buzz beyond its niche fan base. Also, Time Warner's (TWX) Warner Bros. owns the show, which means ABC would have no streaming incentive to air new episodes.

Discovery Communications (DISCA) stock jumped Monday on speculation that the multichannel television producer is a takeover target.A report late Sunday by the Australian Financial Review said that 21st Century Fox (FOXA) held preliminary merger talks with Discovery about two weeks ago. A Fox spokesperson responded to the article, saying, "The story is categorically untrue." Discovery declined to comment.The idea that Discovery might be in play excited Wall Street."If the parties, as they maintain, are not talking, we think they ought to have a chat," Bernstein analyst Todd Juenger said in a research note Monday. "We believe a merger between FOXA and DISCA would make strategic sense on a number of levels."Discovery owns such channels as Discovery Channel, Animal Planet and Science, with such popular shows as "Gold Rush," "Deadliest Catch" and "MythBusters."The combination of Discovery and Fox would create a dominant player in international cable networks, he said. It would allow for a natural combination of the Discovery Channel and Fox's National Geographic channels, as well as Fox's Sky Sports networks and Discovery's Eurosport in Europe, Juenger said.Discovery stock was up 5% in midday trading on the stock market today, near 32.50. It had been up as much as 9% in morning trading but has been in a downtrend since August.On Thursday, Discovery reported its first year-over-year decline in earnings per share in eight quarters. Sales growth was the slowest for the company in seven quarters.In the December quarter, Discovery earned 38 cents a share, down 7% from the year-earlier quarter, on sales of $1.68 billion, up 9%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were looking for 41 cents and $1.7 billion.

Apple (AAPL) plans to launch a TV streaming service this fall with some 25 channels, including several broadcast networks. The service, which would seriously disrupt the cable industry, would work on any Apple iOS devices, including iPhones, iPads and Apple TV, the Wall Street Journal reported Monday night. The channels would include CBS (CBS), Fox (FOXA) and Walt Disney (DIS)-owned…

Apple (AAPL) is preparing to enter the over-the-top Internet television market this year with a multichannel subscription service that would provide an alternative to more expensive cable, satellite and telco TV services. The streaming video service will launch this fall with about 25 channels, including several broadcast networks, the Wall Street Journal reported late Monday. Apple's service would be available on iOS devices including iPhones, iPads and the Apple TV set-top box.

Apple's service reportedly will include CBS (CBS), Fox (FOXA) and Walt Disney (DIS)-owned ABC broadcast networks. NBC is not part of the subscription programming bundle, but the Comcast (CMCSA)-owned network plans to offer a stand-alone streaming app for Apple TV later this year, 9to5Mac reported Tuesday.
Apple is aiming to offer the service for $30 to $40 a month. It likely will announce the service in June and launch it in September, the Journal said.

The news follows the recent launch of Dish Network 's (DISH) watershed Sling TV service. Sling TV starts at $20 a month and includes live streaming of 20 cable networks including AMC, Cartoon Network, CNN, ESPN, TBS and TNT. Additional channels are available through add-on packages.

On Tuesday, Sling TV added Microsoft's (MSFT) Xbox One video game console to its list of compatible hardware. It's the third big-screen platform for Sling TV, which is also available on Roku and Amazon (AMZN) Fire TV hardware. Microsoft said Xbox One owners can get a one-month free trial of Sling TV service.
Sony (SNE) is planning to launch a similar service aimed at so-called "cord cutters" soon.
Apple stock was up more than 1.5% in afternoon trading on the stock market today, near 127.

Apple's over-the-top television service could lay the groundwork for Apple to come out with its own television set, possibly in 2016, Piper Jaffray analyst Gene Munster said in a research report Tuesday. Munster rates Apple stock as overweight with a price target of 160.
This month, Apple slashed the price of its Apple TV set-top box to $69 from $99 and announced that it would be the exclusive launch partner for Time Warner's (TWX) HBO Now streaming service in April.

The Apple television service could be a low-margin business designed to keep customers using its hardware, Wells Fargo Securities analyst Maynard Um said in a note Tuesday. Um rates Apple stock market-perform.

"While this could help revenue, we believe margins may be low when taking content and other costs into account," Um said. "Rather, we believe this strategy could be to drive further lock-in to stem any threats of attrition and potential to gain share (i.e. hardware sales)."

Given Apple's immense size, revenue from the TV service would be "largely immaterial" to the company, Bernstein analyst Toni Sacconaghi said in a note Tuesday. And the service likely would cut into Apple's gross profit margin, he said.

"We see an Apple TV service's principal value as enhancing Apple's iOS ecosystem, akin to other service offerings like iCloud, Siri, and Apple Pay, which we believe collectively help strengthen and differentiate the platform relative to Android," Sacconaghi said.

He rates Apple stock outperform with a price target of 135.Apple (AAPL) is preparing to enter the over-the-top Internet television market this year with a multichannel subscription service that would provide an alternative to more expensive cable, satellite and telco TV services. Federal regulators could launch a probe if Comcast (CMCSA), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Walt Disney (DIS) bring in Time Warner (TWX) as a fourth partner in Hulu, especially if the media quartet becomes much more selective in licensing content to Web video streamer Netflix (NFLX).
So says Paul Gallant, an analyst at Guggenheim Partners.

Gallant notes that the Department of Justice in 2012 reportedly launched an antitrust investigation involving nascent over-the-top (OTT) online video services and the broadband policies of cable TV companies.
Even though Hulu is much smaller than Netflix, plans involving Hulu could raise alarm, says Gallant.

"It may well be the case that media company executives have not privately discussed restricting the sale of content to OTTs," said Gallant in a research report. "But given the growing public discussion around this issue — highlighted by Time Warner's comments and its possible Hulu move — it would not surprise us if the DOJ began an investigation for any indication of coordination regarding OTT."

One wild card is whether the media companies go ahead and license content to a formidable new entrant, such as Apple (AAPL). A Web TV service from Apple has long been speculated, though another analyst on Tuesday cast some doubt.
Time Warner reportedly is in talks to be the fourth partner in money-losing Hulu.
Disney, 21st Century Fox and cable TV firm Comcast, which controls NBCUniversal, are co-owners of Hulu.
Comcast is barred from taking part in Hulu's management until 2018, under conditions that regulators set on its 2011 acquisition of NBCU.
Disney disclosed higher Hulu losses in its Q3 earnings.
Programming Fees At Risk
While Netflix's subscribers continue to grow, pay-TV companies have been losing customers, putting the programming fees that media giants garner from Comcast and others at risk.

Some analysts have cautioned that pulling content from Netflix might not be the best strategic move, since Netflix pays for the content. Media firms' subscription video-on-demand revenue is much smaller than pay-TV revenue.

Time Warner and Fox have been the most open about rethinking their SVOD (subscription video on demand) licensing plans. Viacom (VIA) has cut back on content provided to Neflix. CBS, Disney and Comcast all licensed new shows to Netflix in Q3.

Media companies might not have a united front. Disney's three-year movie deal with Netflix kicks in during 2016. CBS (CBS) Chief Executive Leslie Moonves, at an investor conference Nov. 11, said, "Netflix is not the Antichrist."

Amid speculation that he's about to use his stakes in Discovery (DISCA), Starz (STRZA), Lionsgate (LGF) and Liberty Media (LMCA) to roll up smaller content providers, Liberty Chairman John Malone last week said that his biggest recent mistake was not launching a hostile takeover of Netflix when its shares plummeted in 2011 following a price hike.

Media stocks took a pummeling last quarter following a series of weaker-than-expected earnings and concerns that Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN) Prime were prompting subscribers to cut the cord.

This week, all eyes are on Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Time Warner (TWX) as they report quarterly results, with investors and analysts awaiting key figures such as subscriber growth and ad revenue.
Disney, which had hit a high of 122.08 on Aug. 4, tumbled 11% the following day after warning of slowing affiliate-fee revenue growth and noting "modest" subscriber declines at ESPN.
But shares have since regained their climb, and finished up 1.1% in the stock market Monday. Netflix dipped 0.7%, and Amazon ended up 0.4%.
When the Mouse reports fiscal Q4 results late Thursday, Wall Street expects Disney to earn $1.14 a share, up 28% from the prior-year quarter, while revenue is seen rising 9% to $13.55 billion.
Fox reports a day earlier on Wednesday, when analysts expect fiscal Q1 earnings to dip 3% to 38 cents per share and revenue to notch down 0.2% to $6.42 billion.
Shares closed up 0.55% Monday.

As online streamers gain steam with bulked-up original scripted content and solid licensed offerings, mainstream broadcasters reportedly have been re-examining their licensing relationships with rivals such as Netflix.

At a Goldman Sachs media conference in September, Fox chief James Murdoch called Netflix a "valuable partner," according to the Financial Times, but also mulled licensing more of its content to Hulu for its more "attractive" compensation.
Hulu is a joint venture between Disney, Fox and Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal.

At the same September event, Time Warner head Jeff Bewkes agreed with the idea that Netflix adoption is ramping up cord-cutting, but also said HBO's streaming service, HBO Now, was "performing well against expectations."
Time Warner, which also reports Wednesday, is expected to see a Q3 earnings decline of 11% to $1.09 per share and revenue growth of 4% to $6.51 billion.
Shares finished the regular session up 1.6%.

Amid cord-cutting worries, content remains king. In a recent study from entertainment news site Extreamist, HBO topped Netflix at picking up TV series that would become critical darlings. Disney's ABC came in third, with CBS (CBS) and Fox rounding out the fourth and fifth spots.

Meanwhile, even Netflix has not been immune to disappointing investors. The streaming service fell short of Q3 earnings and revenue estimates several weeks ago and missed its own target for U.S. subscriber growth during the quarter, adding just 880,000 subscribers vs. guidance for 1.15 million.

Despite the tizzy over traditional media companies losing subscribers, cable TV stocks got a boost last week as Time Warner Cable (TWC) and Charter Communications (CHTR) logged higher broadband subscriber numbers and narrowed video subscriber losses.
And Comcast topped Q3 revenue forecasts on Tuesday as it added 320,000 broadband customers and also narrowed video subscriber losses during the quarter.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.
RELATED:
Netflix Earnings Reviews Poor Like Adam Sandler Movie

Netflix (NFLX) is bullish on its first feature film, "Beasts of No Nation," which debuted on Oct. 16 and already has over 3 million views in North America alone, but the jury is still out on whether the company will continue to take on even more Oscar-level movie projects.The drama about an African warlord and child soldiers could set the tone for the other feature films in Netflix's pipeline, including Brad Pitt and Adam Sandler movies, among others. Here are three risks that come with Netflix's Oscar aspirations:AudienceNetflix is known as a binge-watching platform. Its subscribers enjoy watching a succession of TV episodes for hours on end. With its own original series, Netflix releases all episodes at once so viewers can do just that.Feature-length films are a different beast. The benefit of having series that people love is that they take longer to watch and keep viewers coming back, a Zack's Investment Research analyst recently noted. When you watch a movie, it's over after two hours.MoneyFeature films are also seen as a potentially bigger financial risk than a series because a series can be adapted to the reactions of viewers.Because "Beasts" was released on Netflix's site the same day it debuted in theaters, AMC Entertainment (AMC), Regal Entertainment (RGC) and others boycotted the film before it hit big and small screens, meaning stifled box office sales.But Rich Tullo, an analyst with Albert Fried, discussed the film's results after its initial weekend debut, saying a "flop" in theaters doesn't mean it's not popular online."While the $51,000 box office seems like a huge flop it is possible that Beasts of No Nation may be popular on Netflix," Tullo said in a report last week.CompetitionAside from Amazon's (AMZN) Prime Video service and Hulu (a joint venture between Disney (DIS), Fox (FOXA) and Comcast's (CMCSA) NBCUniversal), Netflix is facing increased competition from Alphabet's (GOOGL) YouTube Red paid subscription service and DisneyLife, a streaming app that's expected to soon debut in the UK.It Could Pay OffBut if Netflix can nab an Oscar with "Beasts," that's one more accolade that may sway consumers to purchase a subscription.Jyske Bank said in an Oct. 16 research report that original movies, along with TV shows, are one of Netflix's strengths.Netflix's U.S. subscriber additions disappointed investors last quarter, so the fresh content, though not in binge format, could grab more attention.Follow Alissa Williams on Twitter @IBD_AWilliams and Facebook.

AMC Networks (AMCX) on Wednesday stumbled like one of the zombies from its show "The Walking Dead" after a Wall Street analyst cut his price target on the stock over declining ratings for that program.
AMC stock fell as much as 3.8% on Wednesday but ended the session down 1.8% at 68.13 on the stock market today.
Guggenheim Securities analyst Michael Morris maintained his buy rating on AMC stock but cut his price target to 83 from 90.

Through the first two weeks of their current seasons, "The Walking Dead" (season 6) and its companion recap show "The Talking Dead" (season 4), have recorded declines of 15% to 20% in their core demographic of 18- to 49-year-old viewers, Morris said.
"While it is early and there are numerous factors to consider, we cannot overlook the importance of the franchise to equity value and risk of sustained declines," Morris said in a report.

One possible reason for the ratings declines has been competition from Major League Baseball playoff teams from large markets (New York City, Chicago and Los Angeles) and a marquee National Football League match-up last Sunday, he said.

"Despite our positive view of the company's expanding content offering, we believe ratings pressure on 'The Walking Dead' will weigh on overall reported ratings, and will ultimately temper ad growth," Morris said. "Despite attractive underlying content value, we do not expect the public valuation multiple to expand without ratings growth. Sustained lower 'The Walking Dead' ratings are likely too heavy to be offset by new programming, in our view."
He also trimmed his 2016 and 2017 EPS estimates for AMC to $5.60 and $6.48, respectively, from his prior $5.79 and $6.74, reflecting a lower advertising revenue forecast.
'Walking Dead' Next 'American Idol'?

Cowen analyst Doug Creutz initiated coverage on AMC Networks on Tuesday with a market perform rating and price target of 72. He cited the company's overreliance on "The Walking Dead" for his cautious report.

"While AMC Networks has been one of the fastest growing companies in the media universe, we are concerned about the company's reliance on 'The Walking Dead' franchise and see significant risk if viewership begins to decline," Creutz said.
He estimates "The Walking Dead" franchise, including the original series, talk show and spinoff show "Fear the Walking Dead," account for nearly 25% of the AMC channel's total primetime viewership.

"This is a very comparable figure to American Idol's contribution to the Fox broadcast network's total season viewership as recently as 2011," he said. The subsequent ratings decline for "American Idol" was the primary driver behind declining earnings at the Fox TV segment over the last four years, he said. The Fox network is owned by 21st Century Fox (FOXA).
"AMC could find itself in an even more difficult position than Fox has been in if 'The Walking Dead' were to start suffering a significant loss of viewer interest," Creutz said.

AMC found success with TV dramas "Mad Men" and "Breaking Bad," but those popular shows have ended their initial runs. Since those series premiered, competition for high-quality TV programs has become fiercer, with over-the-top Internet services like Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon.com (AMZN) entering the bidding, Creutz said.

Ultrahigh-definition television is going mainstream this holiday shopping season, as major retailers use UHD or 4K TVs as promotional items for Black Friday.

"You can get a 4K Ultra HD television for under $700 this year," said Shawn DuBravac, chief economist and senior research director for the Consumer Technology Association, the former Consumer Electronics Association. Retailers are using cheap 4K televisions as door-buster specials for Black Friday, the annual kickoff to the holiday shopping season, this year on Nov. 27.
UHD televisions have four times the resolution of today's high-definition television sets for increased picture clarity and sharpness.

The wholesale price for a 4K television has dropped by half to $1,100 from $2,200 just a year ago, DuBravac said at the CTA's CES Unveiled event Tuesday in New York City. Factors behind the drop include the strong dollar lowering import prices, cheaper components and higher factory yields on display technology, DuBravac said.
"Next year, about 80% to 90% of televisions with displays over 50 inches will be Ultra HD sets," DuBravac said.

Best Buy (BBY) is advertising a 49-inch 4K UHD Smart LED TV from LG for $499.99 (regularly $899.99) for Black Friday weekend sales. It will also sell a Samsung 60-inch 4K UHD Smart LED TV for $799.99 (regularly $1,499).
Best Buy is offering a Vizio 65-inch 4K UHD Smart LED TV for $999.99 (regularly $1,499.99) and a Samsung 65-inch SUHDTV for $1,999.99 (regularly $3,300).
Other retailers offering deals on ultrahigh-definition TVs for Black Friday include Costco (COST), Target (TGT) and Wal-Mart (WMT).

UHD TVs do a good job of upscaling HD content, but native 4K content is still hard to find. Streaming video services like Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon.com (AMZN) offer some of their original shows in 4K, but there are no cable or broadcast channels in 4K yet.

UHD Blu-ray Disc recordings and players will be coming to the market soon. Sony (SNE) announced Tuesday that it will release its first Ultra HD movies on Blu-ray Disc in early 2016. In September, the home entertainment unit of 21st Century Fox (FOXA) said that it would come out with Ultra HD movies on Blu-ray Disc in early 2016 as well.

Apple Discounts Stand Out Among Black Friday Deals.Ultrahigh-definition television is going mainstream this holiday shopping season, as major retailers use UHD or 4K TVs as promotional items for Black Friday."You can get a 4K Ultra HD television for under $700 this year," said Shawn DuBravac, chief economist and senior research director for the Consumer Technology Association, the former Consumer Electronics Association. Retailers are using cheap 4K televisions as door-buster specials for Black Friday, the annual kickoff to the holiday shopping season, this year on Nov. 27.UHD televisions have four times the resolution of today's high-definition television sets for increased picture clarity and sharpness.The wholesale price for a 4K television has dropped by half to $1,100 from $2,200 just a year ago, DuBravac said at the CTA's CES Unveiled event Tuesday in New York City. Factors behind the drop include the strong dollar lowering import prices, cheaper components and higher factory yields on display technology, DuBravac said."Next year, about 80% to 90% of televisions with displays over 50 inches will be Ultra HD sets," DuBravac said.Best Buy (BBY) is advertising a 49-inch 4K UHD Smart LED TV from LG for $499.99 (regularly $899.99) for Black Friday weekend sales. It will also sell a Samsung 60-inch 4K UHD Smart LED TV for $799.99 (regularly $1,499).Best Buy is offering a Vizio 65-inch 4K UHD Smart LED TV for $999.99 (regularly $1,499.99) and a Samsung 65-inch SUHDTV for $1,999.99 (regularly $3,300).Other retailers offering deals on ultrahigh-definition TVs for Black Friday include Costco (COST), Target (TGT) and Wal-Mart (WMT).UHD TVs do a good job of upscaling HD content, but native 4K content is still hard to find. Streaming video services like Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon.com (AMZN) offer some of their original shows in 4K, but there are no cable or broadcast channels in 4K yet.UHD Blu-ray Disc recordings and players will be coming to the market soon. Sony (SNE) announced Tuesday that it will release its first Ultra HD movies on Blu-ray Disc in early 2016. In September, the home entertainment unit of 21st Century Fox (FOXA) said that it would come out with Ultra HD movies on Blu-ray Disc in early 2016 as well.RELATED:Apple Discounts Stand Out Among Black Friday Deals.

21st Century Fox (FOXA) is bringing its A game to China with a deal to bring flicks such as "The A-Team" and "Black Swan" to the country's small screens. The studio's distribution arm, 20th Century Fox Television Distribution, has greenlighted a licensing agreement with YOU On Demand (YOD), giving the video-on-demand service provider subscription VOD rights in China to an array of feature film titles.
Fox shares rose 0.9% to 33.45 in the stock market today. YOU On Demand Holdings shares shot up 35.6% to 2.78 on the news.
You On Demand said subscribers will be able to watch Fox films on all of the provider's platforms, including mobile, over-the-top, digital cable and Internet protocol television.

Fox isn't the only studio with its eye on China's at-home movie watchers. In November, Time Warner's (TWX) HBO formed a distribution deal with ISP Tencent to give Chinese viewers access to "Game of Thrones" and other hits from the premium cable channel. That same month, Walt Disney expanded its strategic partnership with Shanghai Media Group to include TV content development, film production, marketing cooperation and content distribution.
