In an entertainment-industry version of "The Hunger Games," dozens of shows are competing this fall to stay alive long enough through the first season so that viewers can get a chance to get hooked and root for their survival. But cancel-happy network execs, take note: It usually takes more than a pilot episode for viewers to get so invested in…

Netflix (NFLX) has 10 billion reasons to hike subscriber prices, something bears on the stock know and bulls tend to gloss over. That's more than $10 billion in streaming content obligations over the next five years — cash Netflix must fork over to programmers for rights to TV shows. That doesn't include its own growing expenses for developing original content.

And that $10 billion could be table stakes if Apple (AAPL) enters the video streaming business and bids up the price of on-demand content. Apple's cash horde could support a content buying spree that makes Amazon.com's (AMZN) look paltry.

If Apple launches a Web-TV service in 2016, it'll be in a dogfight with Netflix for cord nevers — young adults who never subscribed to a cable or pay-TV service, says a Forrester report. So it makes sense for Netflix to prepare.
Netflix on Thursday announced a $1 hike for its subscription video service, driving its stock up more than 6%. But Netflix was down 1% in morning trading in the stock market today, near 114.

Pacific Crest Securities on Friday hiked its price target on Netflix to 140 from 122. BMO Capital Markets late Thursday initiated coverage on Netflix, with a market perform rating and a price target of 115.
Netflix is scheduled to report its Q3 earnings Wednesday after the market close.
Content A Costly King
BMO analyst Daniel Salmon, in his research report, notes that "content is king; it's also expensive."

"Netflix's streaming content liabilities are growing steadily, a significant portion of which is due within the next three years," Salmon wrote. "Netflix currently has $10 billion of future streaming content obligations.

"Of that $10 billion, $4.2 billion is due within one year and $4.8 billion is due within one to three years. Netflix's content obligation should continue to grow as it expands internationally, but the international scale will also help lower costs per subscriber."

Netflix will raise prices for new subscribers in the U.S,. Canada and parts of Latin America. The monthly fee for its standard subscription service will go up $1 to $9.99 for all new subscribers in the U.S., Canada and Latin America effective Nov. 8. Existing customers will have a grace period before their monthly rate goes up. Netflix boosted the price of its service in Europe by one euro in August.
Wall Street analysts have long maintained that a price increase would be a good move for Netflix to bolster its finances as it invests in original content and international expansion.

No sell-side analyst will ever forget 2011, when Netflix's stock plunged after it announced a price hike that led some 800,000 subscribers to cancel service. Netflix also shelved a spinoff of its DVD operations into a new company called Qwikster.
Netflix's comeback has been fueled by demand for on-demand content by millennials, some of whom have cut the cord, terminating cable-TV service, or never have subscribed to pay-TV service.
Parsing The Balance Sheet
Andy Hargreaves, an analyst at Pacific Crest, says Netflix is delivering more content value, giving it pricing power.

"Netflix management undoubtedly still remembers Qwikster and would not likely raise prices if it were concerned about the direction of subscriber growth," he said in a research note. "Consequently, we believe (Thursday's) price increase is a positive indicator of the stability in the current domestic user base and the potential for further growth.

"This is the second U.S. price increase since the beginning of 2014. We currently model a terminal U.S. price of $12, which is beginning to look very conservative based on the current pace of price increases and the value Netflix is delivering vs. higher-priced services such as (Time Warner's (TWX) HBO, CBS' (CBS) Showtime and Hulu."
Comcast (CMCSA), Walt Disney (DIS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) own Hulu.
Still, Netflix's content expenses are also rising, some analysts note.

As Salmon put it: "Netflix is currently only carrying $4.5 billion of its content obligations on its balance sheet; $5.6 billion is off-balance sheet. Generally a streaming content obligation is incurred at the time Netflix enters into an agreement to obtain future titles.

"However, the liability is only recorded on the balance sheet once the title becomes available. Because certain agreements include the obligation to license rights for unknown future titles, where the ultimate quantity and/or fees are not determinable at the time of the agreement, Netflix doesn't include an estimated obligation for those future titles on the balance sheet. However, the ultimate value of those obligations is expected to be significant and the expected timing of the payments could range from less than one year to more than five years."

As the broadcast industry consolidates, local TV station owner Gray Television (GTN) is surging in the stock market today on the news that it's scaling up. Late Monday, Gray announced that it has agreed to acquire all of Schurz Communications' television and radio stations for about $443 million. The buyout expands Gray's reach to a total of 49 TV markets…

If Apple (AAPL) launches a Web TV service, it might have a tough time winning over "cord nevers" — young adults who never subscribed to a cable or pay-TV service — especially if they're already Netflix or YouTube users, says Forrester Research in a report. Apple reportedly is planning to offer a Web TV service that will target millennials, millennials…

Streaming darling Netflix (NFLX) may find its appeal among content providers fading as traditional TV networks question whether licensing out their content to an online rival is worth it. "The business rules around how we sell to providers is changing," 21st Century Fox (FOXA) chief James Murdoch said at the Goldman Sachs Communacopia conference on Wednesday, according to Deadline. While…

Streaming video is one of the fastest growing industries as "cord-cutting" consumers continue switching from TV networks to Web-based content. Amazon (AMZN) and Netflix (NFLX) were early market leaders and are widely expected to continue growing in the streaming market.
Today's Screen Of The Day is Estimate Beaters, stocks that beat earnings-per-share estimates by the widest margin in the latest reported quarter.
Amazon absolutely crushed EPS estimates, beating Wall Street's target by 236%. Netflix was no slouch either, topping views by 50% in its last report.
The streaming battle heated up Monday as Netflix dropped its online deal with major movie distributor Epix, three years after ending a similar agreement with Starz (STRZA).
Netflix is increasingly relying on producing its own content, such as the Emmy- and Golden-Globes-winning political drama "House of Cards," starring Kevin Spacey and Robin Wright.

Meanwhile, Netflix rival Hulu said it's already entered a new distribution deal with Epix, and Stifel said in a research report that Comcast (CMCSA), the nation's No. 1 cable company and parent of NBCUniversal, is also a potential new Epix partner.
Comcast, along with 21st Century Fox (FOX) and Walt Disney (DIS), jointly own Hulu.
The streaming battle is going global. Netflix is already in 80 countries, with Amazon playing catchup and streaming in far fewer countries for now.
Amazon late Wednesday announced it will take the streaming video rivalry with Netflix to Japan, where Amazon will launch its Prime Instant Video service next month.

Like Netflix, Amazon is expanding its original programming lineup. Amazon's offerings include the comedy "Transparent," starring Jeffrey Tambor and a winner of two Golden Globe awards, and the detective drama "Bosch."

"We've been offering videos and DVDs in Japan for 15 years — we know what the entertainment customers want — and we plan to deliver it with Prime Video, all at no additional cost" to the $32.50 a year Prime charge in Japan, said Amazon Japan President Jasper Cheung.
Netflix said it will launch in Japan on Wednesday.

Amazon shares were down less than 1% in Monday trading amid volatility in the stock market today. Amazon climbed above a second-stage flat base with a $452.75 buy point on July 13, closing at $455.57. Then it raced 27% higher from that point to an all-time high at 580.57 before consolidating.

Netflix has had similarly robust results. It rose above a first-stage, 7.5-month cup-with-handle base with a 69.62 buy point on April 16, closing at 80.32. It popped 61% from that point to a new high at 129.29 on Aug. 5 before consolidating.
Both companies have held up well during the current market volatility and are trading near their highs.

U.S. media companies should continue making overseas acquisitions, but international expansion may not be a cure-all for what ails them — namely Netflix (NFLX), Facebook and Google's YouTube, says Morgan Stanley. Morgan Stanley analyst Benjamin Swinburne said "the three-headed monster of (Google's  (GOOGL) YouTube, Netflix, and Facebook (FB)" gives U.S. media companies good reason to invest in overseas content…

Overseas markets beckon for U.S. media and entertainment companies amid hand-wringing over the state of the U.S. pay-TV industry. Media companies face cord-cutting and loss of traditional TV subscribers as millennials flock to Web streaming and on-demand viewing. So there's upside in taking content abroad and investing in untapped markets.

"International growth is important as it offsets a slowing U.S. market," said Michael Nathanson, an analyst at MoffettNathanson. "The biggest headroom for international growth could be found at Fox due to India, Disney due to China and Discovery from Eurosport," he told IBD.

Discovery, with 51% of 2014 revenue outside the U.S., has the most international exposure. 21st Century Fox (FOXA) garnered 33% of revenue from beyond our shores in 2014, followed by Time Warner (TWX) at 30%, Viacom (VIA) at 26%, Disney at 25%, AMC Networks (AMCX) at 20% and CBS (CBS) at 13%, says Nathanson.
Other analysts point to overseas growth for Time Warner, from its HBO channel as well as Turner International, which has expanded kids and news programming in Latin America and Asia.
AMC Networks in early 2014 acquired Chellomedia, the international channel unit of pan-European cable giant Liberty Global, for $1 billion.

AMC has rebranded Chellomedia's MGM channel and other programming. AMC on Aug. 23 launched "Fear the Walking Dead," its sequel to a zombie TV show hit, in more than 120 countries, aiming to boost its international brand.

Disappointing earnings guidance, weak summer audience ratings, Walt Disney's (DIS) warning over slowing revenue growth from affiliate fees, and Discovery Communications' (DISCA) move to hit the brakes on stock buy-backs all combined to torch media stocks in early August.
While the ranks of doomsayers are growing, Sanford Bernstein analyst Todd Juenger says concern is justified.

"The market is now valuing U.S. ad-supported TV businesses as structurally impaired assets," Juenger said. "When an industry is undergoing a massive structural upheaval — one major revenue stream is already impaired and now there are signs the second one may be as well — investors won't wait for final conclusive evidence to re-evaluate how much they are willing to pay for the existing status-quo cash flow streams."

While analysts expect international growth to provide an incremental boost to some U.S. media companies, none seem on the same trajectory as Web video streamer Netflix (NFLX), whose subscriber growth is expected to come mostly from overseas. Netflix's services are expected to be available in markets covering 385 million broadband households by the end of 2016, making them possible customers, says Pacific Crest Securities.

Media company management was keen to tout international prospects on Q2 earnings calls, says Anthony DiClemente, a Nomura Securities analyst. Time Warner noted that HBO's pay-TV service is available to only 10% of 750 million potential global pay-TV viewers.

"Given headwinds in the U.S. market, companies pointed to international growth," DiClemente said in a report. "Owing to expanded use of subscription VOD services in several markets, management teams are increasingly shifting focus as well as investments toward international markets."
While currency exchange rates pose a near-term issue for media companies as the dollar strengthens, they still aim to prosper from long-term trends.
For Fox, India looms as a growth market as incomes rise, making broadband and ad-supported TV services more affordable for consumers.

In India, Fox owns TV service Star India as well as a new Web streaming business called Hot Star. The ad-supported streaming platform lets users watch live TV shows, cricket and on-demand content for free.
While Fox has been investing heavily in sports rights for Star India, it was rewarded in April when the Cricket World Cup garnered record TV and online digital viewership.
Discovery also is betting on upside from sports.

Discovery in July acquired full ownership of Eurosport, which operates across the Continent and Asia. Eurosport recently paid $1.4 billion to acquire all the TV and digital platform rights for four Olympic Games, from 2018 through 2024.
Discovery took a 20% stake in Eurosport in 2012 and upped its investment to 51% two years later.

"Executing on its international prospects is now more important than ever to offset industry headwinds impacting U.S. advertising growth," said Amy Yong, a Macquarie Capital analyst, in a report on Discovery.
In December, Discovery aims to show its reach, broadcasting the documentary "Racing Extinction" in 220 international markets within a 24-hour period.

The core Discovery Channel has mustered improved ratings in India, Brazil and Mexico. But some analysts say Discovery's international business has matured, with advertising and programming fee growth slowing.

"Over the prior half-decade, core international growth in advertising has ranged from the high 20% range to high singles to low double digits. While we still view international as a longer-term growth opportunity, a combination of macroeconomic, geopolitical, competitive and acquisition headwinds is probably going to keep core international advertising growth at the low end of the range for the next several quarters," said David Bank, analyst at RBC Capital Markets in a report.
Discovery in August named a new president of international content, Marjorie Kaplan.
Disney, a diversified media company, still counts on sports channel ESPN for much of its profit. Even so, with U.S. costs rising, ESPN has pulled back on bidding for sports rights overseas.

Disney is expected to open a $5.5 billion theme park and resort in Shanghai in the spring of 2016. Disney has built the Shanghai theme park, much bigger than its older Hong Kong park, with a consortium of state-owned companies known as Shanghai Shendi Group. Disney has already opened its largest retail store at the Shanghai location. The new theme park will feature attractions based on Marvel comics and Star Wars, and others based on Chinese culture.Overseas markets beckon for U.S. media and entertainment companies amid hand-wringing over the state of the U.S. pay-TV industry. Media companies face cord-cutting and loss of traditional TV subscribers as millennials flock to Web streaming and on-demand viewing. So there's upside in taking content abroad and investing in untapped markets."International growth is important as it offsets a slowing U.S. market," said Michael Nathanson, an analyst at MoffettNathanson. "The biggest headroom for international growth could be found at Fox due to India, Disney due to China and Discovery from Eurosport," he told IBD.Discovery, with 51% of 2014 revenue outside the U.S., has the most international exposure. 21st Century Fox (FOXA) garnered 33% of revenue from beyond our shores in 2014, followed by Time Warner (TWX) at 30%, Viacom (VIA) at 26%, Disney at 25%, AMC Networks (AMCX) at 20% and CBS (CBS) at 13%, says Nathanson.Other analysts point to overseas growth for Time Warner, from its HBO channel as well as Turner International, which has expanded kids and news programming in Latin America and Asia.AMC Networks in early 2014 acquired Chellomedia, the international channel unit of pan-European cable giant Liberty Global, for $1 billion.AMC has rebranded Chellomedia's MGM channel and other programming. AMC on Aug. 23 launched "Fear the Walking Dead," its sequel to a zombie TV show hit, in more than 120 countries, aiming to boost its international brand.Disappointing earnings guidance, weak summer audience ratings, Walt Disney's (DIS) warning over slowing revenue growth from affiliate fees, and Discovery Communications' (DISCA) move to hit the brakes on stock buy-backs all combined to torch media stocks in early August.While the ranks of doomsayers are growing, Sanford Bernstein analyst Todd Juenger says concern is justified."The market is now valuing U.S. ad-supported TV businesses as structurally impaired assets," Juenger said. "When an industry is undergoing a massive structural upheaval — one major revenue stream is already impaired and now there are signs the second one may be as well — investors won't wait for final conclusive evidence to re-evaluate how much they are willing to pay for the existing status-quo cash flow streams."While analysts expect international growth to provide an incremental boost to some U.S. media companies, none seem on the same trajectory as Web video streamer Netflix (NFLX), whose subscriber growth is expected to come mostly from overseas. Netflix's services are expected to be available in markets covering 385 million broadband households by the end of 2016, making them possible customers, says Pacific Crest Securities.Media company management was keen to tout international prospects on Q2 earnings calls, says Anthony DiClemente, a Nomura Securities analyst. Time Warner noted that HBO's pay-TV service is available to only 10% of 750 million potential global pay-TV viewers."Given headwinds in the U.S. market, companies pointed to international growth," DiClemente said in a report. "Owing to expanded use of subscription VOD services in several markets, management teams are increasingly shifting focus as well as investments toward international markets."While currency exchange rates pose a near-term issue for media companies as the dollar strengthens, they still aim to prosper from long-term trends.For Fox, India looms as a growth market as incomes rise, making broadband and ad-supported TV services more affordable for consumers.In India, Fox owns TV service Star India as well as a new Web streaming business called Hot Star. The ad-supported streaming platform lets users watch live TV shows, cricket and on-demand content for free.While Fox has been investing heavily in sports rights for Star India, it was rewarded in April when the Cricket World Cup garnered record TV and online digital viewership.Discovery also is betting on upside from sports.Discovery in July acquired full ownership of Eurosport, which operates across the Continent and Asia. Eurosport recently paid $1.4 billion to acquire all the TV and digital platform rights for four Olympic Games, from 2018 through 2024.Discovery took a 20% stake in Eurosport in 2012 and upped its investment to 51% two years later."Executing on its international prospects is now more important than ever to offset industry headwinds impacting U.S. advertising growth," said Amy Yong, a Macquarie Capital analyst, in a report on Discovery.In December, Discovery aims to show its reach, broadcasting the documentary "Racing Extinction" in 220 international markets within a 24-hour period.The core Discovery Channel has mustered improved ratings in India, Brazil and Mexico. But some analysts say Discovery's international business has matured, with advertising and programming fee growth slowing."Over the prior half-decade, core international growth in advertising has ranged from the high 20% range to high singles to low double digits. While we still view international as a longer-term growth opportunity, a combination of macroeconomic, geopolitical, competitive and acquisition headwinds is probably going to keep core international advertising growth at the low end of the range for the next several quarters," said David Bank, analyst at RBC Capital Markets in a report.Discovery in August named a new president of international content, Marjorie Kaplan.Disney, a diversified media company, still counts on sports channel ESPN for much of its profit. Even so, with U.S. costs rising, ESPN has pulled back on bidding for sports rights overseas.Disney is expected to open a $5.5 billion theme park and resort in Shanghai in the spring of 2016. Disney has built the Shanghai theme park, much bigger than its older Hong Kong park, with a consortium of state-owned companies known as Shanghai Shendi Group. Disney has already opened its largest retail store at the Shanghai location. The new theme park will feature attractions based on Marvel comics and Star Wars, and others based on Chinese culture.

After two weeks of bullish analyst reports and price target hikes, Netflix (NFLX) stock fell from its lofty perch on Thursday. In afternoon trading on the stock market today, Netflix was down 7.5% to near 113 amid a broader market selloff.
The Internet television company reached a record high of 129.29 on Aug. 5. Analysts attributed the drop Tuesday to profit-taking and valuation concerns.

Netflix stock has held strong in recent weeks as traditional media companies like Time Warner (TWX), 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Viacom (VIAB) and Walt Disney (DIS) have tanked. Analysts say that those old-school media firms are feeling pressure from Netflix as viewers shift from linear broadcast television to on-demand Internet video.

Netflix had been riding high since delivering better-than-expected subscriber numbers for the second quarter on July 15, and Netflix stock has a high 98 Relative Strength Rating from IBD, which means that it's performed among the top 2% of all stocks in the past 12 months.
Netflix ended Q2 with 65.55 million streaming subscribers — 42.3 million in the U.S. and 23.25 million elsewhere.
For the current Q3, Netflix expects to add 3.55 million new streaming subscribers for a total of 69.1 million. It hopes to gain 2.4 million international subscribers and 1.15 million in the U.S.
Netflix plans to complete its global rollout by the end of next year. It is scheduled to launch in Japan on Sept. 2 and in Italy, Portugal and Spain in the fourth quarter.
Rosenblatt Securities analyst Martin Pyykkonen said that there were no obvious factors driving down Netflix shares on Thursday.

Growth stocks like Netflix that have had a great run often pull back harder during market selloffs, Pyykkonen told IBD. "High beta, high valuation stocks are easier to purge," he said. Plus, media stocks overall have been hit pretty hard, he said.

Wells Fargo downgraded several media stocks on Tuesday — including Walt Disney (DIS), CBS (CBS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) — citing the dismal earnings season within the group during the second quarter.

The downgrade comes a couple of weeks after media stocks got slammed amid ongoing fears that competition from Netflix (NFLX) and other streaming services will lead to subscriber losses and lower cable ad revenue.
Shares of Disney closed down 1.9%, Fox 1.1% and CBS 1.4% on the stock market today. Netflix finished 1.1% lower.

Biotech startup Juno Therapeutics (JUNO) — which inked a $1 billion deal with biotech giant Celgene (CELG) last month — was initiated with an outperform rating and 73 price target by FBR Capital. Juno's stock price, which had been up 5.2% in afternoon trading, ended the day flat.

Meanwhile, highly rated auto parts retailer Advance Auto Parts (AAP) got an upgrade and steep price target hike Tuesday, while cosmetics giant Estee Lauder (EL) also received an upgrade a day after its stock price tanked 7% on disappointing quarterly sales and a cautious outlook.
Argus upgraded Advance Auto to buy from hold with a price target of 217. Advance Auto shares edged up 0.6%. Last week, the stock set a new high of 192.27 on better-than-expected quarterly earnings.

Estee Lauder's stock price closed up 1.2% after Telsey Advisory Group upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. Coach (COH) was upgraded to buy from hold by Jefferies as analysts said the maker of luxury accessories is underappreciated by investors. Coach rose 1.9%.

Comcast (CMCSA) aims to boost international revenue, with M&A an option, NBCUniversal's chief executive said at a financial conference on Wednesday.Comcast, which owns a cable TV network and entertainment giant NBCU, aims to catch up with Walt Disney (DIS), 21st Century Fox and others outside America, said Stephen Burke, NBCU's CEO, speaking at a Bank of America Merrill Lynch media and entertainment conference in Beverly Hills, Calif.NBCU on Wednesday forged a movie distribution deal with China-based Alibaba's (BABA) new Web streaming service.Burke said NBCU's "Fast and Furious 7" movie grossed $400 million at the box office in China."With growth in China, India and Latin America, you want a higher percentage of revenue coming from overseas," said Burke, noting that Comcast's cable TV business is all domestic. Liberty Global (LBTYA) is the biggest cable TV player in Europe."There are very few companies with a $150 billion market cap with so little of their revenue coming from outside the U.S.," Burke said. "We see it as a huge opportunity. I think whether it's M&A activity or organic growth, international is a huge opportunity for us and it's something we'll pursue over the next five to 10 years."Comcast also is building a $3.3 billion Universal theme park in Beijing with local partners.Burke said NBCU garners some 20% of revenue internationally. Discovery Communications (DISCA), with 51% of 2014 revenue outside the U.S., has the most international exposure. Fox (FOXA) garnered 33% of revenue outside America, followed by Time Warner (TWX) at 30%, Viacom (VIA) at 26% and Disney at 25%. Growing international revenue is key for media firms amid falling TV ratings and advertising woes, says MoffettNathanson.Burke said Comcast is interested in acquiring more live sports content and is investing in new content for millennials as video viewing habits shift to the Internet.

U.S. diversified stock funds slid 0.54% on average in the week ended Aug. 6, ending a one-week rally. They've lost money for investors on average in five of the past seven weeks. Their loss in the latest week trimmed their year-to-date gain to 2.30%.
The week opened amid signs that global economic growth is too anemic to make a dent in a growing glut of oil. Light sweet crude's price fell.
Oil giants Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) led a slide in energy stocks, fueling negative stock market news.
On Monday, Athens' stock market reopened after a five-week suspension — and the Greek exchange nose-dived 16%.
Closer to home, Puerto Rico defaulted on a $58 million bond payment. The commonwealth is seeking to restructure $72 billion in debt.

Separately, investors in mutual funds industrywide felt a chill as Pimco said it got a Wells notice from the SEC, indicating that the regulatory agency might sue the asset manager over how it valued assets in one of its most popular exchange traded funds.
On Tuesday, the U.S. market fell again as an Atlanta Federal Reserve said the U.S. economy was ready for higher interest rates.

Also on Tuesday, Apple (AAPL) fell for a fifth straight day as investors worried whether the electronic gadget giant can keep climbing at the pace it has set in recent quarters. Apple — and the market overall — was also dogged by concerns over China's slowdown.
Despite more declines by oil stocks, Wednesday was the week's only up day, thanks to a flurry of corporate earnings.
First Solar (FSLR) heated up by 17% by beating earnings estimates and raising its guidance.
Priceline (PCLN) gapped up to close more than 5% ahead. The online booker's profit and revenue topped analysts' expectations, driven by rising reservations for rental cars and hotel rooms.
On Thursday it was media stocks that weighed on the market. Viacom (VIA) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) created a lot of static for investors, losing 7% and 6%, respectively.
In the weak week, large-cap growth funds fared best among all market-capitalization-and-style mutual fund categories. They gained 1.38%, lifting their year-to-date gain to 6.42%.
Small-cap value funds fared worst, losing 3.28%. That dropped their year-to-date loss to 1.93%, worst among cap-and-style groups.
Small-cap growth funds retained year-to-date leadership among cap-and-style categories, with a 6.61% gain.
Among other U.S. diversified stock fund groups, dedicated short bias funds gained 5.81%, showing that bets on stocks losing ground paid off.
Real estate funds did best among sector categories in the latest week. With dividends suddenly looking attractive among the week's stock carnage, they gained 2.71%.
Precious metal funds — reflecting the woes of all commodities — had the worst week among sectors, losing 19.88%. That padded their year-to-date loss to 23.84%, also worst among sectors.
Health/biotechnology funds held on to their year-to-date lead among sectors with a 17.90% gain.
World equity funds fell 1.87% in the latest week, cutting their year-top-date gain to 3.19%.
Among foreign stock funds, India region funds performed best in the latest week, gaining 3.20%. That built their year-to-date gain to 6.80%.
Latin American funds fared worst in the latest week, plunging 10.77%. That extended their loss for the year to 17.07%.
Japanese funds stayed atop world equity fund groups year to date, rising 17.44%.
Like stocks on Tuesday, taxable bonds reflected concerns about the prospect of the Fed starting to raise interest rates soon.
Taxable bond funds lost 0.29% in the latest week despite Treasury funds' gain of 2.61%, which trimmed their year-to-date loss to 0.09%.
High-yield bond funds lost 1.09% in the latest week, and emerging market local currency funds knifed down 4.04%.
Tax-exempt bond funds gained 0.54% in the latest week. That lifted their year-to-date return to 0.32%.

Despite the week's stock-fund setbacks and underlying concerns, Nuveen Asset Management portfolio manager and chief equity strategist Bob Doll voiced a guardedly bullish outlook ahead in his weekly commentary.
Lower energy prices, he wrote, should fuel overall economic growth, and consumer spending in particular.
"This should ultimately provide a tailwind for stock prices," he wrote.
In fact, U.S. GDP growth is gaining steam. And the global economy is growing. Also, global monetary easy-money policies should boost stocks.

Still, David Joy, chief market strategist for Ameriprise Financial, wrote in his weekly commentary that negative headlines about China and Greece will dampen consumer confidence and spending.U.S. diversified stock funds slid 0.54% on average in the week ended Aug. 6, ending a one-week rally. Competitive threats are weighing on Netflix (NFLX) stock as the company continues its rapid global rollout. As the world's leading Internet television service, Netflix has a big bull's eye on its back and rivals such as Alibaba (BABA), Amazon.com (AMZN), Apple (AAPL) and Hulu are taking aim.

Netflix stock closed down 0.33% on the stock market today, its fourth straight down day and the second in a row below its 50-day moving average. Netflix stock touched a record high above 129 on Aug. 5.

On Wednesday, Netflix launched its streaming video service in Japan in partnership with SoftBank. Los Gatos, Calif.-based Netflix now offers service in more than 50 countries, mostly in the Americas and Europe.

Back in the U.S., Hulu announced a commercial-free streaming video service for $11.99 a month and Amazon said its Prime customers will be able to download streaming content to view later on their mobile devices. Plus, Apple is rumored to be in talks with Hollywood studios about producing original shows for a possible streaming service.
Hulu Adds Ad-Free Option
The commercial-free Hulu service eliminates one of the biggest user complaints about Hulu. However, Hulu will still offer a lower-priced, advertiser-supported service tier for $7.99 a month.

"At Hulu, we pride ourselves on listening to our customers and giving them the best possible experience," Hulu CEO Mike Hopkins said in a blog post Wednesday. "Many of our customers have asked us for a commercial-free option, and so today we are excited to introduce just that. Providing more choice for consumers is fundamental to the Hulu experience, in addition to an array of choices in content and devices, our customers can now choose to watch with or without commercials."
Hulu has been bucking up its content lineup lately through licensing deals, such as with Epix, and with original shows, such as "Difficult People," "Deadbeat" and "The Hotwives."
Hulu is owned by Comcast (CMCSA), Walt Disney (DIS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA).
Amazon Allows Offline Video Viewing

Amazon announced Tuesday that Prime members in the U.S., U.K., Germany and Austria now can download movies and TV episodes to iPhones, iPads and Android phones and tablets for offline viewing, at no additional charge.
Offline viewing is ideal for people who want to watch video on a plane, in a car, or at the beach, anywhere where wireless service isn't available or is cost prohibitive, Amazon said.
Amazon Prime Video offers a range of licensed Hollywood movies, network and cable TV shows, as well as original programs like "Transparent," "Catastrophe" and "Bosch."
Apple Exploring Original Content

Apple has long been rumored to be working on a streaming video service. Entertainment trade newspaper Variety reported Monday that Apple has held preliminary discussions with Hollywood executives about funding original shows.
Apple is believed to be negotiating with broadcasters to offer a "best of cable" package of channels for its Internet pay-TV service.
Apple is expected to unveil a fourth-generation Apple TV set-top box at a press event next Wednesday, Sept. 9.

"Apple clearly has deep pockets to invest in original programming, including maybe securing top creative talent with long-term deals to produce exclusively for an Apple TV, iOS, etc. platform," Rosenblatt Securities analyst Martin Pyykkonen said in a report Wednesday.
Alibaba Beats Netflix To China
Alibaba this week launched a subscription video service called TBO, or Tmall Box Office, in its home market of China.
Alibaba says it wants to be the equivalent of HBO and Netflix in China.
Netflix has its own designs on China. It expects to launch a modest service next year and learn as it grows.

Entertainment trade newspaper Variety reported Monday that Apple has held preliminary discussions with Hollywood executives about funding original shows.Apple is believed to be negotiating with broadcasters to offer a "best of cable" package of channels for its Internet pay-TV service.Apple is expected to unveil a fourth-generation Apple TV set-top box at a press event next Wednesday, Sept. 9."Apple clearly has deep pockets to invest in original programming, including maybe securing top creative talent with long-term deals to produce exclusively for an Apple TV, iOS, etc. platform," Rosenblatt Securities analyst Martin Pyykkonen said in a report Wednesday.Alibaba Beats Netflix To ChinaAlibaba this week launched a subscription video service called TBO, or Tmall Box Office, in its home market of China.Alibaba says it wants to be the equivalent of HBO and Netflix in China.Netflix has its own designs on China. It expects to launch a modest service next year and learn as it grows.RELATED: Netflix success hinges on steady flow of hit shows
In addition to being affected by the market's volatility, Netflix (NFLX) shares are getting hit hard in the stock market today as competition in the streaming space heats up.

Variety reported late Monday that Apple (AAPL) has had early talks with Hollywood executives about obtaining original content to go along with its not-yet-announced streaming service. It's not yet apparent whether Apple would develop movies and/or TV shows, create an in-house studio or work with outside production companies, as Netflix has.

Netflix gapped down 8.6% in fast trade, falling back below its 50-day moving average. It's on track for its third straight session of losses. Shares are now about 18% below their all-time high of 129.29, reached on August 5.
Apple shares were also trading lower, down 2.4%.

Netflix is looking to expand its own original content. It confirmed over the weekend that it was dropping its deal with Epix, a joint venture of Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF), Viacom (VIAB)-owned Paramount and MGM. That means no more "Hunger Games: Catching Fire" or "Transformers: Age of Extinction," among other high-profile flicks, at the end of September.

But the streaming site noted that it has Adam Sandler and Judd Apatow original movies in the pipeline. And starting next year, Netflix says, it will be the home for the latest movies from Disney (DIS), including its upcoming Pixar, Lucasfilm and Marvel films.

The company's decision not to renew its agreement with Epix opened up an opportunity for rival Hulu to become the cable network's partner. Disney, Comcast (CMCSA) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) own Hulu. Amazon (AMZN) also has a deal with Epix.

Elmo, meet the Mother of Dragons. Time Warner's (TWX) HBO is bringing Elmo and Cookie Monster to Khaleesi's territory with a five-year deal to air and stream new episodes of beloved kids' program "Sesame Street," as the "Game of Thrones" network sets its sights not on the fictional turf of Westeros but the very real battleground of on-demand media. Under…
Time Warner's decision to sell HBO on the Web in 2015 and CBS' plans to launch a subscription streaming service are fresh proof to pay-TV companies that the trend is not their friend.

Federal regulators are mulling rules to help Internet TV providers acquire content and live programming from media companies. Dish Network (DISH), Verizon Communications (VZ) and Sony are ramping up Internet video, also called over-the-top (OTT) services, that may soon debut.

The Web streaming services target young adults and other consumers that "cut the cord," industry jargon for the growing number of people that disconnect pay-TV service in favor of more affordable online video options and on-demand content.

As pay-TV subscriptions fall, cable-TV channels such as Walt Disney's (DIS) ESPN and TNT reach fewer U.S. households, impacting their revenue stream. More advertising dollars, meanwhile, are flowing to Google's (GOOGL) YouTube and other online streaming websites as broadcast TV audience ratings fall.
Cable Has Broadband

Shares in Comcast (CMCSA), Time Warner Cable (TWC), satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network and other pay-TV companies fell on Thursday as investors digested the latest moves from Time Warner's (TWX) HBO and CBS (CBS). Pay-TV stocks rallied Friday.
Pay-TV companies face big challenges to preserve their ecosystem in the face of a growing OTT threat.

"The Golden Goose appears to be shedding some feathers," said Mike McCormack, a Jefferies analyst, referring to the annual increases in pay-TV subscriber bills that have fed cable industry free cash flows as well as programming fee increases garnered by media companies.
On the other hand, "The Goose is not cooked quite yet," McCormack added.
Cable TV companies are likely better off than satellite TV providers, he says.

That's because cable TV companies are the biggest providers of high-speed Internet services to homes. They stand to keep that revenue stream as online streaming services expand and likely require faster connections.
Satellite TV Woes
Satellite firms don't sell broadband services. With prospects for video subscriber growth bleak, DirecTV Group (DTV) agreed in May to be acquired by AT&T (T).

Much depends on the ability of Internet service providers to charge a premium for the fastest broadband connections, perhaps bundled with out-of-home Wi-Fi, analysts say. Long-run, Internet service providers could try to impose usage-based billing systems, though regulators might block that course.

To target cord cutters looking for "a la carte" packages, marketing may shift to broadband-first deals. Comcast, Cox and AT&T have stepped up promotions of cheaper, $40 to $50 monthly plans that feature high-speed Internet and basic TV — without ESPN, Discovery and other channels. In the future, pay-TV companies may package their broadband products with popular streaming services from Netflix (NFLX), Amazon.com (AMZN) or Hulu, says Moody's analyst Karen Berckmann.
What's clear is that the pay-TV ecosystem is fraying.

HBO's decision to launch a stand-alone Web offering that does not require consumers to have a cable TV or satellite subscription could mark a turning point, some analysts say, by encouraging more cable partners to dabble in Web offerings.
Time Warner had been "the most stalwart protector of the status quo," said Craig Moffett, analyst at MoffettNathanson.

Disney's ESPN sports channel, an early adopter of online streaming services, has required users of its app to log in as pay-TV customers, a process called authentication. The danger for pay-TV companies is that more media companies will stray from the TV Everywhere authentication model and offer content directly to consumers via the Web.

HBO CEO Richard Plepler cited 10 million "broadband-only" homes in the U.S. in explaining its decision. "In 2015 we will go beyond the wall and launch a stand-alone, over-the-top service with the potential to produce hundreds of millions in revenue," Plepler said at Time Warner's investor day. Half of the 10 million homes subscribe to streaming video services, he said. HBO's 10 million figure doesn't refer only to cord-cutters as such, because it includes homes that never had pay-TV.

HBO's rivalry with Netflix as well as 21st Century Fox's (FOXA) aborted bid for Time Warner may have contributed to the decision to launch a stand-alone streaming service, analysts say. HBO generated $4.9 billion in 2013 revenue vs. $4.4 billion at Netflix, whose sales jumped 21% last year.

Netflix late Wednesday said Q3 subscriber growth fell short of its forecasts. The company also reported rising content acquisition costs and gave a weak Q4 EPS forecast. Its stock plunged 19% Thursday.

HBO did not disclose a launch date, pricing, or other specifics of its streaming strategy. One decision HBO faces, analysts say, is whether to make hit shows such as "Game of Thrones" available at the same time to Web and pay-TV customers, or delay Internet availability. Cable TV companies typically charge $15 monthly for HBO as part of top-tier plans.

Barclays analyst Kannan Venkateshwar says HBO still has a lot at stake in the pay-TV ecosystem, including 30 million U.S. subscribers. If HBO's goal is tapping new consumer demographics, Venkateshwar says it can do that by teaming with cable TV firms for "skinny broadband packages."
Comcast's Internet Plus bundle includes 25 Mbps Internet service, basic TV and HBO for $50. Cox's $60 "Flex Watch" package includes 50 Mbps broadband, basic TV, HBO and Starz.

The cable plans now require customers to get a set-top box to access HBO. But, Venkateshwar sees them evolving toward broadband-only services. Cable industry-led plans, he says, "have the potential to reshape the competitive dynamics for HBO relative to Netflix."

If consumers don't buy Internet services as part of a "triple play" or "double play" bundle that includes video and/or phone services, pay-TV firms typically charge $20 to $30 more monthly. Even so, cord-cutters don't have to pay for channels they don't watch. Pay-TV companies have passed on rising programming fees to consumers in monthly bills.

Jefferies' McCormack calls sports programming the "ace-in-the-hole" of pay-TV companies. CBS broke new ground by offering live streaming as part of its new $6 monthly "All Access" service. But, CBS' streaming service doesn't include National Football League games or other live sports.Time Warner's decision to sell HBO on the Web in 2015 and CBS' plans to launch a subscription streaming service are fresh proof to pay-TV companies that the trend is not their friend.Federal regulators are mulling rules to help Internet TV providers acquire content and live programming from media companies. Gannett (GCI), the owner of USA Today, announced Tuesday it would spin off its publishing business into a separate company to focus on its broadcast and digital holdings.
The media company said its publishing company would keep the Gannett name and be listed on the NYSE while the broadcasting arm, which hasn't been named, will also trade on the NYSE.
Chief Executive Gracia Martore was named the CEO of the new broadcasting company, while Robert Dickey, president of the U.S. Community Publishing division, was named CEO of the print company
Shares rose initially to 35.60 on the stock market today, but quickly reversed to trade down 0.3% to 34.23.

The spin-off comes as other media outlets split off their less-profitable print units. Rupert Murdoch hived off News Corp. (NWSA) from 21st Century Fox (FOXA). Time Warner (TWX) pushed out Time magazine and other print assets into Time Inc. (TIME)

Gannett also announced Tuesday the purchase of the rest of Cars.com for $1.8 billion from fellow media companies, including Belo Corp. and McClatchy (MNI). The deal will be paid for with cash on hand and new senior notes.

Apple (AAPL) is unlikely to bid for Time Warner or make a major content acquisition of that size, says BMO Capital Markets in a research report analyzing whether others might join 21st Century Fox (FOXA) in pursuing Time Warner.
Time Warner (TWX) on Wednesday confirmed that it had rejected Rupert Murdoch-controlled Fox's $80 billion cash and stock offer for the company.
Time Warner, though, might be open to a sale if more suitors surface, says BMO Capital Markets.

"We don't believe Time Warner would consider a sale without an auction process," said the report, in which analysts discussed whether potential buyers include Walt Disney (DIS), Amazon.com (AMZN), Google (GOOGL), Facebook (FB), Apple, Comcast (CMCSA), Verizon Communications (VZ) and AT&T (T).

Apple in May acquired Beats Music, a subscription streaming service, and Beats Electronics for $3 billion. There has been on-and-off speculation over the years that Apple could target Walt Disney. Apple has a large cash hoard, even after increasing shareholder returns.
However, BMO Capital Markets says Apple isn't looking to choose sides as TV distributors like Comcast and media-content firms grow bigger.

"We have struggled with the notion of Apple getting into the content game," said analyst Keith Bachman. "Such action would potentially limit content (on Apple's iOS platform) from other vendors, so we think Apple stays neutral on content and focuses on technology."
Comcast, which acquired NBCUniversal last year from General Electric (GE), is tied up seeking federal regulatory approval to merge with Time Warner Cable (TWC).
Media giant Time Warner spun off its cable TV business in 2009. AT&T, meanwhile, has agreed to purchase satellite TV broadcaster DirecTV Group (DTV). That deal also requires regulators' approval.
BMO Capital says it's unlikely that a phone or Internet company would bid for Time Warner. It says Disney has the financial muscle to bid, but is already "well-stocked" with content.

Rupert Murdoch's 21st Century Fox (FOXA) reportedly aims to take over Time Warner (TWX) as analysts say a wave of media consolidation beckons in the wake of proposed mergers among TV distributors. Time Warner's stock shot up 15% in early trading to 81.66 on the stock market today after the New York Times reported that 21st Century Fox bid $80…

Major League Baseball's strategy for the Internet this year includes more games and more ad revenue.MLB.TV, the league's online service that shows live baseball games over the Internet that are not shown locally on TV, will provide its paid premium-plan subscribers with first-time access to the World Series, All-Star Game and some previously unavailable national games. It also plans to get more advertising revenue from the service.Making the games more accessible helps subscribers who aren't always in front of a TV set and those who prefer to view the action on smartphones and tablets, says Robert Bowman, chief executive of MLB Advanced Media, the unit that manages all of the league's online subscription services."They might be on the go, they might be at a neighbor's house or they might be at an event and increasingly the younger fans are more comfortable with a personal device," he said. "I'm amazed at the amount of video my son watches on his (Apple (AAPL) iPhone."The list of new games available includes national games selected by Fox, a unit of 21st Century Fox (FOXA). For the first time, subscribers to the MLB.TV Premium plan can use the service to view Fox games not televised in their local market.MLB secured the rights in off-season talks with the TV network, Bowman says."Those restrictions got lifted by Fox in certain instances, which was something important to us in the renegotiation of the national TV deal," he said.Adding more games such as the World Series and giving the fans the choice of what device they can use to view them is another way to boost renewal rates and attract new subscribers, says Jonathan Hurd, director for business consulting firm Altman Vilandrie & Co."Consumers are so much now used to the idea of watching TV shows, movies and live events on tablets or computers that making the World Series available is a big positive for them," he said.MLB.TV Premium is MLB's most robust online product. The league sells the service along with a mobile application for $129.99 — the same price as last year but slightly more than the MLB.TV basic plan.MLB ended last year with more than 3 million total paid subscribers.With paid subscriptions growing at between 15% and 20% annually, MLB avoided raising the price while hoping to attract more fans, Bowman says."We are going to do just fine economically with keeping the price where it is," he said.Raising prices is always a balancing act for companies, says Hurd, who is also an MLB.TV subscriber."You want to come up with an overall value proposition and strike that balance between having more subscribers and maximizing revenue," he said.MLB's effort to attract more subscribers also extends to devices.This year, MLB.TV Premium subscribers can watch games via the Sony (SNE) PlayStation 4 and Microsoft (MSFT) Xbox One video game consoles. Both consoles debuted in November.That brings the total to more than 400 devices that can access the games via the premium package.MLB added Xbox One after the success of the Xbox 360, which reached 80 million in global sales last year, Bowman says.Another factor in MLB's favor is ad revenue.Ad revenue, particularly on mobile devices, is expected to rise as more companies target the two-minute gaps between innings, rather than promoting products in ads before and after games."More advertisers understand the value of video," he said. "We can serve video in stream, which makes it really popular with advertisers and not a pre-roll or a post-roll."Subscribers are also less likely to become annoyed with ads that appear in between innings than before or after a game, Hurd says."As a baseball fan I'm conditioned to the idea that once the third out comes I'm going to expect to see ads while I'm waiting for the next inning to start," he said.Most of MLB.TV's advertisers are the same national companies that sponsor the league's games on TV. But the regional aspect of the service also gives companies an opportunity to focus on specific areas or customers, Bowman says."They may be a national sponsor like Subway but they might geographically target it based on some (ad) campaign they're running in Philly but not in Boston," he said.

The U.S. Supreme Court, in a 6-3 decision, ruled that startup Aereo's TV-over-Internet service violated broadcasters' copyrights, a big win for broadcasters that sent shares of CBS and other media companies rising. CBS (CBS) stock was up 5% in early trading in the stock market today. Shares of Walt Disney (DIS), which owns ABC, and Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA) were…

Media and entertainment companies will gain from growing content demand by Internet video providers as well as traditional broadcast TV, says investment bank Jefferies, which on Thursday initiated coverage on the sector.
Jefferies analyst John Janedis started coverage with buy ratings on CBS (CBS), Walt Disney (DIS), Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA), Time Warner (TWX) and Viacom (VIA).

"Despite emerging threats to the business model, we believe entertainment companies will continue to benefit from the global demand for content (and) enjoy pricing power for both affiliate and retransmission (licensing) fees as well as advertising inventory, all buoyed by significant return of capital programs," wrote Janedis in a research report.

"Multiple expansion over the past two years has been significant, increasing from 13.5 times forward 12-month earnings to 17 times currently, as the market has better appreciated the business model," he added. "While we do not expect the outperformance of entertainment stocks to continue to the same degree of recent years, we think the fundamental backdrop for the industry is good enough for it to outperform, though we believe investors need to be more selective going forward."

The Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled that Aereo's TV-over-Internet service violates broadcasters' copyrights. The ruling sent many media stocks higher, including CBS, Walt Disney and Twenty-First Century Fox. Local TV-station owners E.W. Scripps (SSP) and Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) also gained.

"Aereo will no longer be able to avoid paying retransmission fees going forward," Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan said in a report published Thursday. "The ruling was largely as expected and is positive for the established pay-TV ecosystem. The ruling will also increase broadcaster leverage vs. the FCC in the upcoming incentive auction."

Proposed mergers among pay-TV companies, meanwhile, have been an overhang on media stocks. Comcast's (CMCSA) merger with Time Warner Cable (TWC) is under federal review. AT&T (T) has proposed acquiring DirecTV Group (DTV), the biggest satellite-TV broadcaster. Both Comcast and AT&T stand to gain negotiating clout over programming fees with content companies.

"Scale has been a key topic of discussion across media," wrote Janedis. "One potential reason some are more cautious on media stocks is the potential impact of mergers on affiliate fee growth and annual escalators.

"Over time, a significant amount of the overall synergies are expected to come in the form of programming cost savings from the Comcast/Time Warner Cable and AT&T/DirecTV deals. However, in our analysis, we think the practical impact on affiliate fee growth will be minimal. (The) deals will impact affiliate fees at some point, but the exact timing is unclear due to clauses in individual contracts."Media and entertainment companies will gain from growing content demand by Internet video providers as well as traditional broadcast TV, says investment bank Jefferies, which on Thursday initiated coverage on the sector.Jefferies analyst John Janedis started coverage with buy ratings on CBS (CBS), Walt Disney (DIS), Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA), Time Warner (TWX) and Viacom (VIA)."Despite emerging threats to the business model, we believe entertainment companies will continue to benefit from the global demand for content (and) enjoy pricing power for both affiliate and retransmission (licensing) fees as well as advertising inventory, all buoyed by significant return of capital programs," wrote Janedis in a research report."Multiple expansion over the past two years has been significant, increasing from 13.5 times forward 12-month earnings to 17 times currently, as the market has better appreciated the business model," he added. "While we do not expect the outperformance of entertainment stocks to continue to the same degree of recent years, we think the fundamental backdrop for the industry is good enough for it to outperform, though we believe investors need to be more selective going forward."The Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled that Aereo's TV-over-Internet service violates broadcasters' copyrights. The ruling sent many media stocks higher, including CBS, Walt Disney and Twenty-First Century Fox. Local TV-station owners E.W. Scripps (SSP) and Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) also gained."Aereo will no longer be able to avoid paying retransmission fees going forward," Oppenheimer analyst Tim Horan said in a report published Thursday. "The ruling was largely as expected and is positive for the established pay-TV ecosystem. The ruling will also increase broadcaster leverage vs. the FCC in the upcoming incentive auction."Proposed mergers among pay-TV companies, meanwhile, have been an overhang on media stocks. Comcast's (CMCSA) merger with Time Warner Cable (TWC) is under federal review. AT&T (T) has proposed acquiring DirecTV Group (DTV), the biggest satellite-TV broadcaster. Both Comcast and AT&T stand to gain negotiating clout over programming fees with content companies."Scale has been a key topic of discussion across media," wrote Janedis. "One potential reason some are more cautious on media stocks is the potential impact of mergers on affiliate fee growth and annual escalators."Over time, a significant amount of the overall synergies are expected to come in the form of programming cost savings from the Comcast/Time Warner Cable and AT&T/DirecTV deals. However, in our analysis, we think the practical impact on affiliate fee growth will be minimal. (The) deals will impact affiliate fees at some point, but the exact timing is unclear due to clauses in individual contracts."

The Supreme Court on Friday said it would hear broadcasters' challenge to startup Aereo, whose TV-over-Internet service has set off a legal battle vs. ABC, CBS (CBS), Fox and Comcast (CMCSA)-owned NBC. A ruling by the high court could come as soon as June. "It's great news for everyone involved. The sooner we can get some clarity the better," said…

The National Football League could split its NFL Sunday Ticket between DirecTV Group (DTV), which now has the rights, and Google's YouTube or another Internet video service provider, says Moody's Investor Service in a report. AT&T; (T) on Sunday announced an agreement to buy satellite broadcaster DirecTV for $48.5 billion, but the terms give it the right to walk away…

Charter Communications (CHTR) can't claim its consolation prize from the takeover battle for Time Warner Cable vs. Comcast until federal regulators rule on the industry's biggest proposed merger ever.
Charter shareholders seem fine with the scenario. Charter's stock has shot up since the company announced a complex deal with Comcast (CMCSA) on April 28.

If regulators, as expected, approve the merger of Comcast and Time Warner Cable (TWC) by year's end or early 2015, Charter would become the second biggest cable TV firm, though Comcast would be more than three times larger in subscribers.
The new Charter, whose biggest shareholder is the John Malone-controlled Liberty Media (LMCA), would wind up with a much different geographic makeup than the old Charter.

"(The Comcast deal) creates a highly efficient footprint for us in the Midwest and Southeast, communities where we think we can compete very well," said Charter CEO Thomas Rutledge on a conference call.
"The upside at the business, I think, is still there in terms of the ability to grow (pay-TV and broadband) penetration. So I think we've got a big runway in front of us," he added.
Serious Money

Comcast in mid-February agreed to buy Time Warner Cable for $45 billion. Comcast's all-stock offer beat out Charter's takeover bid. Comcast aims to pare its subscriber gains from the Time Warner Cable deal in order to ease critics' concerns that it'll wield too much clout in broadband services as well as in the entertainment industry.
Philadelphia-based Comcast would have nearly 33 million pay-TV subscribers if it were to gobble up Time Warner Cable whole.

Instead, Comcast has agreed to sell Charter 1.4 million subscribers for $7.3 billion in stage one of a deal. In stage two, Comcast would spin off 2.5 million subscribers into a new, Charter-managed public company.

Charter would use stock to buy a 33% stake in the new company. After two years, Charter could up its stake to 49%. In four years, Charter could buy out Comcast completely and own 100%. The entire deal has been valued at $20 billion.
If that scenario plays out, Charter would nearly double its size. It had 4.26 million video subscribers as of March 31.
Had Charter succeeded in buying Time Warner Cable, it would have amassed more than 15 million subscribers, with systems in New York City and Los Angeles.
Comcast winds up with subscriber clusters in New York state, California and Texas.
Charter could make more acquisitions, analysts say. Privately held Cox Communications, the third biggest cable firm, is not viewed as a likely seller, however.
"Given (Charter's) footprint in the Midwest, Bright House seems to be the best fit," said UBS analyst John Hodulik in a report.
Bright House Networks, part of Newhouse family's media holdings, is the No. 6 cable TV firm. Bright House has had programming ties to Time Warner Cable.

The new company spun off by Comcast, with 2.5 million customers, would include systems in Michigan, Indiana, Illinois and Minnesota. Bright House also operates cable systems in parts of Indianapolis and Detroit, Hodulik says.
Comcast and Charter, meanwhile, have agreed to swap 1.6 million cable TV subscribers.
Charter stands to gain Time Warner Cable's former assets in Ohio, Wisconsin, Kentucky, Indiana and parts of Alabama.
Comcast, in turn, would get Charter subscribers in Los Angeles as well as other parts of California, including Long Beach, Burbank and Glendale.

By acquiring Time Warner Cable, Comcast's systems will span 19 of the top 20 U.S. markets, including New York and Los Angeles. Time Warner Cable launched a sports network in Los Angeles in late 2012 after winning rights to Lakers basketball and Dodgers baseball games.
Comcast owns a majority stake in two Philadelphia-based sports teams and operates a dozen regional sports networks.

Comcast, which acquired all of media giant NBCUniversal last year from General Electric (GE), also owns the NBC Sports Network, which competes with Walt Disney 's (DIS) ESPN and Fox Sports One, a unit of 21st Century Fox (FOXA). From Charter, Comcast also would gain small cable systems in parts of New England and Fort Worth, Texas. Charter gets some side benefits from the Comcast deal.

The new Midwest-based company, with 2.5 million video subscribers, will be managed by Charter. The company will pay Charter a yearly management fee of 4.25% of its revenue, which could top $200 million annually, analysts say.
Plus, Charter will be able to use tax credits to increase free cash flow through the structure of the Comcast deal, say analysts.

Another positive for Charter shareholders is that following the Comcast transaction, it'll have even less market overlap vs. Verizon Communications (VZ), analysts say. Verizon's fiber-optic FiOS network, which provides Internet and TV service, is mostly on the East Coast.
Shifting
Verizon has more than 6 million FiOS Internet customers and 5.3 million TV customers, many of whom have switched over from cable TV companies.
"For Charter, low FiOS overlap is a key plank of the story," said Craig Moffett, analyst at MoffettNathanson.
Charter has withdrawn its slate of directors for the Time Warner Cable board, closing out its opposition to the Comcast deal.
Charter shareholders likely will root for federal regulators to give the Time Warner deal a green light, analysts say.

But Charter could revisit a Time Warner Cable bid if the deal is blocked. "In the unlikely event a deal is not approved by regulators, Charter appears to be the sole potential buyer for Time Warner Cable," said Jeff Wlodarczak, analyst at Pivotal Research.Charter Communications (CHTR) can't claim its consolation prize from the takeover battle for Time Warner Cable vs. Comcast until federal regulators rule on the industry's biggest proposed merger ever.Charter shareholders seem fine with the scenario. Internet video streamer Hulu says its 2013 revenue will jump nearly 44% to $1 billion.
By comparison, Google (GOOG)-owned YouTube will rake in $1.96 billion in net global digital ad revenues in 2013, up 66%, according to research firm eMarketer. Here's IBD's earlier report.
Hulu CEO Mike Hopkins, in a blog post Wednesday, said the online video company's number of advertisers rose 15% this year to more than 1,000 brands.
"It was also a record year for consumption as Hulu viewers streamed more than 1 billion content videos in each quarter," wrote Hopkins.

"This year, we reached 5 million subscribers. Roughly 50% of those subscribers are now streaming exclusively on devices, with living-room viewing accounting for over half of all content consumption on the service," he added.

Hulu's owners — 21st Century Fox (FOXA), Walt Disney (DIS) and Comcast (CMCSA), which doesn't have management control for regulatory reasons — took Hulu off the block this summer after exploring a sale.

Satellite broadcaster DirecTV Group (DTV) and Time Warner Cable (TWC) were reportedly among those interested in acquiring Hulu. Even if the TV-over-Internet startup wins its legal battle vs. ABC, CBS (CBS), Fox and NBC, there's a good chance Congress would then step in, analysts say. Aereo, which has won two federal court rulings, on Thursday asked the U.S. Supreme Court to hear TV broadcasters' appeal.…

Cable TV companies should hike their prices to offset rising programming costs, despite the threats posed by Netflix (NFLX) and cord-cutting, according to a new JPMorgan report. Cord-cutting refers to customers that disconnect pay-TV service and switch to free or low-cost Internet video. Comcast (CMCSA), Time Warner Cable (TWC) and others have added new broadcast TV surcharges and regional sports…

Dish Network (DISH) agreed to disable its ad-skipping "AutoHop" technology for ABC programming as part of a deal with Walt Disney Co. (DIS) that gives the satellite pay-TV broadcaster more rights to whisk content in and out of homes via the Internet.

Dish gained rights for a Web-based subscription service that will stream TV shows, sports and movies produced by Disney cable TV channels, ESPN and broadcaster ABC. The deal covers live content and video on demand.

Disney had sued Dish, with 14 million subscribers, over the "AutoHop" technology, which lets subscribers skip commercials on programs recorded on DVRs. The agreement ends litigation, the two companies said.

The two companies had extended talks, seeking to avoid a programming black-out, after their programming agreement expired at the end of September. Comcast (CMCSA), Time Warner Cable (TWC) and DirecTV Group (DTV) have also renewed deals with content providers such as Viacom (VIA), 21st Century Fox (FOXA), and CBS (CBS).
The wide-ranging agreement also covers advertising on mobile devices and dynamic ad insertion — commercials based on customer viewing data.
"The creation of this agreement has really been about predicting the future of television with a visionary and forward-leaning partner," Dish CEO Joseph P. Clayton said in a statement.
The companies also renewed carriage agreements for eight ABC local stations.

Dish's stock was unchanged in early trading in the stock market today.Dish Network (DISH) agreed to disable its ad-skipping "AutoHop" technology for ABC programming as part of a deal with Walt Disney Co. Google (GOOG) and Apple (AAPL) are unlikely to follow in the footsteps of cable TV firm Comcast (CMCSA) by acquiring a media giant, Bernstein Research says in a report, but it doesn't rule out smaller content purchases. Comcast, which acquired all of NBCUniversal from General Electric (GE) last year, is seeking regulatory approval to buy Time Warner Cable (TWC). Here's…

21st Century Fox (FOXA) kicks off Q3 earnings for media and entertainment companies on Tuesday after the market close, with Viacom (VIA) ending the string of reports with its results Nov. 14. Media stocks have posted healthy gains in 2013. IBD's 23-company Media-Diversified group is up 52% this year and ranks No. 32 of 197 groups tracked. It's ranked between…
Higher-than-expected Q2 revenue growth at NBC Universal and a 20% hike in broadband subscriber additions sent shares of Comcast rising 5.6% Wednesday.

The nation's No. 1 cable TV system operator said it earned 65 cents per share, up 30% from the year-earlier period and 2 cents above analyst estimates. Philadelphia-based Comcast (CMCSA) said revenue rose 7% to $16.2 billion, also ahead of expectations.
Comcast said it added 187,000 broadband Internet customers, up from 156,000 in Q2 2012. Comcast said it lost 159,000 video subscribers, fewer than the 176,000 it shed in the year-earlier period.
Cable revenue increased 5.8% to $10.5 billion, boosted by 26% growth in business services, to $788 million.
While Comcast's cable unit turned in solid results, NBC Universal shined, analysts said.
"Cable networks beat. Film beat. Even the peacock (TV broadcaster NBC) beat," Craig Moffett, analyst at Moffett Research, told IBD.
Q2 revenue at NBCU rose 8.9% to $6 billion, Comcast said. NBCU's cable TV network revenue increased 7.7% to $2.4 billion.

Broadcast TV sales rose 11.6% to $1.7 billion, as higher prime-time ratings drove an increase in advertising. Filmed entertainment revenue increased 12.8% to $1.4 billion, boosted by the movie "Fast and Furious 6."
NBCU's operating cash flow rose 21.3% to $1.19 billion.
"Growth at NBCU is accelerating with much better-than-expected ad revenue at broadcast and cable networks," said Macquarie Capital analyst Amy Yong in a research report.
Comcast bought out General Electric's (GE) remaining stake in NBC Universal for $16.7 billion in February. It acquired 51% of NBCU from GE in early 2011.

Comcast's cable channels — Syfy, Bravo, USA Network, E, Style, Golf and CNBC — generated 70% of NBCU's Q2 operating cash flow, earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. Cable network EBITDA rose 8.9% to $860 million, while broadcaster NBC's rose 6.4% to $206 million.
Comcast has put in "a very strong management team" at NBC Universal, including CEO Steve Burke, says Moffett.
Needs More Voices
"Broadcast TV is the key to hopes for a meaningful turnaround for NBCU," Moffett added.

"The Voice" has helped NBCU improve TV ratings, but it needs to develop more hit shows, analysts say. Aside from competing with Walt Disney's (DIS) ABC, CBS (CBS) and Fox, NBCU must contend with Netflix (NFLX), Amazon.com (AMZN), AMC Networks (AMCX) and other video services that are developing more original content.
Moffett says Comcast needs to create more marketing tie-ups between NBCU's content and the core cable TV business.

"There have been a few anecdotal examples of synergy — they used to talk a lot about promoting 'The Voice' on Comcast Cable, for example — but the real evidence for vertical synergies is hard to come by," Moffett said.
Comcast, meanwhile, continues to add content for NBC Sports. In mid-July, NBC Sports signed a 10-year deal with auto racing circuit Nascar.

NBC Sports also has rights to NHL hockey games and English soccer, but competition remains tough. 21st Century Fox (FOXA) launches its new national sports network on Aug. 17. Called Fox Sports 1, it'll take on Disney's ESPN and NBC Sports.
Comcast says it's not fretting the Fox Sports 1 launch, but analysts say bidding for rights could drive up costs.

"I don't think it changes the playing field for NBC Sports too much," Comcast CFO Michael Angelakis said on the company's earnings call. "We've always had a lot of competition for rights with ESPN and Fox and Turner."

Comcast is investing in its entertainment business. NBCU's capital spending will rise about 50% in 2013 to about $1.1 billion, mostly driven by improvements at theme parks. Comcast has also upped capital spending on its cable business, aiming to add Wi-Fi coverage in public locations, expand its network to reach more smaller businesses, increase broadband speeds and develop new digital technologies to deliver content to homes.
Cable capital spending rose 10.4% in Q2 to $1.24 billion, and overall capital spending jumped 17% to $1.51 billion.
Q2 is seasonally weak for cable TV companies because college students and homeowners who move disconnect service.

Comcast's addition of 187,000 broadband customers and fewer video subscriber losses "were particularly impressive considering heavy marketing from both AT&T (T) and Verizon during the quarter," said Jeffrey Wlodarczak, an analyst at Pivotal Research, in a research note.
Shares of Comcast have risen 21% in 2013.

Comcast has also upped capital spending on its cable business, aiming to add Wi-Fi coverage in public locations, expand its network to reach more smaller businesses, increase broadband speeds and develop new digital technologies to deliver content to homes.Cable capital spending rose 10.4% in Q2 to $1.24 billion, and overall capital spending jumped 17% to $1.51 billion.Q2 is seasonally weak for cable TV companies because college students and homeowners who move disconnect service.Comcast's addition of 187,000 broadband customers and fewer video subscriber losses "were particularly impressive considering heavy marketing from both AT&T (T) and Verizon during the quarter," said Jeffrey Wlodarczak, an analyst at Pivotal Research, in a research note.Shares of Comcast have risen 21% in 2013.

If startup Aereo prevails in a legal battle that has reached the U.S. Supreme Court, the pay-TV industry structure that supports "retransmission fee" payments to TV broadcasters would still carry on, at least until existing contracts expire, RBC Capital Markets said in a report Tuesday. The Supreme Court in January said it will hear broadcasters' challenge to startup Aereo, whose…
Add NBCUniversal to the list of TV broadcasters looking to latch onto the pay-TV gravy train, even if parent Comcast isn't smiling at higher programming costs.

Shares of CBS (CBS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) have been on a two-year roll, partly on views that high-margin carriage fees that pay-TV service providers pay to broadcasters will increase. The outcome of CBS' recent clash with Time Warner Cable (TWC) has reinforced views that broadcasters are sitting in the catbird seat, unless federal regulators step in to head off further disputes between media firms and pay-TV distributors.

The per-subscriber fees that Time Warner Cable pays CBS to retransmit CBS' TV signals over its network reportedly will double over the next five years. CBS had set a goal of doubling its retransmission fees to $1 billion by 2016. That "appears very doable at this point," noted UBS analyst John Janedis in a report.
Fox is in a similar position. Morgan Stanley analyst Benjamin Swinburne estimates Fox's retransmission revenue will hit $1.1 billion by 2017, up from $400 million this year.

Owned by cable firm Comcast (CMCSA), NBCUniversal has been less aggressive in targeting hikes in retransmission fees. Comcast pays those fees to CBS, Fox and Walt Disney Co. (DIS), which owns the ABC broadcast network.

NBC, though, is ready to boost those fees as its contracts with cable, satellite and phone pay-TV providers come up for renewal. Steve Burke, NBCUniversal's CEO, said at last month's Bank of America/Merrill Lynch media conference that he expects NBC to make up ground.
NBC's retransmission fees, about $200 million this year, will jump by 2017, he says.

Higher retransmission fees are "now part of the ecosystem. I'd be surprised if that changes," Burke said at the conference. " We need to get the same kind of retransmission-consent dollars that CBS and Fox and ABC get if we want to be competitive with them and invest in programming the way they do."
CBS: $2 Per Subscriber?

CBS and Time Warner Cable didn't disclose terms of their recent deal, reached only after TWC blocked CBS for a month as they haggled over fees. Analysts speculate CBS will rake in nearly $2 per cable subscriber by 2017, up from about 75 cents in its earlier agreement.
Morgan Stanley estimates NBC will garner $1 billion in retransmission revenue in 2017, and CBS $1.3 billion.

TV broadcasters have gained more bargaining leverage since cable companies have sought rights to whisk programming to mobile devices outside of homes under "TV Everywhere" business models. In addition, cable TV firms aim to keep broadcasters in their pay-TV ecosystem, rather than explore more distribution via the Internet.
CBS, though, was careful in its TWC deal to retain its ability to provide its own online video streaming services.

Higher retransmission fees for the broadcast networks mark a new twist in the pay-TV industry's programming costs. Pay-TV companies still pay much higher fees to cable networks, such as Disney's ESPN, TNT, USA Network or American Movie Channel.
Research firm SNL Kagan has estimated that retransmission fees paid by pay-TV companies could reach $4.3 billion in 2015, up from $3 billion in 2013.
Still, retransmission feeds would be only 10% of the estimated $43 billion that pay-TV operators are expected to pay cable networks in 2016.
On the other hand, retransmission fees will account for nearly 6% of broadcaster revenue by 2016, up from 1% in 2008, says investment firm Veronis Suhler Stevenson.
As the CBS-Time Warner battle ends, pay-TV distributor Dish Network (DISH) and Disney are locked in talks over both broadcasting rights and cable network fees.

To cope with escalating programming costs, analysts expect more pay-TV companies to merge. Analysts speculate that satellite-TV firms DirecTV Group (DTV) and Dish could merge. Some see a TWC-Charter Communications (CHTR) marriage.
Mergers would increase the bargaining power of pay-TV companies in negotiations over programming fees, says Citigroup analyst Jason Bazinet in a report.

"We do not expect premium channels, retransmission fees or video-on-demand to see material reductions in revenues if the pay TV firms consolidate. But we do expect national cable networks and regional sports networks to bear the brunt of pay TV's newfound scale," he wrote.Add NBCUniversal to the list of TV broadcasters looking to latch onto the pay-TV gravy train, even if parent Comcast isn't smiling at higher programming costs.Shares of CBS (CBS) and 21st Century Fox (FOXA) have been on a two-year roll, partly on views that high-margin carriage fees that pay-TV service providers pay to broadcasters will increase.
